node.title: 1101 AI-pollo
node.excerpt: We are a multicultural team including people from Brazil, Turkey and India. We focus on AI and software development knowledge.

projectDetails.name: Project 1101 AI-pollo
projectDetails.summary:
ExoDetect AI is an exoplanet discovery pipeline that turns NASAâ€™s Kepler photometry into actionable candidate rankings.

We reimagined the classification stack around an FT-Transformer trained with self-supervised objectives on millions of stellar light-curve summaries, learning feature embeddings before any labeled supervision. This representation pretraining captures subtle photometric correlationsâ€”color indices, extinction, metallicityâ€”that classical tabular models often miss, enabling the transformer to flag rare but promising planetary signatures with higher recall.

When the self-supervised backbone is fine-tuned on curated confirmation labels and deployed alongside our legacy tree-based ensemble, it consistently surfaces additional high-confidence candidates while maintaining a low false-positive rate.

By packaging the model inside an accessible web API and UI, we equip mission scientists and citizen researchers to score new stars instantly, prioritize follow-up observations, and accelerate the validation cycle for small, low-signal planets that traditional pipelines overlook.
projectDetails.details:
ExoDetect AI ingests features about star systems, applies a shared preprocessing pipeline, and then routes each record through a self-supervised FT-Transformer alongside four gradient-boosted baselines.

The transformerâ€™s pretraining on unlabeled light-curve summaries yields richer embeddings, so its supervised head can spot faint transit signatures while keeping false alarms low; tree models provide interpretable cross-checks.

Deployed as a Flask REST API with a static JS frontend, the system delivers single, JSONL, and CSV scoring plus live model metrics, enabling mission teams to triage thousands of targets in seconds. Our stack relies on Python (Flask, pandas, PyTorch, scikit-learn), Torch for the transformer, Docker for reproducible deployment, and a lightweight HTML/CSS/JS interface.

We leaned into creativity by adapting vision-style pretraining to tabular astrophysics data, aligning feature engineering with astrophysical priors, and bundling the results in a scientist-friendly UI.

Key considerations included class imbalance, calibration across heterogeneous models, inference latency within CPU-only containers, and preserving interpretability so astronomers can relate predictions back to stellar physics.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: BloomWatch: An Earth Observation Application for Global Flowering Phenology
challengeDetails.excerpt: Witness the pulse of life across our planet! From season to season and year to year, Earthâ€™s vegetation is constantly changing, providing critical information on plant species, crops, seasonal effects, pollen sources, and changes in plant phenology (the relationship between seasonal changes and climate and biological phenomena in plants). Your challenge is to harness the power of NASA Earth observations to create a dynamic visual tool that displays and/or detects plant blooming events around the globeâ€”just like pollinators doâ€“and that advances solutions for monitoring, predicting, or managing vegetation. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Cosmic Windows
projectDetails.summary: The project aims to create an accessible and user-friendly website for everyone interested in viewing space images captured and stored by NASA, with the goal of reducing complexity and making access more practical and less burdensome for the general public. The challenge essentially proposes new ways, uses, and applications for NASAâ€™s images, from zooming in to discovering new patterns. Building on this idea, we created a simple website for the general public to view and explore the images provided by NASAâ€™s API. Through a straightforward search, the site navigates the vast dataset, allowing users to continue their own space investigations. The main and most important point is that the website democratizes and simplifies access to complex space data and images that are otherwise difficult for the general public to obtain.
projectDetails.details:
It provides clear and accessible information, enabling searches across NASAâ€™s vast database, and remains highly performant.
By lowering technical barriers, it democratizes access to knowledge for people who have the time, interest, or expertise â€” and especially for those who do not.

The intended impact of the project is to expand the dissemination of scientific knowledge and spark curiosity among the general public. By making NASAâ€™s data and images easy to find, understand, and explore, the platform transforms passive observers into active participants in discovery.

We built the project using Python, CSS, HTML, Flask, Jupyter notebooks, Redis, PostGIS, DNS, a GoDaddy-registered domain, Hander, Figma, and Canva.
Our creative process followed three pillars: Ideation, Development, and Presentation, ensuring a strong link between user needs, technical execution, and storytelling.

The core factors guiding our approach were education and the democratization of knowledge â€” aligning with NASAâ€™s mission to inspire and engage people everywhere.
By connecting cutting-edge data infrastructure with an intuitive user experience, the project reflects the spirit of citizen science and inclusion that has defined many of the most impactful Space Apps winners from Brazil in recent years.

challengeDetails.title: Embiggen Your Eyes!
challengeDetails.excerpt: While your cell phone screen can display about three million pixels of information and your eye can receive more than ten million pixels, NASA images from space are even bigger! NASAâ€™s space missions continue to push the boundaries of what is technologically possible, providing high-resolution images and videos of Earth, other planets, and space with billions or even trillions of pixels. Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Guardions Of JalapÃ£o
projectDetails.summary:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, Brazilian middle school students, and we developed the project "Guardians of JalapÃ£o," which addresses the favorable Brazilian climate conditions for harvesting Golden Grass. Inspired by the proposed challenge and the Golden Grass Women's Project, which uses sustainable agricultural practices for the production and harvesting of golden grass, our goal was to develop an educational game to raise awareness about the importance of such initiatives that use natural resources through sustainable management based on ideal climate conditions.

Therefore, the relevance of this project lies in simulating a resource collection scenario (temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture) and providing players with information about the correct and ideal management of golden grass harvesting. This game is intended to be made available to students as a way to raise awareness about sustainability and proper golden grass management. Additionally, it could be displayed in museums and at the headquarters of the Golden Grass Women's Project to highlight the ideal conditions and the consequences of resource collection according to the seasons.
projectDetails.details:
We are the Alpha Mackenzie team, and our project, "Guardians of JalapÃ£o," is aligned with Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 15, which focuses on life on land. Thatâ€™s why we chose to work with Golden Grass â€” a resource widely used in the JalapÃ£o region for the production of handicrafts that generate income for local communities â€” by understanding the most favorable climate conditions for its growth and harvest.

We developed a game using the tools available on Scratch, with the main purpose of raising awareness about the harvesting of Golden Grass in the JalapÃ£o region, based on the climate characteristics we researched and how they affect the collection of this resource. The gameâ€™s primary goal is to promote awareness about the extraction of Golden Grass and how it grows throughout the seasons of the year. It serves as a tool to present the data and information collected, helping the public understand and become more conscious of this issue.

Golden Grass (Syngonanthus nitens) is a plant native to the Brazilian Cerrado, especially found in JalapÃ£o (Tocantins state). It is used to make handicrafts that symbolize the local culture, such as bags and jewelry. Its sustainable harvesting is regulated by the Tocantins Nature Institute (Naturatins) to ensure the conservation of the species. The grass is harvested annually after the seeds mature.

We collected data using Google Earth Engine and selected the JalapÃ£o region, where Golden Grass is most abundantly produced. Additionally, we uploaded a script with commands to retrieve climate characteristics such as temperature, precipitation, and soil moisture from last year (2024). Our main focus was on precipitation and temperature.

Based on this information, we identified the climate characteristics and associated them with their impact on the production and harvesting of Golden Grass, allowing us to understand the reactions caused by these factors. The game uses this data to show the player what happens depending on the amount of resources collected during gameplay.

"Guardians of JalapÃ£o" runs, as mentioned earlier, on Scratch â€” a free, open-source visual programming language developed at MIT to teach coding in a fun and accessible way. The user will access a link that redirects them to the game on Scratch. In the game, the player controls a character and collects clouds (precipitation), a thermometer (temperature), and a soil bar (soil moisture). Depending on the number of items the user collects, the outcome will change according to the climate conditions of JalapÃ£o for each season.

The ideal time for the player to achieve the best result is during spring, as it is the favorable season for harvesting Golden Grass in the region â€” a dry and arid period. If the user collects values that differ from the ideal, the game will inform them of the current season and its impact on the Golden Grass.

With this project, we aim to show how closely climate characteristics are linked to the development and harvesting of Golden Grass â€” a vital resource for income generation in the JalapÃ£o region. Furthermore, one of our goals is to bring the game to museums in the Cerrado region, especially those that focus on this biome, or to communities that work with this resource, particularly the "Golden Grass Women's Project." There, tourists could learn about the differences in Brazilâ€™s seasons and how they affect the harvesting of this plant. In this way, the game could be commercialized and made available for use in these locations (museums and community centers).

Therefore, the target audience for the game includes the communities that work with Golden Grass, organizations or institutions that deal with this resource or the Cerrado biome, and tourists visiting the aforementioned locations.

For the development of our project, we used the following technologies:

Scratch: A visual programming platform and block-based coding language that allows users to create games, animations, and interactive stories by dragging and dropping visual commands instead of writing complex code â€” used for creating the game developed by the team.

Google Earth Engine (a tool recommended by NASA): A geospatial data science platform that provides a massive catalog of satellite imagery and geographic data, along with cloud computing infrastructure for planetary-scale analysis â€” used for collecting, comparing, and analyzing climate data.

projectDetails.name: Project Farm Navigators
projectDetails.summary:
For the challenge NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture, we developed "Farm Navigators", an educational strategy card game designed to make complex Earth science data accessible and engaging. Players take the role of agricultural decision-makers, balancing four pillars â€” Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People â€” while making choices about irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management. Each decision carries trade-offs, teaching that agriculture involves dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Our game integrates real NASA datasets: NDVI/EVI (MODIS & Landsat) to monitor vegetation health, SMAP for soil moisture, GPM for precipitation, and MODIS LST for land surface temperature. These datasets inform the scenarios presented in the cards, grounding decisions in real-world science.

To enrich the narrative, we created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. Eliot provides short, subtly ironic reflections on each decision and, at the end of the game, the playerâ€™s results are added to a shared database. This allows participants to compare outcomes, fostering collective learning and a sense of responsibility for the world.

Demo: https://angelus-novus.vercel.app/
projectDetails.details:
Project Details â€“ Farm Navigators

Play it, here: https://angelus-novus.vercel.app/

What it does / how it works
Farm Navigators is an educational strategy card game that simulates real farming decisions using NASAâ€™s open datasets. Players must balance four pillars â€” Economy, Sustainability, Technology, and People â€” while managing irrigation, fertilization, and livestock. Each choice triggers trade-offs, showing that agriculture is a world of dilemmas rather than perfect solutions.

Benefits & Intended Impact
The game makes complex NASA Earth data accessible and engaging, helping players of all ages understand how environmental variables affect food production, sustainability, and social well-being. By linking real satellite data to everyday farming scenarios, it promotes climate awareness, sustainable practices, and data-driven thinking. The collective database of player results encourages reflection on global responsibility, as participants can compare whether their choices â€œhelped or harmed the world.â€

AI Integration â€“ Little Eliot
We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst. After each decision, Eliot generates short, subtly ironic commentaries suggesting possible futures. At the end, progress is recorded in a shared database, fostering a sense of community and collective learning.

Tools, Languages, and Frameworks
We combined modern tools to develop the project:

  • Lovable, Langflow, Cursor â€“ for AI workflows and prototyping.
  • React & TypeScript â€“ for the front-end interface.
  • FastAPI & MongoDB â€“ for backend logic and database storage.
  • ChatGPT-5 nano â€“ powering Eliotâ€™s generative AI responses.

Creativity & Design Considerations
We designed Farm Navigators to merge serious data with playful storytelling, blending strategy, education, and irony. Our key considerations were scientific accuracy, player engagement, and scalability, ensuring the game can grow into classrooms, communities, and global platforms.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Our project makes purposeful use of AI in both its game design and technical development:

  1. Narrative Gameplay â€“ Little Eliot
    • We created Little Eliot, an AI Agent acting as a Narrative Consequence Analyst.
    • Eliot uses a fine-tuned prompt with ChatGPT-5 nano to generate short, subtly ironic narrative commentaries after each player decision.
    • These outputs enrich the storytelling by suggesting possible consequences without referencing scores or game mechanics.
    • We used AI-assisted tools (such as Langflow, Cursor, and Lovable) to accelerate prototyping, workflow orchestration, and prompt optimization.
    • Draft texts, gameplay scenarios, and narrative examples were initially generated with AI, then refined by our team.
    • All AI-generated texts were reviewed and edited to align with the projectâ€™s educational goals.
    • Portions of boilerplate code and database handling were generated using AI tools to speed up development.
    • Metadata and documentation acknowledge AI contributions.

Compliance Measures

  • No NASA logos, mission identifiers, or official branding were generated or modified by AI.
  • Any AI-generated visuals or audio (if used in later stages) will carry visible AI-generated watermarks and proper metadata acknowledgments.

Through this integration, AI was not used to replace originality but to accelerate creativity, enhance gameplay, and prototype faster while keeping the final vision and design firmly in the hands of our team.

node.title: Asteroid Watchers
node.excerpt: We are the Asteroid Watchers, united by a shared passion for space, science, and the protection of our planet. Brought together by the NASA Space Apps challenge, we thrive on creativity, collaboration, and curiosity. Together we transform data and...

projectDetails.name: Project Asteroid Watchers
projectDetails.summary:
Our project is an interactive educational platform designed to translate complex asteroid science into an understandable visual experience. Using data from NASA APIs like the JPL Small-Body Database and NeoWs, we ensure each simulation is based on real celestial objects and their observed trajectories.

From primary data such as diameter and velocity, our platform applies principles of impact physics and orbital mechanics to calculate derived parameters, including mass, kinetic energy, and seismic energy release. Users can select a real asteroid and an impact location to visualize the consequences, including the fireball radius, shockwave propagation, devastating wind speeds, and the resulting earthquake's magnitude.

Beyond simulating the problem, our project also focuses on the solution. It serves as an educational tool to showcase the mitigation and deflection strategies that modern science offers, demystifying the dangers, creating solutions and empowering people with a clear understanding of the challenges and solutions in planetary defense.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

Asteroid Watchers is an educational web-based simulation platform that models near-Earth asteroid impacts and provides comprehensive analysis of potentially hazardous objects. The system works through several integrated components:

Data Collection & Processing: The platform utilizes NASA's NEO Web Service API to fetch real-time data about near-Earth objects for any selected date. The Python backend processes this data to calculate additional physical properties including mass estimation, orbital energy, and impact velocities using gravitational physics calculations.

Interactive 3D Visualization: Users can explore asteroids through a 3D preview system that allows rotation and zoom functionality to inspect object characteristics visually.

Impact Simulation Engine: The core functionality enables users to simulate asteroid impacts at any location on Earth by:

  • Selecting specific dates to view available near-Earth objects
  • Choosing from a list of asteroids with their approach distances
  • Placing impact coordinates on an interactive map
  • Running physics-based simulations that calculate crater size, casualty estimates, seismic effects, fireball radius, and shock wave impacts

Customization Tools: A creator module allows users to design custom asteroids with variable parameters (size, speed, composition) for experimental "what-if" scenarios.

Benefits and Intended Impact

Educational Value: The project transforms complex astronomical and physics concepts into accessible, interactive learning experiences. Students and educators can visualize the real consequences of asteroid impacts, making abstract scientific concepts tangible.

Public Awareness: By providing accurate data visualization of potentially hazardous asteroids, the platform increases public understanding of planetary defense challenges and the importance of asteroid monitoring programs.

Scientific Literacy: The simulator bridges the gap between raw NASA data and public comprehension, helping users understand orbital mechanics, impact physics, and risk assessment methodologies.

Research Support: The platform can assist researchers and educators in demonstrating impact scenarios and testing theoretical deflection strategies through the integrated deflection recommendation system.

Tools, Technologies, and Development Stack

Programming Languages:

  • Python for backend data processing and API integration
  • JavaScript for frontend interactivity
  • HTML/CSS for user interface design

APIs and Data Sources:

  • NASA NEO Web Service API for real-time asteroid data
  • WorldPop for displaying the real-time map to select the impact location
  • Gravitational physics calculations using standard astronomical constants

Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Python: requests for API calls and json for data parsing
  • Frontend: Modern web technologies for 3D rendering and interactive mapping

Deployment Platform: Vercel for web hosting and deployment

Physics Engine: Custom-built impact simulation using:

  • Gravitational constant calculations
  • Orbital mechanics formulas
  • Energy and momentum conservation principles
  • Seismic impact modeling

Creative and Innovative Aspects

Real-Time Data Integration: Unlike static educational tools, Asteroid Watchers provides live data from NASA's monitoring systems, ensuring users work with current astronomical information.

Multi-Layered Simulation: The platform combines orbital mechanics, atmospheric physics, and impact geology into a unified simulation experience, so it can provide user the most amount of data possible.

Deflection Strategy Integration: The system includes an innovative deflection recommendation algorithm that suggests appropriate planetary defense strategies based on asteroid proximity and characteristics.

User-Centric Design: The step-by-step guided interface makes complex astrophysics accessible to users without specialized knowledge while maintaining scientific accuracy.

Customization Capabilities: The creator module allows users to experiment beyond real asteroid data, fostering creative exploration of hypothetical scenarios.

Team Considerations and Factors

Scientific Accuracy vs. Accessibility: The team balanced computational precision with user-friendly presentation, using simplified physics models that remain educationally valuable while being computationally efficient.

Data Reliability: Careful consideration was given to handling incomplete or missing NASA data through reasonable estimation algorithms that maintain simulation functionality.

Educational Framework: The interface was designed with pedagogical principles, providing contextual help, unit clarifications, and step-by-step guidance to support learning objectives.

Performance Optimization: The team considered API rate limits and server performance, implementing efficient data caching and processing to ensure stable user experience.

Risk Communication: Ethical considerations were addressed in how impact simulation results are presented, ensuring users understand these are educational models, not predictive tools for actual events.

The project represents a comprehensive approach to space science education, combining real astronomical data with interactive simulation technology to create an engaging platform for understanding planetary defense challenges and asteroid impact physics.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI to understand the ThreeJs library, since all of members knew just a little of it. We also used some generated text to fill our web-app, to review some english text and also to generate AI Images, such as the group logo and the asteroid texture.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: AstroBit AI
projectDetails.summary:
AstroBit AI is an interactive web platform dedicated to exoplanet exploration. We developed a tool that integrates data from the NASA Exoplanet Archive (Kepler, K2, and TESS missions) and presents it in an accessible way, using dynamic visualizations, interactive charts, and an Artificial Intelligence-based analysis built with Python and Scikit-learn.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex astronomical data understandable. Through a responsive front-end and analysis dashboards, we enable anyone, even those without an academic background, to explore and identify patterns in exoplanet discovery, such as the distribution of planetary radii and orbital types.

AstroBit is important because it lowers the barrier between science and the public. By offering an intuitive and easily accessible tool, the platform encourages scientific engagement and astronomy education, inviting the community to actively participate in the search for new worlds and to expand our collective knowledge of the universe.
projectDetails.details:
Project Demo: https://astrobit-nasaspaceapps.onrender.com

What the project does and how it works?

AstroBit AI is an interactive web platform that uses Artificial Intelligence to analyze and classify exoplanet candidates. Its functionality is simple and direct:

  1. Data Input: Users can submit photometric transit data in two ways: by uploading a CSV file with multiple candidates or by manually entering the parameters for a single object.
  2. AI Processing: The data is sent to a Flask back-end server where a Machine Learning model (Random Forest Classifier)â€”trained on thousands of examples from the NASA Exoplanet Archiveâ€”analyzes the patterns.
  3. Classification and Visualization: The platform returns an instant classification, identifying the object as a Confirmed Planet, Candidate, or False Positive, and presents the results on a visual analysis page rich with charts and statistics.

What are the benefits and intended impact?

The main benefit is to democratize exoplanet science by making data analysis accessible to a wider audience.

  • For Scientists: It accelerates the initial screening of large datasets, allowing them to quickly focus on the most promising candidates.
  • For Amateur Astronomers and Students: It offers a powerful and educational tool to analyze public or personal data, promoting engagement in citizen science.

The intended impact is to inspire space exploration and provide a practical tool that bridges data science and astronomy, making the discovery process more transparent and engaging.

How is the project creative and what factors were considered?

AstroBit AI's creativity lies in its focus on Explainable AI (XAI) and user experience. Instead of being a "black box," the platform was designed to be a tool for exploration. Factors considered include:

  • Intuitive Interface: A clean and modern design that transforms complex numerical data into clear and understandable visualizations.
  • Model Transparency: The inclusion of charts like "Feature Importance" allows users to understand which variables were most decisive for the classification, building trust in the results and providing immense educational value.
  • Flexibility: The dual data input option (CSV and manual) makes the tool versatile for different use cases.

What tools and technologies were used?

  • Back-End & AI:
    • Language: Python
    • Web Framework: Flask
    • Machine Learning: Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas, NumPy (for data manipulation), Joblib (for saving the model).
  • Front-End:
    • Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
    • CSS Framework: Tailwind CSS
    • JavaScript Libraries: Chart.js (for charts), Swiper.js (for carousels).
  • Data Source:
    • NASA Exoplanet Archive (for model training).
  • AI-Assisted Development:
    • Google's Gemini AI was used as a programming assistant to accelerate front-end component development.
projectDetails.aiReferences: AI-Assisted Development To accelerate the front-end development process and refine the user experience, Google's Gemini AI was utilized as a coding assistant. It played a key role in generating boilerplate HTML structures, creating responsive Tailwind CSS components, and debugging complex JavaScript functions, significantly streamlining the workflow from concept to deployment.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: EarthShield25 â€” Simulated Asteroid Mitigation
projectDetails.summary:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to address the â€œMeteor Madnessâ€ challenge by simulating the potential impacts of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) using real NASA data. The project integrates the NASA NeoWs API to retrieve updated asteroid information and combines it with geospatial layers and scientific models to calculate impact energy, crater size, seismic magnitude, and affected zones such as thermal and pressure radii.

Through an intuitive interface built with Leaflet.js and Chart.js, users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters to visualize the consequences of an impact on specific geographic regions. The tool also introduces educational features, helping the public, students, and decision-makers better understand asteroid threats and mitigation strategies.

By transforming complex astrophysical and geophysical data into accessible visualizations, EarthShield25 highlights the importance of planetary defense while promoting scientific literacy. This project demonstrates how open NASA datasets can empower communities to prepare for future scenarios and foster global collaboration in space science and disaster resilience.
projectDetails.details:
EarthShield25 is an interactive web platform designed to simulate and visualize the potential consequences of asteroid impacts on Earth. Using real data from NASAâ€™s Near-Earth Object Web Service (NeoWs), the tool provides accurate information about asteroid trajectories, sizes, and velocities. Users can select an asteroid or input custom parameters and instantly see the simulated effects on a map, including crater formation, seismic activity, thermal radiation, shockwave radius, and potential tsunami risk.

The primary benefit of EarthShield25 is its ability to make complex scientific models accessible to a wide audience, from researchers and decision-makers to students and the general public. By transforming raw space data into interactive simulations, the project helps raise awareness of planetary defense challenges and supports education in space science and disaster preparedness.

The project was developed using JavaScript, HTML5, CSS3, Leaflet.js, and Netlify for deployment. Data visualization and physics models are integrated into the simulation engine, with a Node.js backend to handle API communication and environment variables securely.

Creativity comes from combining authentic NASA data with an engaging, gamified interface where users can not only explore impact scenarios but also test mitigation strategies (such as asteroid deflection). The project emphasizes accessibility with bilingual support (English and Portuguese) and clear explanations of technical terms to reach both experts and non-experts.

Our team considered usability, scientific reliability, and educational value as the main factors. The result is a platform that bridges the gap between scientific knowledge and public understanding, promoting global awareness and preparedness for asteroid threats.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used AI tools in the following ways for the EarthShield25 project:

  • Images and Icons: The main logo, favicon, and some asteroid/impact icons were generated with the assistance of AI image generation tools (ChatGPT/DALLÂ·E). All AI-generated images include an indication in the README file and project documentation.
  • Code Assistance: AI (ChatGPT) was used to support code refactoring, debugging, and optimization of JavaScript functions for API integration and infinite scrolling. All final implementations were reviewed, tested, and validated by the development team.
  • Documentation: AI was also used to assist in drafting and translating descriptive text, including the English README and submission materials, which were later reviewed and finalized by the team.

AI was applied as a support tool to accelerate development and enhance clarity, while all creative, design, and technical decisions were made by the team.

projectDetails.name: ExoData AI
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, the Exoplanet Detector AI, directly addresses the challenge of manually analyzing vast astronomical data by providing a comprehensive, AI-powered web platform. We developed a high-accuracy (98.46%) XGBoost machine learning model, trained on unified open-source data from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions, to automatically classify exoplanet candidates.

Our solution is not just a model, but an interactive tool where users can upload new data or enter parameters manually for instant classification. Furthermore, it serves as an educational hub with a data analysis dashboard for visualizing the dataset and a detailed reference guide explaining the science behind exoplanets and our AI pipeline.

This is important because it democratizes access to complex astronomical data, saves researchers valuable time by efficiently filtering out false positives, and ultimately accelerates the discovery of new worlds.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, the ExoData AI, is a comprehensive web platform designed to accelerate the discovery of exoplanets. It works in two main parts: The AI Engine (Backend): At its core is a powerful XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) machine learning model, pre-trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. This AI engine follows a rigorous Machine Learning Pipeline: when it receives new data about a potential exoplanet, it automatically handles missing values (imputation), normalizes the data to a consistent scale (scaling), and then feeds it to the trained model to generate a classification ('Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive') with a high degree of accuracy (98.46%).

The benefits and intended impact of our project are multi-faceted:

Acceleration of Scientific Discovery: By automating the classification of exoplanet candidates with high accuracy, our tool drastically reduces the manual labor required by astronomers. This allows them to focus their time and resources on the most promising signals, directly speeding up the process of confirming new worlds.

Increased Efficiency: The AI is highly effective at identifying 'False Positives', preventing valuable telescope time from being wasted on signals caused by instrumental noise or other astrophysical phenomena.

Our project was developed entirely with open-source tools on standard computer hardware.

Programming Language: Python

Web Framework: Streamlit

Pandas, Scikit-learn, Imblearn, XGBoost, Matplotlib, Seaborn

Development Environment: Jupyter Notebook for model training and experimentation; Visual Studio Code for application development.

Version Control & Deployment: Git & GitHub for version control; Streamlit Community Cloud for deployment.

SITE: https://binarybitsai.streamlit.app/

GITHUB: https://github.com/gasbriel07sm/hackathon_exoplanet

PRESENTATION: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1tML0y7xdS7ZsoGhZMpWzUZGGZPHVVHVd/view?usp=sharing
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our project utilizes Artificial Intelligence in two distinct ways:

Data and Training: The model was trained on a unified dataset from NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS missions. We designed and executed a complete machine learning pipeline, including data cleaning, feature engineering, handling class imbalance with SMOTE, and hyperparameter tuning, all documented in our Jupyter Notebook

Function: This is the "brain" of our application. Its function is to analyze astronomical data and classify exoplanet candidates as 'Candidate', 'Confirmed', or 'False Positive' with 98.46% accuracy. This AI is the direct solution to the challenge.

AI as a Development Tool (Assistance): To accelerate development and innovation, we utilized a Large Language Model (LLM) as a programming and writing assistant throughout the project. The LLM's role was to support our team, not to create the core logic or concept. Its specific uses include.

  • Documentation: Helping to generate summaries and detailed descriptions for the project submission forms.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Cosmic Canvas
projectDetails.summary: We developed an AI-powered tool that transforms 608 space biology studies into interactive visual mind maps. Instead of scrolling through search results, researchers ask questions and get visual maps showing how studies connect, key themes, and relevant sourcesâ€”all editable and exportable. This solves the critical problem of information overload: what normally takes hours of manual searching and connecting research now happens in minutes. By making research discovery visual and intuitive, we're accelerating scientific progress, and while focused on space biology now, this approach can scale to any field.
projectDetails.details:
What It Does & How It Works:

Our tool transforms static research databases into interactive knowledge maps. When a researcher asks a question, our AI agent expands the query into relevant keywords and searches through 608 space biology studies stored in a vector database. Instead of returning a simple list, it analyzes the retrieved documents to identify central themes and relationships, then generates an interactive mind map using visual canvas technology. The map shows thematic clusters, individual studies within those themes, and how everything connects to the original questionâ€”complete with citations and links. Researchers can edit the maps directly in the app and export them as images for presentations or papers.

Benefits:

- Dramatically reduces research time from hours to minutes

- Reveals hidden connections between studies that traditional search misses

- Provides visual, spatial understanding rather than linear lists

- Generates proper citations with links automatically

- Allows collaborative editing and sharing through exportable images

- Makes complex research landscapes immediately understandable

Intended Impact:

We aim to accelerate scientific discovery by making research exploration intuitive and visual. Information overload is a critical bottleneck in modern scienceâ€”researchers struggle to find relevant connections across thousands of studies. By visualizing these connections automatically, we help scientists discover insights faster, identify research gaps, and build on existing work more effectively. While starting with space biology, our vision is to scale this to any research database, democratizing access to scientific knowledge across all fields.

Tools & Technologies:

- Frontend/Backend: TanStack Start (React-based framework)

- Vector Database: ChromaDB for semantic search and embeddings

- LLM Infrastructure: OpenRouter with Kimi K2 model

- Embeddings: OpenAI embeddings for document processing

- Visualization: tldraw SDK for interactive canvas

- Framework: LangChain for AI agent orchestration

- Hosting: Railway for deployment

- Architecture: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)

Creative Aspects:

The creativity lies in combining multiple AI capabilities into a novel user experience. Instead of chat interfaces or search results, we chose mind maps because research thinking is inherently spatial and non-linear. We also focused on making the output actionableâ€”maps can be edited and exported, turning AI analysis into shareable artifacts. The query expansion agent ensures users find what they need even with imprecise questions, and the automatic theme identification reveals patterns that wouldn't be obvious from individual studies.

Factors We Considered:

- User experience: Researchers need visual thinking tools, not just text

- Scalability: Built to work with any research database, not just space biology

- Accuracy: Using RAG architecture ensures responses are grounded in actual documents

- Accessibility: Making complex research discoverable for scientists at all levels

- Shareability: Export functionality allows collaboration and presentation

- Prototype nature: Acknowledging this is a proof of concept with room for improvement in speed, accuracy, and visual design

- Real-world workflow: Integration with existing research practices through exportable citations and references
projectDetails.aiReferences: We utilized AI tools throughout the development process. Claude Code (Anthropic's CLI assistant) was used extensively for writing application code, including the TanStack Start frontend/backend implementation, ChromaDB integration, and tldraw canvas generation logic. The core functionality of our project itself relies on AI models: we use OpenAI embeddings to process and embed the 608 space biology studies into vector representations, and the Kimi K2 model (accessed via OpenRouter) powers our LangChain research agent for query expansion, document retrieval, theme identification, and mind map generation.
projectDetails.dataReferences: [Repository with links to access 608 full-text space biology publications.](https://github.com/jgalazka/SB_publications/tree/main)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Interactive Space Atlas
projectDetails.summary:
Space imagery is essential for a better understanding of both cosmic and terrestrial phenomena, as well as for comprehending the elements that make up our Solar System and the Universe. With technological advancements in the capture and processing of images and videos, the need for more efficient tools has emerged.
 Our project, developed using a combination of HTML and JavaScript, presents a web-based application designed to zoom, compare, and characterize NASA satellite images interactively, helping both researchers and enthusiasts identify patterns on Earth and in space. We addressed the challenge with the primary goal of facilitating the exploration of data provided by NASA and making it accessible to the general public and scientific communities, while also encouraging broader interest in our Universe through dynamic exploration.
projectDetails.details:
How does it works?

The Interactive Space Atlas (ISA) allows users to navigate, analyze, and compare celestial bodies using high-resolution visual data generated by NASAâ€™s space and Earth-based missions. In addition to providing detailed visualization, the platform offers tools such as zoom, temporal comparison, and feature identification within the images. Focused on performance, we ensure a smooth browsing experience, allowing users to zoom in and out without compromising speed or image quality.

To begin the analysis, the user selects a Martian day (sun), which serves as a temporal reference for the space landscapes. Then, they choose the camera type and activate "Compare Mode," which switches the interface to "Compare (ON)." Once two images are selected, they are automatically displayed side by side and can be manipulated freely. Another option is to click the "Compare" button directly on the selected images.

Benefits:

ISA's tools help capture small details in the images, enabling careful observation of changes and patterns present across 2D images simultaneously. Additionally, the platform offers open exploration accessible to all audiences, encouraging a broader interest in astronomy.

Intended impact:

- Develop a practical platform for the general public.

- Inspire people around the world to explore and research our Universe, enabling major discoveries in astronomy.

Technologies used:

- Java Script (ES6+): used to make the website dynamic and user-friendly.

- HTML5: responsible for the overall structure of the content and the web page interface.

- CSS3: used to style HTML elements, ensuring a visually friendly and accessible interface.

- JSON: lightweight data format used for exchanging information between NASA APIs and the browser.

Creativity:

- Efficient integration of HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

- Implementation of an interactive model.

Considered factors:

- Accessibility across all devices.

- Simple and intuitive interface.
projectDetails.aiReferences: As beginners, we used ChatGPT-4 and Gemini (2.5 Flash) to assist in the organization, feedback on the coherence of discursive texts, improving the structure of our code, explaining some commands and concepts, accessing other NASA APIs, add the APIs in code quickly, and for translation. The elements that make up the website, the ideas, and the project work were developed by our team.

Your challenge is to create a platform that allows users to zoom in and out on these massive image datasets, label known features, and discover new patterns. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Brazuca - Plantando o Futuro
projectDetails.summary:
Education faces a major challenge: effectively integrating technology to engage students and develop citizens who are aware of the environmental and social impacts of human activities. While public policies and traditional methods are progressing slowly, new generations demand practical, up-to-date experiences connected to the real world.

Our solution addresses this challenge with an educational game that uses real-time NASA data to simulate agricultural scenarios in different regions of Brazil. The player chooses a crop and a state (for example, planting coffee in Rio Grande do Sul) and the system analyzes climate, terrain, and environmental events to demonstrate the viability and impacts of this choice. Wildfires, climate variations, and other real-world phenomena are automatically captured and directly affect crops in the game, connecting students to the living dynamics of the environment.

The result is an innovative tool that combines hands-on learning, gamification, and reliable scientific data to transform environmental education. In this initial phase, we're starting in Brazil, but our vision is global: to bring this interactive experience to schools and players worldwide, fostering collaboration, knowledge exchange, and planetary awareness.
projectDetails.details:
Project links:

  • Repository: https://github.com/3up-Dev/hackathon-nasa-2025
  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech



1. WHAT DOES IT DO OR HOW DOES IT WORK

Plantando Futuro (â€œPlanting the Futureâ€) is an educational simulation game that teaches sustainable agriculture and climate awareness through interactive gameplay.
The application allows users to simulate the entire agricultural production cycle across Brazilâ€™s 27 states using real NASA and INMET climate data.
Players select from 13 crops across 5 agricultural sectors (Agriculture, Livestock, Aquaculture, Forestry, and Horticulture), manage resources, respond to real-time environmental alerts, and earn sustainability-based rewards.

1.1 Core Functionality

  1. User Authentication and Profile Management:
    Secure login via Supabase Auth with persistent user profiles and multiple game slots per account.
  2. Crop and Location Selection:
    Interactive map of Brazil where players choose crops and states.
    Each state uses real geographic coordinates to fetch climate data.
  3. Pre-Planting Viability Analysis:
    The system calculates the compatibility between selected crop and regional conditions using NASA POWER data (temperature, rainfall, humidity, evapotranspiration).
  4. Production Cycle Simulation:
    Players advance through a 120-day virtual growing season, completing management tasks such as irrigation, pest control, and fertilization.
    The system dynamically generates events like droughts, floods, or fires using NASA and INMET data.
  5. Real-Time Climate Alerts:
    Integrations with NASA FIRMS and INMET APIs provide real-time wildfire and meteorological alerts that directly affect gameplay variables such as crop health and sustainability score.
    • Health (40%)
    • Sustainability (30%)
    • Water Efficiency (30%)
      Players earn medals (Gold, Silver, Bronze) and can compare results in a dashboard.
  6. Progressive Web App (PWA):
    Fully installable on mobile and desktop, with offline functionality and caching for low-connectivity environments.

2. WHAT BENEFITS DOES IT HAVE

  1. Educational Value:
    Simplifies complex climate and agricultural concepts through interactive simulation.
    Players learn how environmental decisions influence sustainability and productivity.
  2. Real Data Integration:
    Uses verified NASA and INMET data, ensuring scientific accuracy and trustworthiness.
  3. Engagement through Gamification:
    Combines education with entertainment, enhancing user retention and motivation.
  4. Accessibility and Inclusion:
    PWA support enables access on any device, even in low-bandwidth areas.
    Interface available in Portuguese and English for broader reach.
  5. Environmental Awareness:
    Encourages critical thinking about sustainability and responsible resource management.

3. WHAT IS THE INTENDED IMPACT OF THE PROJECT

  1. Educational Transformation:
    Converts environmental science into an engaging, visual, and practical learning experience.
    Players can understand the link between climate data and agricultural outcomes in real time.
  2. Critical Thinking and Responsibility:
    Demonstrates how local decisions affect global sustainability.
    Encourages reflection on water usage, emissions, and biodiversity.
  3. Regional and Social Inclusion:
    Promotes awareness of Brazilâ€™s diverse climates and ecosystems.
    Provides accessible educational material for schools, NGOs, and rural communities.
  4. Institutional Adoption:
    Designed to serve as an educational resource for schools and environmental programs.
    Can be used in classrooms or workshops to complement sustainability education.
  5. Long-Term Awareness:
    Aims to build lasting environmental responsibility and inspire young generations to consider sustainability in real-world decision-making.

4. WHAT TOOLS, CODING LANGUAGES, HARDWARE, OR SOFTWARE WERE USED

4.1 Frontend Stack

  • React 18.3.1: Component-based UI framework.
  • TypeScript: Static typing and compile-time validation.
  • Vite: High-speed development build tool.
  • Tailwind CSS: Responsive utility-first styling.
  • shadcn/ui: Accessible UI components (based on Radix UI).
  • Zustand 5.0.8: Lightweight global state management.
  • React Router DOM 6.30.1: Protected route management.
  • React Hook Form + Zod: Validation and schema enforcement.
  • Recharts 2.15.4: Data visualization.
  • date-fns 3.6.0: Date and time handling.

4.2 Backend Infrastructure

  • Supabase: Backend-as-a-Service (PostgreSQL, Auth, and Edge Functions).
  • Supabase Auth: Secure authentication with JWT.
  • Row-Level Security: User-level data isolation.
  • Deno Edge Functions: Serverless integrations for NASA and INMET APIs.

4.3 External APIs

  1. NASA POWER API (Climate Data)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-nasa-climate-data/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://power.larc.nasa.gov/api/temporal/daily/point

Location in Code: Key lines 34-196

  1. NASA FIRMS API (Fire Detection)
    Consumption File: supabase/functions/get-brazil-climate-alerts/index.ts
    NASA Endpoint: https://firms.modaps.eosdis.nasa.gov/api/area/csv/{MAP_KEY}/VIIRS_NOAA20_NRT/...

Returned Data:

  • Fire hotspots (latitude, longitude, confidence)
  • Fire risk alerts by state

Location in Code: Key lines 91-159 (fire data fetching)

4.4 Deployment and Hardware

  • Hosting: Lovable Cloud (auto-deploy via Git push).
  • Database: Supabase PostgreSQL.
  • Devices: Any modern web browser (desktop or mobile).
  • Connectivity: Internet for real-time data; offline support via PWA caching.

5. HOW IS THE PROJECT CREATIVE

  1. Real Satellite Data Integration:
    First educational game to combine NASA POWER (climate) and FIRMS (fire) data for interactive sustainability simulation.
  2. Dynamic Environmental Gameplay:
    Real-time data directly influences the playerâ€™s outcomes â€” fires, droughts, and rainfall events generate immediate feedback and learning moments.
  3. Gamified Learning Framework:
    Transforms scientific knowledge into an engaging experience through challenges, scoring systems, and medal rewards.
  4. Cross-Disciplinary Approach:
    Combines data science, game design, and environmental education into a unified, accessible tool.
  5. Visual and UX Creativity:
    Uses pixel-art style and simple interactive dashboards to make complex climate data intuitive for all audiences.

6. WHAT FACTORS DID THE TEAM CONSIDER

  1. Pedagogical Design:
    Educational balance between scientific accuracy and accessible learning for ages 10 and up.
    Concepts simplified without losing data integrity.
  2. Accessibility and Inclusivity:
    Compliance with WCAG accessibility standards and full keyboard navigation.
    Color contrast verified for color blindness.
  3. Localization:
    Native Portuguese interface with English translation.
    Temperature and precipitation units adapted per locale.
  4. Scalability:
    Modular architecture allows adding new crops or data sources easily.
    APIs abstracted via edge functions for rapid expansion.
  5. Resilience and Offline Access:
    Built as a Progressive Web App to support unstable internet connections common in rural areas.
  6. Cultural Context:
    All examples, crops, and terminology based on Brazilian agriculture, ensuring local relevance while maintaining global applicability.

Conclusion

Plantando Futuro is an innovative educational platform that merges space technology, climate data, and game design to raise awareness about sustainable agriculture.
By transforming real NASA and INMET data into interactive learning, it enables players to understand â€” in an intuitive, hands-on way â€” how environmental conditions shape the world we live in.

  • Published Project: https://nasa.3up.tech

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASAâ€™s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. projectDetails.name: Project Candiru Space
projectDetails.summary:
What we developed: A comprehensive AI-powered web application that automatically detects and classifies exoplanets using NASA's Kepler, K2, and TESS mission data. The system employs ensemble machine learning models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM) to analyze transit light curves and classify objects as confirmed exoplanets, planetary candidates, or false positives.
How it addresses the challenge: This solution directly tackles the "Planetary Tourism" challenge by providing an automated, accurate, and accessible tool for exoplanet discovery. It democratizes exoplanet research by making NASA's vast datasets accessible through an intuitive web interface, enabling both researchers and citizen scientists to contribute to exoplanet discovery efforts.
Why it's important: With over 5,000 confirmed exoplanets and thousands more candidates, automated detection systems are crucial for processing the massive amounts of data from current and future space missions. Our system accelerates the discovery process, reduces human bias, and makes exoplanet research more accessible to the global community, ultimately advancing our understanding of planetary systems and the search for habitable worlds.
Key Features: Real-time analysis, multi-language support (PT/EN/ES), interactive visualizations, data upload capabilities, and comprehensive documentation for educationalÂ purposes.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

Our Exoplanet Detection AI System is a comprehensive web application that automatically identifies and classifies exoplanets from NASA's astronomical datasets. The system works through a multi-stage pipeline:

Data Preprocessing: Cleans and normalizes NASA datasets (Kepler KOI, TESS TOI, K2) using statistical methods and SMOTE for class balancing

Transit Analysis: Detects periodic brightness dips in stellar light curves using advanced signal processing

Machine Learning Classification: Employs ensemble models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM) to classify objects into three categories:

Confirmed Exoplanets: Scientifically validated planets

Planetary Candidates: Promising signals awaiting confirmation

False Positives: Stellar phenomena that mimic planetary transits

Benefits and Impact*

Scientific Impact:

Accelerated Discovery: Processes thousands of light curves in minutes vs. months of manual analysis

Reduced Human Bias: Objective classification based on statistical patterns

Democratized Research: Makes NASA's data accessible to citizen scientists worldwide

Educational Value: Interactive visualizations teach astronomy concepts

Societal Benefits:

Public Engagement: Multi-language interface (Portuguese, English, Spanish) reaches global audiences

Research Accessibility: No specialized software or expertise required

Future-Ready: Scalable architecture for upcoming missions (JWST, PLATO, ARIEL)

Technical Implementation*

Technologies Used:

Backend: Python 3.10, Streamlit framework

Machine Learning: Scikit-learn, XGBoost, LightGBM, Imbalanced-learn

Data Processing: Pandas, NumPy, SciPy

Visualization: Plotly, Matplotlib, Seaborn

Deployment: Docker, Buildpacks, VPS hosting

Infrastructure: Git version control, automated CI/CD

Architecture:

Modular Design: Separate modules for ML models, data visualization, and transit analysis

Real-time Processing: Live data updates and interactive dashboards

Responsive UI: Mobile-friendly interface with custom CSS animations

Data Security: Secure file upload and processing capabilities

Creative Elements*

Innovation Factors:

Ensemble Approach: Combines multiple ML algorithms for robust predictions

Interactive Visualizations: 3D hyperparameter landscapes and real-time charts

Multilingual Accessibility: Complete translation system for global reach

Educational Integration: Built-in documentation and tutorial system

Starfield UI: Immersive space-themed interface with CSS animations

Data Reset Functionality: Browser cache clearing for clean data uploads

Team Considerations*

Technical Factors:

Scalability: Designed to handle increasing data volumes from future missions

Accuracy: Balanced precision vs. recall to minimize false discoveries

Performance: Optimized for both speed and computational efficiency

Compatibility: Cross-platform support for various operating systems

Ethical Considerations:

Open Source: All code publicly available for scientific transparency

Data Privacy: No personal data collection or storage

Accessibility: Designed for users with varying technical backgrounds

Educational Focus: Prioritizes learning and scientific literacy

Future Considerations:

Mission Integration: Ready for JWST, PLATO, and ARIEL data

Algorithm Updates: Modular design allows easy model improvements

Community Features: Potential for collaborative research features

Mobile Optimization: Progressive web app capabilities

Intended Impact:

Short-term: Enable immediate analysis of existing NASA datasets by researchers and citizen scientists worldwide.

Long-term: Establish a foundation for automated exoplanet discovery that can scale with future space missions, contributing to humanity's understanding of planetary formation and the search for habitable worlds.

Educational: Inspire the next generation of astronomers and data scientists through accessible, interactive tools that make complex astronomical concepts understandableÂ andÂ engaging.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Our Project

AI Tool Usage Disclosure

Primary AI Assistant: Claude (Anthropic) - Used exclusively for development guidance and technical assistance

How AI Was Utilized:

Code Development Assistance (90% of AI usage):

Library Guidance: AI provided recommendations for Python libraries (Streamlit, Plotly, Scikit-learn, XGBoost, LightGBM)

Syntax Help: Assistance with Python syntax, error debugging, and code optimization

Architecture Planning: Guidance on modular design patterns and best practices

Documentation: Help structuring README files and inline code comments

Technical Problem Solving:

Build Issues: Assistance resolving Buildpacks deployment errors and dependency conflicts

Translation Implementation: Guidance on creating multilingual interfaces

UI/UX Design: Suggestions for user interface improvements and accessibility features

Error Debugging: Help identifying and fixing TypeError, IndentationError, and Streamlit-specific issues

Educational Content:

Scientific Accuracy: Verification of astronomical concepts and NASA data format specifications

Project Documentation: Assistance structuring technical explanations and user guides

What AI Did NOT Do:

No Data Analysis: All machine learning models and data processing logic was developed independently

No Creative Design: All UI elements, visualizations, and user experience decisions were made by the team

No Scientific Research: All astronomical concepts and methodologies were researched independently

No NASA Branding: No AI-generated content used NASA logos, flags, or mission identifiers

Human-Driven Development:

Original Contributions:

Algorithm Selection: Team independently chose ensemble ML approach (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM)

Data Processing Pipeline: Custom implementation of NASA data preprocessing and normalization

Visualization Design: Original interactive charts and real-time dashboards

Multilingual System: Custom translation framework with 3 languages (Portuguese, English, Spanish)

Deployment Strategy: Independent research and implementation of VPS deployment with Buildpacks

AI Role Summary:

AI served purely as a development assistant and learning resource, similar to how developers use Stack Overflow or technical documentation. The AI provided:

Technical guidance and suggestions

Error resolution assistance

Best practice recommendations

Educational explanations

All creative decisions, scientific methodology, code implementation, and project vision originated from the human development team. The AI was a tool to accelerate learning and problem-solving, not a substitute for original thinking or development work.

Development Breakdown:

Human Work: 80% (Original ideas, code, design, scientific methodology)

AI Assistance: 20% (Guidance, suggestions, debugging help)

AI-Generated Content: 0% (No content was directly generated by AI)

This approach exemplifies responsible AI use in scientific development, where AI enhances human capabilities without replacing human creativity, scientific rigor, or originalÂ thought.

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classification Tool
projectDetails.summary:
We developed the Exoplanet Classification Tool, an interactive web application that leverages a machine learning model to classify exoplanet candidates from NASA's Kepler mission data. The primary challenge in the field is efficiently vetting the vast number of potential signals (KOIs) to identify the most promising candidates.

Our tool addresses this by allowing researchers to upload their data and receive an instant classification of each object as 'CONFIRMED' or 'FALSE POSITIVE', based on a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest model. Crucially, the tool goes beyond simple prediction. For each classification, it provides a detailed technical justification using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), showing exactly which astronomical parameters most influenced the decision.

This is important because by providing fast, accurate, and interpretable classifications, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource, helping astronomers prioritize candidates, building trust in the AI's results, and accelerating the pace of exoplanet discovery.
projectDetails.details:
The Exoplanet Classification Tool is a web application designed to automate and accelerate the vetting of potential exoplanets. The workflow is simple and direct:

  1. Data Upload: An astronomer or researcher submits a CSV file containing data for exoplanet candidates (Kepler Objects of Interest - KOIs).
    • Feature Selection: From the raw data, the system selects only the 52 features that proved most predictive in the original data analysis. Columns with a high percentage of missing values, identifiers (kepid), redundant data, and parameters not directly related to the transit's physical properties were systematically removed.
    • Missing Data Handling: If any of the 52 essential features are missing from the user's file (or contain empty cells), the system automatically fills them with pre-calculated average values from the original training dataset, ensuring consistency.
  2. AI Classification: The clean data is then fed into a high-accuracy (99%) Random Forest machine learning model, which classifies each candidate as either "CONFIRMED" or "FALSE POSITIVE".
  3. Visualization and Analysis: The results are presented in an interactive interface featuring a dashboard, tables, and most importantly, an Individual Analysis section. Here, a researcher can select any candidate and view a graph (SHAP Force Plot) and a detailed technical justification that explains exactly which factors led to that specific classification.

The primary benefit of the tool is efficiency and trust. The process of vetting exoplanet candidates is time-consuming and complex. Our tool drastically reduces the time required for an initial screening, allowing researchers to focus on the most promising candidates.

The intended impact is to accelerate the pace of exoplanet discovery. By providing not only a fast and accurate classification but also a transparent explanation of the "why" behind each AI decision, the tool serves as a powerful decision-support resource. It enables astronomers to prioritize targets for follow-up observations with more powerful telescopes, optimizing resources and speeding up the confirmation of new worlds.

The project was developed entirely with open-source software, requiring no specific hardware.

  • Programming Language: Python
  • Backend (Artificial Intelligence): Scikit-learn (for the Random Forest model), Pandas (for data manipulation), and Joblib (for model serialization).
  • Frontend (Web Interface): Streamlit.
  • Data Visualization: Plotly and Matplotlib.
  • AI Explainability: SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a state-of-the-art library for interpreting machine learning model predictions.

The project's creativity lies in the integration of three complex components into a single, simple, and accessible tool. We combined:

  1. A high-performance machine learning model.
  2. An AI explainability framework (SHAP) that "translates" the model's decisions.
  3. An interactive and intuitive user interface.

Instead of being a "black box," the tool makes the AI's decision-making transparent and understandable to domain experts (astrophysicists), who can validate whether the model's reasoning is scientifically sound. This bridge between advanced data science and practical application in astronomical research is the project's main creative distinction.

The key factors considered were:

  • Scientific Rigor: Ensuring the AI model was trained and validated with a robust methodology (cross-validation) to achieve high accuracy and reliability.
  • User Experience (UX): Designing a clean, minimalist, and intuitive interface that would allow a researcher to use the tool without needing expertise in programming or machine learning.
  • Interpretability: The most important factor. From the outset, the project was designed with the idea that the explanation behind a classification was as crucial as the classification itself. We wanted the tool to build trust, not just provide answers.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Audio Generation: The audio narration for the project's presentation video was created with the assistance of the AI voice synthesis tool, Luvvoice.

Code and data: Google Gemini was used as an AI assistant to support the prototyping of the project's web interface. Its role was limited to helping outline the initial Streamlit layout and generate sample CSS elements.
