projectDetails.name: Code and cheese
projectDetails.summary:
Our project addresses NASA's "Will it rain at my parade?" challenge by developing an intelligent system capable of calculating the probability of adverse weather conditions months in advance, using 20 years of historical data from the NASA POWER API.

Unlike traditional weather forecasts, which have a limited range (1â€“2 weeks), our solution is based on long-term observational data, allowing us to identify historical patterns and climate trends for any specific location and date on Earth.

The system applies a multi-criteria statistical methodologyâ€”temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidityâ€”to assess the weather suitability of outdoor events such as weddings, festivals, harvests, or sporting activities. From this analysis, it generates a historical probability (0â€“100%) of event success and suggests more favorable alternative dates within a range of Â±30 days.
projectDetails.details:
This project addresses NASA's "Will it rain on my parade?" challenge by building an application that allows users to make personalized queries to determine the probability of adverse weather conditions for a specific location and time.

The Problem: Planning outdoor events - vacations, hikes, fishing trips, weddings, festivals - without knowing the chances of bad weather conditions ("too hot", "too cold", "too windy", "too wet" or "too uncomfortable").

Our Solution: A system that analyzes 20 years of NASA historical data to calculate accurate weather condition probabilities, allowing users to be better prepared and make informed decisions months in advance.

Important: This is not a weather forecast! These are probabilities based on historical data, not predictive models. This allows planning months in advance, something traditional forecasts (1-2 weeks) cannot offer.


NASA Earth Observation Data

Primary Source: NASA POWER API

We use the NASA POWER API (Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources), which provides global meteorological data on temperature, precipitation, wind, and humidity collected over several decades
The system analyzes 20 years of historical data (2005-2025) for each specific location and date, building a robust statistical compendium that enables pattern identification and reliable probability calculations.

Key Features

  • Location Selection: Interactive map with global coverage and precise coordinates- Personalized Query: Date and time selection with advance planning (months ahead)
  • Event Profiles: Predefined templates (picnic, wedding, sports, festival, photography) or custom criteria via LLM assistant- Probability Analysis: Visual gauge 0-100% based on NASA historical data
  • Alternative Dates: Comparative heatmap (Â±30 days) highlighting the best option
  • Complete Export: CSV/JSON download with metadata and sharing

How We Process the Data

Processing Pipeline

Our system follows a structured workflow to ensure accurate and reliable analyses:


Processing Steps:
  1. User Input: Location (latitude/longitude) + Specific date
  2. NASA POWER API Query: Fetch historical data (2005-2025)
  3. Data Aggregation: Organize by calendar date
  4. Criteria Application: Compare with event criteria (temperature, rain, wind, humidity)
  5. Probability Calculation: Historical analysis + recent trends
  6. Trend Analysis: Identify patterns (positive/negative/stable)
  7. Alternative Generation: Suggest nearby dates (Â±30 days)
  8. Results Formatting: Present probability (0-100%) + classification
  9. User Display: Clear and intuitive interface

Data Analysis in Detail

Temperature Variation Over 20 Years

This visualization shows how temperature varies on the chosen date over the last 20 years. The dashed lines indicate:

  • Green: Ideal minimum temperature for the event
  • Red: Safe maximum temperature

Usefulness: Identifies temperature patterns and extremes, helping assess if the date is consistently suitable.


Precipitation Pattern


Year-by-year analysis of precipitation on the chosen date:

  • Green Bars: Years with acceptable precipitation (â‰¤1mm)
  • Red Bars: Years with excessive rain (>1mm)

Insights: Assesses rain risk and identifies historically problematic years.


Multi-Parameter Dashboard


Comprehensive view of all climate parameters:

  • Temperature: Minimum and maximum range
  • Precipitation: Intensity over the years
  • Wind Speed: Trends and safety limits
  • Relative Humidity: Comfort and atmospheric conditions

Advantage: Enables holistic analysis of all climate factors simultaneously.

Criteria Evaluation

Each year is evaluated based on all defined criteria:

  • Green: Year that met all criteria
  • Red: Year that failed one or more criteria

Calculation: Probability = (Ideal Years / Total Years) Ã— 100%
Application: Provides the historical probability of success for your event.


Alternative Dates Heat Map

Compares the chosen date's probability with nearby dates (Â±15 days):

  • Blue Border: User-selected date
  • Golden Border: Best alternative identified

Benefit: Suggests better dates if the chosen one is not ideal.

Summary Infographic

Complete dashboard with all key metrics:

  • Main Probability: Large, color-coded percentage
  • Average Temperature: Mean of maximum temperatures
  • Rain Distribution: Proportion of dry vs. rainy days
  • Wind Analysis: Safe years vs. strong winds
  • Historical Timeline: Year-by-year visualization (2005-2025)

Usefulness: Complete executive view for quick decision-making.

How It Works in Practice

Scenario: Planning a barbecue in UberlÃ¢ndia on August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM


Select the location on the map

Click on UberlÃ¢ndia or enter coordinates manually!

Choose the event date and time

Set August 15, 2026, at 2:00 PM!

Select the event profile

Choose "Barbecue" or customize weather criteria!

View analysis results

Check the probability and detailed historical data!

Analyze climate trends

Compare data from the last two decades!

Explore alternative dates

In this example, August 15 showed 100% ideal probability. To demonstrate the alternative feature, we also tested October 24, 2025 (35% probability), which shows suggested nearby dates with better conditions.

Export data for analysis

Download results in CSV or JSON

Scientific Methodology

Data Used

Primary Source: [NASA POWER API](https://power.larc.nasa.gov/)

  • System: Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources
  • Analysis Period: 2005-2025 (two decades)
  • Coverage: Global (any point on Earth)
  • Temporal Resolution: Daily or hourly
  • Spatial Resolution: 0.5Â° Ã— 0.5Â° (~55km at equator)

Measured Parameters (Adverse Condition Detection):

  • T2M_MAX / T2M_MIN | T2M - Temperature at 2m (Â°C)
    • Detects: "too hot" or "too cold" conditions
    • Detects: "too wet" conditions (rain)
    • Detects: "too windy" conditions
    • Detects: "too uncomfortable" conditions

Benefits and Impact

For Event Organizers
  • Reduction of cancellations, postponements, and losses
  • Better contingency planning
  • Greater participant satisfaction and safety
For Participants
  • Confidence in event execution
  • Adequate preparation (clothing, equipment)
  • Greater comfort and safety in outdoor activities
For the Community
  • Democratization of access to quality scientific data
  • Evidence-based decisions
  • Awareness of local climate change

Additional Resources

  • NASA POWER API Documentation
  • Source Code on GitHub
  • Application Demo

Conclusion

Answering the Challenge: "Will It Rain on My Parade?"

Yes, now you can know!
This system addresses NASA's challenge by creating an accessible bridge between complex Earth observation scientific data and practical everyday decisions.


Our Contribution:

  • Personalized interface that anyone can use
  • Accurate probabilities** based on NASA historical data (2005-2025)
  • Clear visualizations that make complex data understandable
  • Advance planning that traditional forecasts cannot offer

NASA science serving people. Earth observation data for everyone.

NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025

Challenge: Will it rain on my parade?

Team: Code and Cheese

Technologies Used:

  • Data Source: NASA POWER API
  • Frontend: React, TypeScript, React Router v7
  • Backend: Node.js, Bun
  • Data Analysis: Python, Jupyter Notebook, Machine Learning
  • UI/UX: Tailwind CSS v4, shadcn/ui, Radix UI
  • Maps: Leaflet, React Leaflet
  • Deployment: Vercel, Coolify

AI Tools Used
  • Claude Code: Code generation, debugging, refactoring, and architecture planning for React components, TypeScript definitions, and NASA POWER API integration.

Applications
  • Code Development: Component structure, TypeScript interfaces, data processing logic, and UI implementation

Originality Statement

All AI-generated content was reviewed, tested, and modified by our team. AI tools served as assistive technologies only. Original team contributions include:

  • Data processing methodology and probability algorithms
  • Scientific methodology and analytical frameworks
  • Integration architecture

No AI-generated images, videos, or audio were used. All visualizations were created using legitimate data visualization libraries processing real NASA POWER API data (2005-2025).

projectDetails.name: Project CODENAUTAS
projectDetails.summary:
Climetry is an intelligent climate monitoring and forecasting application built with Flutter that integrates NASA-powered data from the Meteomatics API and AI insights from OpenAI (GPT-4o-mini). Designed for event planning and climate analysis, it delivers real-time weather data, forecasts up to 180 days, and personalized recommendations based on location and event type.

The project addresses the challenge of transforming complex meteorological data into accessible, actionable insights for people and organizations. Climetry continuously monitors key variables such as temperature, precipitation, wind, UV, and humidity, sending automatic alerts when significant changes occur and generating AI-based explanations of potential impacts. It also compares current data with 10-year historical averages, allowing users to evaluate long-term climate patterns and risks.

This solution is important because it helps users make data-driven, sustainable decisions in the face of increasingly unpredictable weather conditions. By combining NASAâ€™s scientific accuracy, AI interpretation, and human-centered design, Climetry empowers communities to better prepare, adapt, and thrive in a changing climate.
projectDetails.details:
ClimetryÂ is an intelligent climate monitoring and forecasting platform that transforms scientific weather data into actionable insights. It collectsÂ real-time meteorological informationÂ from theÂ Meteomatics API (powered by NASA datasets)Â and processes it withÂ AI models from OpenAI (GPT-4o-mini)Â to generate personalized recommendations and climate impact analyses.

The app providesÂ forecasts up to 180 days, tracksÂ temperature, precipitation, UV, wind, and humidity, and issuesÂ automatic alertsÂ when significant weather changes occur. Users receiveÂ AI-generated insightsÂ andÂ morning notificationsÂ before events, helping them plan with confidence.

The main benefits includeÂ accurate predictions,Â personalized weather intelligence, andÂ collaborative event managementÂ throughÂ Firebase synchronization. The intended impact is to help communities and organizations makeÂ data-driven, sustainable decisions, reducing risks associated with extreme weather events.

Technologies used:Â Flutter,Â Dart,Â Firebase,Â OpenAI API,Â Meteomatics API, andÂ Google Maps SDK. These tools ensure aÂ cross-platform, scalable, and responsive application.

Climetry is creative because it combinesÂ scientific precisionÂ withÂ AI-driven storytelling, turning complex data into simple guidance.

The team prioritizedÂ usability, reliability, and accessibility, focusing on how technology canÂ empower people to understand and adapt to climate change.

projectDetails.name: Project Cosbit
projectDetails.summary:
http://72.60.148.155:8617/: Here is the software URL, it is running locally and even though it doesn't have https, don't worry, it is safe. Sorry about that.

What I developed was software that uses a Space Biological Agent and a Data Analyst Agent to analyze and understand documents from space biology experiments and provide practical and objective insights and valuable information from the documents, thus transforming raw data into intelligent data ready for human decision-making and interpretation.This way, the productivity and gains in the work of researchers, scientists, enthusiasts, etc., increase by trying to assimilate and understand what the data is saying.
projectDetails.details:
What benefits does BioExpace offer?

It can extract any data structure you want from the document and provide you with intelligent information based on the context given to it.

This summarizes a lot of manual work and saves human time and energy from reading and understanding numerous documents.

This way, you can get straight to the point. The data is about Space Biology,

which is essential for understanding how life transforms and adapts in space.

BioExpace offers a bridge between knowledge and data generated by NASA professionals

and modern intelligence capable of transforming how you perceive data.

What is the intended impact of the project?

To gather raw data and be able to display valuable information to the end human user, it takes

all the sections (for example, Introduction, Results, Conclusion) of all documents,

analyzes everything, and generates in a practical and useful way information that may be valuable to you,

information that you might spend hours analyzing to find what you're looking for.

Which tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Languages: Python, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
  • Frameworks:
  • Flask (good for microservices),
  • Ollama (for integrating LLMs on my local machine),
  • TikToken (for token control by chunk)
  • Database: PostgreSQL (used to store data collection, agent pipelines, and the structure of the final result)
  • Final Data Format: JSON (JSONB in PostgreSQL)
  • Hardware: Local server with only CPU, 16GB of RAM, Ubuntu operating system, no cloud dependency.

How is your project creative?

It uses text comprehension models (NLP) to analyze thousands of tokens in documents, assimilate everything, organize everything

and generate valuable information. It allows quick access to information and the possible generation

of new biological hypotheses thanks to what the Agents provide to us humans.

Furthermore, the idea of collaborative cognitive agents (one reads, another interprets) and the fusion of spatial

biology and intelligent data (thanks to AI), the notion of augmented science, and the way

data is transformed into intelligent information for this branch of science.

There are two agents working on multiple scientific documents, reviewing and generating information

What factors did your team consider?

The fact is that today, we humans are always needing more convenience, more objectivity, more speed.

Tools like this, which save 85% of your work time, make you more productive, not to mention that, of course,

the better the LLM model used, the smarter and better your final result will be. We solved that problem of scattered and possibly meaningless data,

bringing relevance in a simple and objective way, whatever your purpose may be. We solve and facilitate your exploration of the data
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In addition to using Qween and LLama for data analysis, I used ChatGPT during development for the frontend; it helped me with corrections in JavaScript, some HTML definitions, and quick styling.

I defined how I wanted the design to look, and he styled it in CSS. I started developing some frontend-backend integrations and requested corrections in the JavaScript in cases of errors.

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Comet impact simulator
projectDetails.summary: Our team developed an interactive globe where the user can simulate the impact of various asteroids on different earth locations. The user can utilize known asteroids or create their own with custom properties (velocity, angle, density and diameter). We use the SBDB API as a search tool and the NeoWs API to fetch information about a specific asteroid. By visualizing impact effects our tool can be used to bring awareness about asteroid collisions and their danger.
projectDetails.details:
This project aims to be an interactive tool where the user can simulate the impact of asteroid on planet earth to better understand their risks and clear common misconceptions.

1 - Impact simulator:

A detailed 3d globe of earth that can be spun around and zoomed in and out, the project offers various customization options and shows an estimated impact crater, expected seismic activity, shockwave radius and thermal radiation. The user can select any known asteroid by their name, and their information will be fetched and filled appropriately, after inputting asteroid density (to simulate mass) and entry degree you can choose any location on earth and verify what would happen if an asteroid fell there.

projectDetails.name: Project Cosmos Angle
projectDetails.summary: Summary: We have developed an educational website aimed at children, explaining complex situations about space weather in a relaxed, story-based format. The content is presented in a fun and engaging way for children, using kid-friendly images and explanatory texts. This is important so that children can gain a basic understanding of the space they live in and phenomena that might otherwise seem strange
projectDetails.details:
Project Details:

"Faiska's Journey" is an interactive and illustrated digital story designed to explain the complex phenomenon of space weather to children and the general public. The project functions as a web application that chronicles the journey of "Faiska," an energy spark born on the Sun, who travels to Earth during a Coronal Mass Ejection.

The user can navigate through 10 chapters using next/previous buttons, keyboard arrows, or swipe gestures on touch devices.

  • Visual Feedback: A progress bar at the top of the page indicates the reader's progress through the narrative.
  • Web Technology: The application is built with HTML for structure, CSS for visual styling and animations, and JavaScript to control all interactivity and navigation logic between chapters.
  • Animated Illustrations: Each chapter features animated SVG illustrations that visually represent scientific concepts, such as the "solar sneeze" and Earth's magnetosphere.

Key Features:

  • Educational: It makes a complex scientific topic, like heliophysics and space weather, accessible and understandable to a non-technical audience, including children.
  • Engaging: It uses the power of storytelling and interactivity to create a fun and memorable learning experience, rather than a purely technical explanation.
  • Awareness: It demonstrates the real-world impacts of space weather on our essential daily technologies, such as GPS satellites, power grids, aviation communications, and the safety of astronauts. The educational content details the concepts of Coronal Mass Ejection, Solar Wind, and the Magnetosphere.

Intended Impact:

The intended impact is to demystify space weather and increase public awareness of its importance. By showing how solar eruptions affect ordinary peopleâ€”such as farmers, pilots, and power grid operatorsâ€”the project aims to connect space science with people's daily lives. We hope to inspire curiosity about science and highlight the importance of solar monitoring carried out by agencies like NASA to protect our global technological infrastructure.

Technical Specifications:

  • Programming Languages: HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript for the frontend.
  • Technologies and Tools:
    • SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics): Used for all illustrations, allowing for high-quality visuals and animations.
    • Google Fonts: The "Poppins" and "Roboto" fonts were used for the project's typography.

Design & Strategy:

  • Visual Metaphors: We simplified complex concepts through creative metaphors, such as the Coronal Mass Ejection being a "Great Solar SNEEZE!" and the magnetosphere being a "Magic Shield."
  • Humanized Impact: The project shows the effects of space weather through the stories of different professionals (an astronaut, a pilot, a farmer), making the consequences more concrete and relatable.
  • Immersive Aesthetics: The visual design, with its space theme, stylized illustrations, and smooth animations, creates an immersive experience that invites the user to explore the story.
  • Target Audience: The entire project, from the simple language to the interactivity, was designed to be accessible and interesting for children and the lay public.
  • User Experience (UX): We implemented multiple navigation methods (buttons, keyboard, swipe) to ensure the project is easy to use on both desktops and mobile devices.
  • Scientific Accuracy: Although the story is fictional, it is grounded in real scientific phenomena, ensuring that the educational content is accurate and relevant.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
AI Tools Used:

ChatGPT, Gemini, ClaudeIA

1. Content Generation and Story Scripting:

  • Brainstorming and Structure: We used AI to generate initial ideas for the "Faiska" character's narrative and to structure her journey into 10 chapters.
  • Simplifying Scientific Concepts: AI was a key tool in helping us translate complex scientific concepts from heliophysics (like Coronal Mass Ejection and the magnetosphere) into simple, playful, and accessible language for a young audience, such as the "SOLAR-SNEEZE" metaphor.
  • Text Drafting: We generated initial drafts of the descriptive texts for each chapter. All AI-generated content was subsequently reviewed, edited, and refined by our team to ensure the story's cohesion, tone, and accuracy.

2. Code and Logic Development:

  • Code Assistance (JavaScript/CSS/HTML): We utilized tools like Gemini to speed up development. AI helped us generate the basic structure of JavaScript functions, such as the logic for chapter navigation and updating the progress bar.
  • Debugging: AI was used to identify and suggest fixes for errors in the code, optimizing our development time.

Conclusion: Throughout all stages, AI was treated as a collaborator and an accelerator. The originality, final intent, content curation, and project execution were directed and carried out by our team to ensure a cohesive and creative result that met the challenge's objectives.

challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. â€œSpace weatherâ€â€”the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earthâ€”can impact technologies in space and on Earth. node.title: Cosmos Explorers
node.excerpt: Exploring the cosmos with knowledge, insight and the will to win

projectDetails.name: CosmoEX: Simplifying access to space research with AI
projectDetails.summary: We are the team CosmoEX: Explorers of the Cosmos, and our mission is to democratize access to scientific knowledge, making NASAâ€™s discoveries accessible to everyone. To conclude, we developed a conversational platform with artificial intelligence that answers natural-language questions based on official NASA articles, data, and publications. CosmoEX works like an assistant like ChatGPT but focused exclusively on scientific and space content. Thus, when a user types questions such as â€œWhat has NASA discovered about bone loss in low-gravity environments?â€, they receive contextualized answers grounded in verified sources, plus the source URL of the file, title, authors, and the file identifier (when available) used in the answerâ€”bringing science closer to everyday life.
projectDetails.details:
In a world driven by information, scientific knowledge is one of the most powerful tools for humanityâ€™s advancement. However, access to that knowledge is still unequal. Every day, students, independent researchers, and small-scale scientists face major barriers when trying to find and understand relevant scientific articles processes that is time-consuming, technical, and often discouraging.

In this context, CosmoEX was created with the purpose of democratizing access to research, transforming the pursuit of knowledge into a simple, intuitive, and accessible experience.

Repository Acess - GitHub

The problem

Although scientific research is essential, it is still perceived as inaccessible to most people. In this scenario, university students and small researchers often spend hoursâ€”or even daysâ€”filtering through hundreds of articles in search of the few that truly contribute to their hypotheses.

Moreover, this difficulty in finding relevant materials is not just a technical challenge, it is also an emotional and social obstacle, since many end up giving up on their projects out of frustration or lack of resources. Consequently, the result is a significant loss of intellectual potential and innovation, especially in developing countries where access to quality scientific information remains limited.

The gap

Despite the vast availability of open data and scientific articles, the bridge between information and the people who seek it is still fragile due to current research platforms, which frequently become complex and unintuitive. In other words, there is a chasm between curiosity and knowledgeâ€”and this is precisely the gap that CosmoEX aims to bridge.

Our solution

CosmoEX is a conversational artificial intelligence designed to simplify and accelerate access to scientific research by using data and articles provided by NASA, assembling a RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) setup to constrain the model to answer only based on the provided documents. Through a chat-like interface, the user can ask questions in natural language, for example:

â€œWhat has NASA discovered about bone loss in low-gravity environments?â€

The AI processes the question via a vector to search for similar information in its vector database and responds in a contextualized and reliable manner, along with a link to the full article when available. With CosmoEX, students and researchers can converse directly with knowledge, saving time and opening new doors for discoveries.

How it works

First, when the user accesses the web platform, they encounter a chat interface where they can ask questions about NASA articles previously made available for the challenge. When the user types and sends a question, the platform performs a similarity search between the question and the documents in the platformâ€™s repository.



If it finds an answer in parts of the documents, it will respond with that answer, showing its confidence level and two charts: one showing how many parts of each document were retrieved as similar, and another showing the frequency of relevant repeated terms (excluding conjunctions). If it does not find a document that answers the question, it will reply that it does not have sufficient data to answer. In this way, the search optimizes time spent researching articles and helps democratize access to information with the aim of being less burdensome.


Implementation details

DATA PIPELINES

First, a data pipeline was used with several steps to extract all the initial scientific articlesâ€”the 608â€”and later part of the complementary articles, totaling more than 1,500 files that went through the pipeline. Its steps are:

  • Sources: Collection of articles in multiple formatsâ€”CSV, PDF, and various NASA datasets (with a focus on biology, human research physics)â€”using Python scripts with libraries such as Beautiful Soup and Selenium; converting everything to a standard JSON format organized into fields (title, authors, content, etc.), and filtering the acquired data.
  • Transformations: Python preprocessing scripts convert the data to lemmatized JSON using the NLTK library, organized into two fieldsâ€”content and metadataâ€”in addition to standard data refinement.
  • Embeddings: Creation of semantic vectors with LangChain after splitting into 1,536-token chunks with an overlap of 384, and OpenAIâ€™s text-embedding-3-small model, stored in the Qdrant Vector Database for similarity queries based on content while taking metadata into account.

BACKEND

  • Framework: FastAPI

Python was used with the FastAPI framework to create REST endpoints, ensuring high performance and connection with the virtual interface, using a connection with QRant to search by similarity with a confidence score and using the LangChain and OpenAI librariesâ€”using the same model (text-embedding-3-small) to embed the questionâ€”and, for the Q&A response flow, gpt-5-nano. It builds the LangChain Q&A pipeline with the retriever using the QRant documents and answers based on the returned chunks and indicates when it cannot answer due to a lack of documents. This provides a robust response flow that also generates two charts with data from the chunks and metadata.

FRONTEND

  • Stack: Application developed with Node.js + React + Vite + TailwindCSS, offering a responsive and modern interface.
    • Search for articles based on metadata or semantic similarity.
    • Dynamic dashboards with interactive visualizations generated for each question, using the chunks employed in the answer and their metadata.
    • Direct integration with the backend to display results in real time.

INFRASTRUCTURE

  • Containerization: Use of Docker and Docker Compose to orchestrate Backend, Frontend, and the QRant Vector Database services.
  • Dependencies: All libraries and versions controlled in requirements.txt (Python) and package.json (Node.js).
  • Scalability: Modular architecture allows future expansion to new data sources and integrations.

Impact

CosmoEX has the potential to revolutionize access to scientific research by drastically reducing the time spent searching for relevant information. In this context, it democratizes knowledge, enabling students, enthusiasts, and independent scientists to explore NASA data in a simple way, eliminating technical and linguistic barriers.

With this tool, more people will be able to participate actively in building scientific knowledge, stimulating critical thinking, innovation, and interest in science. In the long term, this means a more informed, collaborative society prepared to tackle global challengesâ€”exactly as NASA has always inspired.

Conclusion

In conclusion, CosmoEX represents the meeting point of technology, curiosity, and purpose. More than a platform, it is a movement in favor of democratizing science, because by transforming complex data into accessible knowledge, our project seeks to inspire new generations of explorers, not only of space, but of understanding itself.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Open IA model (gpt-5-nano)AI and Text-Embedding-3-Small have been used in various purposes, for Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) in the Q&A flow, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), and, with Gemini 2.5 Pro and Â Student Licensed GitHub Copilot , troubleshooting, topic research, writing improvement, code generation and refinement.

challengeDetails.title: NASA Farm Navigators: Using NASA Data Exploration in Agriculture
challengeDetails.excerpt: The agriculture community faces the challenge of integrating technology and data to enhance sustainable farming practices. Simulating key farming activities like fertilizing, irrigating, and livestock management using real-world NASA satellite imagery and climate data can enable better understanding of the impacts of these variables on crop production. Your challenge is to create an engaging educational game that effectively utilizes NASAâ€™s open data sets to simulate farming scenarios and enables players to learn how this data can inform innovative, sustainable, agricultural methods. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Cronistas Estelares
projectDetails.details:
Our project is an educational website created to present the topic of space weather in an interactive, accessible, and engaging way. It brings together scientific information about what space weather is, how it affects people and technology on Earth, and how NASA studies these phenomena.

The website also features a digital story about a young girl who, in a dream, learns about solar storms and space weather with the help of a friendly robot. Through this narrative, we aim to spark curiosity and interest in science and astronomy â€” especially among children, but also among people of all ages.

In addition, we developed an educational quiz game that allows users to test what they have learned in a fun and interactive way. Although the project does not include audio or video, its visual design and storytelling were carefully planned to ensure an immersive and educational experience.

The main goals of the project are to raise awareness about space weather, encourage scientific education, and share NASAâ€™s knowledge in a simple, creative, and accessible way.

To develop the project, we used Google Docs for writing and organization, Canva for visual design, and Base44 as the development platform. The images and visual elements were created with the help of artificial intelligence tools such as ChatGPT and Perplexity, along with contributions from digital illustrators who enhanced the artistic material.

The creativity of the project lies in combining storytelling, science, and interactivity within a digital educational environment, transforming complex heliophysics and space weather concepts into something understandable, inspiring, and captivating for young learners.

Our team carefully considered the target audience and their needs, researching ways to present NASAâ€™s missions and studies in a simplified, engaging, and meaningful format â€” helping inspire a new generation of curious minds about the universe.

challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: DataLab Exoplanet Hunters: AI in the Search for Distant Worlds
projectDetails.summary:
As part of the NASA Global Challenge A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI, the DataLab team developed an artificial intelligence-based solution to accelerate the identification of potential exoplanets within large volumes of astrophysical data. We used the LightGBM model, an advanced decision tree-based machine learning technique known for its speed and high performance in classification tasks.

Our system was trained to analyze light curves â€” records that show variations in the brightness of stars over time â€” and detect subtle patterns that may indicate the transit of planets in front of those stars. To achieve this, we applied feature engineering techniques, noise reduction in the data, cross-validation, and hyperparameter optimization, building a robust, efficient, and reproducible pipeline.

This approach not only enables the automation and scaling of exoplanet candidate screening, but also frees up astronomers' time for deeper investigation. The project highlights the potential of artificial intelligence as a powerful ally in space exploration and in advancing human knowledge about worlds beyond our solar system.
projectDetails.details:
About the DataLab Exoplanet Hunters Project

DataLab Exoplanet Hunters is an interactive platform designed to assist researchers and professionals in detecting and analyzing exoplanets using real astrophysical data from missions such as NASAâ€™s K2 mission. Through an intuitive interface, users can upload their own datasets, which then undergo an automated preprocessing phase. During this step, the platform identifies and classifies variables, whether categorical or numerical. Next, AI-powered predictive models with predefined hyperparameters analyze the data to identify potential exoplanet candidates.

The project aims to simplify the application of data science and artificial intelligence in astrophysics, offering a fast, accurate, and accessible solution for exoplanet detection.

Benefits of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters

Detecting exoplanets requires careful analysis of complex astrophysical data, a process that can be time-consuming and prone to human error. DataLab Exoplanet Hunters helps overcome these challenges by automating critical analysis steps, reducing processing time, and increasing accuracy in identifying candidates. Additionally, the platform provides clear visual outputs to assist with interpretation. This enables researchers to focus more on scientific validation and less on repetitive data tasks, streamlining the path to new discoveries.

Expected Impact of the Project

The main goal of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters is to save researchers time and effort by automating manual calculations and data preparation, thus increasing productivity and allowing scientists to dedicate more attention to activities requiring deeper analysis and interpretation. Moreover, the platform has educational potential, serving as a tool to engage students and early-career scientists with real space mission data and advanced AI techniques.

Technologies and Tools Used

The project was developed using Python, with development environments such as Visual Studio Code and Google Colab. Libraries like Pandas, NumPy, Scikit-learn, and Matplotlib were employed for data manipulation and analysis. AI assistance was provided by tools such as Gemini, ChatGPT, Perplexity, and GitHub Copilot. Cloud-based resources were used for model testing and experimentation, ensuring flexibility and scalability.

Creative Aspects of the Project

The innovation of DataLab Exoplanet Hunters lies in its ability to bridge astrophysics and artificial intelligence in a practical and accessible way. The platform allows users to perform predictive analysis with just a few clicks, regardless of their machine learning expertise. This breaks down technical barriers and encourages broader participation in space science. Furthermore, the project supports open science by making advanced tools available to a wider community of learners and researchers.

Factors Considered by the Team

Throughout development, the team prioritized usability by ensuring a simple and intuitive interface. They also focused on technical simplicity to make the platform accessible to non-experts, speed to handle large datasets efficiently, scalability to support real mission-scale data, and reliability to deliver consistent and replicable results using robust AI models.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We used artificial intelligence tools, specifically Gemini 2.5 Pro and ChatGPT 5, to support our project in the following ways:

Analysis and Interpretation of Results: AI was used to assist in analyzing the data collected and interpreting the results, helping us draw conclusions more effectively.

Translation Support: AI tools were used to help translate and refine the language used in the project documentation and presentations, ensuring clarity and accuracy across languages.

No code or datasets were directly generated by AI. All code was written and validated by the team.

(Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Earth Trailblazers
node.excerpt: A couple vibing with coding, design, and data analysis, on a mission to explore and innovate by transforming complex data into impactful solutions :)

projectDetails.name: METEORIS by Earth Trailblazers
projectDetails.summary:
We, the Earth Trailblazers team, developed METEORIS, an innovative web application designed to be a true lifesaver for tourists planning trips anywhere in Brazil. Through an intuitive and interactive interface, users can search for a destination city or select it directly on an interactive map. By specifying the month and year of their planned trip, they receive detailed climate predictions, including average minimum and maximum temperatures, rainfall in millimeters, and the probability of rain.

Beyond forecasts, METEORIS displays insightful historical weather graphs generated from NASA Earth observation data spanning 2007â€“2025, enhancing the modelâ€™s reliability. The app also provides personalized travel tips based on predicted conditions, helping users plan better experiences.

This solution addresses NASAâ€™s challenge â€œWill it rain on my parade?â€ by going beyond short-term forecasts â€” offering long-term, data-driven planning for travelers, months or even years in advance. METEORIS stands out for its relevance: while many apps predict short-term weather, few empower users to anticipate future climate tendencies and avoid unpleasant surprises during their dream trips.
projectDetails.details:
Overview
METEORIS is an AI-powered web application that predicts future climate conditions for any location in Brazil, based on the month and year selected by the user. The system provides mean temperature and precipitation, interactive climate plots, and travel recommendations tailored to the expected weather. It helps tourists plan their trips in advance, while also offering a data-driven dashboard for climate analysis enthusiasts.

To make the experience seamless, METEORIS integrates the Google Maps API, which enables users to search for or select cities directly on an interactive map. The APIâ€™s Autocomplete feature was essential to ensure accurate city identification, while its Geocoding service converts the city name into precise latitude and longitude coordinates â€” the input format required by our prediction model. This integration made it possible for the frontend, backend, and AI model to communicate efficiently, ensuring that forecasts and plots correspond exactly to the userâ€™s chosen location.

Dataset
The dataset was built from NASA Earth observation data provided by the Global Earth Science Data and Information Service (GES DISC). Data were collected from three sources:

  • M2TMNXSLV (surface and atmospheric variables),
  • M2TMNXRAD (radiation data), and
  • M2TMNXFLX (precipitation and flux data).

We used the EarthAccess API to authenticate and download data between 2007 and 2025, filtered specifically for Brazilâ€™s geographic boundaries (latitude âˆ’33Â° to 5Â°, longitude âˆ’74Â° to âˆ’35Â°).
The dataset includes the following variables:

  • T2M â€“ Air temperature 2 meters above the surface
  • QV2M â€“ Specific humidity
  • PS â€“ Surface pressure
  • SWGDN â€“ Solar radiation at ground level
  • PRECTOT â€“ Total surface precipitation

All data were consolidated into monthly averages and stored in Parquet and CSV formats for high performance and compatibility.

Machine Learning Model
We trained a LightGBM MultiOutputRegressor using Python, Pandas, NumPy, and Scikit-learn to predict temperature and precipitation simultaneously for any given latitude, longitude, month, and year combination in Brazil. This approach was chosen for its high efficiency and robustness when dealing with large, multi-variable datasets.

Data Preparation and Feature Engineering
Before training, the dataset underwent several preprocessing steps to ensure data quality and model readiness:

  • Cleaning: Removed unnecessary or redundant columns (e.g., day, hour, week_day) to reduce noise.
  • Unit Conversion: Transformed temperature values from Kelvin to Celsius and humidity values from fraction to percentage, improving interpretability.
  • Geospatial Filtering: Retained only data points within Brazilâ€™s official geographic boundaries.
  • Feature Creation: Extracted month and year from the time column and generated new columns for minimum and maximum temperature, applying a tolerance of Â±3â€“4Â°C to capture variability.
  • Normalization: Scaled all features using StandardScaler to ensure uniform input distribution across the model.

Model Training and Evaluation
The final dataset contained over 1 million samples covering the period from 2007 to 2025. It was split into 80% for training and 20% for testing, maintaining consistent random states for reproducibility.
We used Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) due to its strong performance in handling non-linear relationships, missing values, and high-dimensional data.

During training, the model optimized the L2 loss function, using 500 boosting iterations with early stopping criteria to prevent overfitting. Cross-validation was applied to tune hyperparameters such as:

  • learning_rate = 0.05
  • num_leaves = 31
  • max_depth = -1 (unrestricted)
  • n_estimators = 500

The model achieved the following performance metrics on the test dataset:

  • RÂ² (Coefficient of Determination): 0.92
  • MAE (Mean Absolute Error): 0.17
  • MSE (Mean Squared Error): 0.10

These results indicate excellent predictive accuracy and low variance between the training and validation sets. The trained model and its corresponding scaler were exported using Joblib, enabling seamless loading through the FastAPI backend for real-time inference.

Comparing with the Meteomatics Forecast
To validate the reliability of our model, we compared its predictions against Meteomatics, a recognized global weather forecasting platform. Using Ubatuba (Brazil) as the reference city, the Meteomatics forecast reported an average temperature of 24.85Â°C, while our model predicted 24.92Â°C â€” a negligible difference of 0.07Â°C.
This near-perfect alignment demonstrates the robustness and precision of the LightGBM model, confirming that it accurately captures Brazilâ€™s climatic patterns. A Meteomatics chart was also analyzed to visually verify the matching behavior between both datasets.

Visualization and Recommendations
All data visualizations in METEORIS were developed internally using Matplotlib and Seaborn, ensuring full control and transparency over the analysis process. These plots illustrate 18 years of historical climate trends for temperature, precipitation, humidity, and solar radiation across Brazil, helping users visualize seasonal variations and long-term patterns.

The system generates interactive time-series charts that allow users to identify ideal travel months and regions with favorable weather conditions. These insights not only support travelers but also serve as valuable references for researchers and data analysts interested in climate evolution.

While Meteomatics was referenced only for validation purposes, its data was never used within the model or visualizations. It served solely as an external benchmark to confirm the accuracy of METEORIS predictions, ensuring the credibility of the results derived from NASAâ€™s Earth observation data.

In addition, METEORIS provides automatic travel recommendations based on the predicted climate for each city, guiding users to explore destinations that align with their preferred weather conditions.

Technology Stack

  • Python (Data processing, ML, and API with FastAPI)
  • LightGBM, Scikit-learn, Pandas, NumPy
  • Matplotlib, Seaborn for visualization
  • React (frontend)
  • C# (backend)

Impact and Creativity

METEORIS transforms NASAâ€™s open climate data into actionable intelligence, bridging the gap between environmental science, technology, and tourism. By merging predictive analytics with intuitive visualization, the project enables people to understand and plan around climate conditions in a way that was previously accessible only to scientists and researchers.

Its impact extends beyond tourism: METEORIS serves as a powerful educational and analytical tool that democratizes access to decades of NASA Earth observation data. It allows users â€” from travelers to data scientists â€” to explore how temperature, precipitation, and humidity patterns evolve over time, fostering climate awareness and data literacy in a practical, engaging format.

The projectâ€™s creative strength lies in its fusion of artificial intelligence, data science, and geospatial intelligence within a single, lightweight platform. While traditional weather apps focus on short-term forecasts, METEORIS innovates by projecting long-term climate tendencies months or even years in advance, offering valuable insights for sustainability, travel planning, and environmental research.

In essence, METEORIS embodies the spirit of the NASA Space Apps Challenge: it takes complex Earth data and transforms it into something human, useful, and inspiring, empowering individuals to make informed decisions while connecting with the planet in a smarter and more meaningful way.

projectDetails.name: Project EcoLife
projectDetails.summary: Our project proposes improvements for cities to become sustainable. Based on data from the city of UberlÃ¢ndia, we devised solutions to these problems that can also be used in other cities around the world. After discussions, we determined that the starting point for making cities sustainable required: population waste management, sustainable energy efficiency, ecological parks and green areas within the city, efficient transportation, and better nutrition/food access. By identifying these urban problems, it is possible to solve them through planning to bring benefits to the population of our city, and beyond UberlÃ¢ndia, many other cities facing similar issues can apply these solutions. Large cities tend to be less sustainable. Sustainability, anchored by the environmental, social, and economic spheres, is, however, growing in importance. UberlÃ¢ndia is the city with the highest growth in industrial GDP. Our project aims to create improvements for urban centers by implementing various measures to make cities sustainable. Following discussions, we decided that the focus for this is Environmental Education, which will guarantee educated and aware citizens, followed by actions for: better management of waste produced by the population, better energy efficiency through sustainable means, more ecological parks and green areas throughout the city, efficient transportation, and better nutrition/food access.
projectDetails.details:
Introduction

The NASA Space Apps Challenge hackathon, organized by NASA - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is an event that brings together people from all over the world. Its objective is to present problems to participants so they can submit plausible solutions for them.

We are residents of UberlÃ¢ndia, a city located in Minas Gerais, Brazil. Five of us are 2nd-year high school students integrated into the Systems Development course, while our last member is a 9th-grade student at the ESEBA-UFU middle school.

To participate in the Hackathon, we chose the theme "Data Pathways to Healthy Cities and Human Settlements" because UberlÃ¢ndia fits the pattern of rapidly growing cities, and we thought we could develop strategies to make our city more sustainable.

We know that the world, even with research alerting us about the state of our planet, continues to maintain unsustainable habits. Large cities are often using the word "sustainability" as a form of propaganda and ignoring its true values.

The city of UberlÃ¢ndia seems to tend towards being sustainable, but even so, we can see situations where "sustainability" is used incorrectly. Thus, considering what was highlighted in the information about the theme we chose, we thought of four topics that, for us, stood out, both as areas of our interest and as obstacles that are prominent in the daily lives of us, residents of UberlÃ¢ndia.

During the meetings, we realized that every time we arrived at a solution, we faced the problem of the lack of environmental education, therefore, discussing it becomes extremely important.

Environmental education is an educational practice that involves the study and learning between members of a society, applying their skills in complex and multi-tasks, and the environment. In this way, the educated individual transforms into an active and transforming agent in reactions concerning environmental conservation.

It's always interesting to emphasize during environmental education lessons that the "environment" isn't just forests and conservation areas: the environment is, especially, the places we are inserted in, whether it's our neighborhood, school, home, or city. Therefore, this education reinforces that the responsibility for conservation is also local and manifests in every action within the community.

Thus, we emphasize that for all proposed actions, the implementation of environmental education will be necessary. It is the fundamental tool that enables the individual to understand their role in the collective. It is through this awareness process that we transform knowledge into conscious action, ensuring that the solutions found are not only applied but also sustainable and long-lasting, as real change begins with the formation of the responsible citizen.

Justification

The present study is justified by the urgent need to develop and propose sustainable urban development strategies that effectively address the challenges posed by accelerated population growth. The research focuses on the city of UberlÃ¢ndia to analyze critical shortcomings that require interventions based on concrete data and technological innovations. The relevance of this work is established by confronting four identified problematic axes, for which specific solutions are proposed.

The first area of intervention aims to address Food Security and Urban Health. The challenge of ensuring access to quality food and green areas is met by implementing Urban Agroforestry Systems (SAFs) and expanding Local Parks. These actions are vital for mitigating the heat island effect and promoting equity in access to organic foods.

Secondly, the problem of improper disposal and low recycling rates is tackled with a Waste Management strategy based on fiscal incentives, such as an IPTU (Urban Property Tax) abatement. This measure aims to stimulate citizen participation and factory engagement, strengthening the local production chain and boosting the circular economy.

The third axis deals with Energy Resilience and Climate Mitigation, where dependence on polluting sources is combatted by promoting photovoltaic solar energy (with tax relief for citizens) and by better utilizing the biogas generated in landfills.

A crucial technical differentiator is the utilization of geospatial data (NASA/Copernicus satellites). This innovative approach guarantees technical precision and transparency in diagnosing social and ecological vulnerabilities, allowing for more efficient and strategic urban planning.

In short, the study contributes a model of urban planning that unites technological innovation, sustainability, and social equity. All proposed solutions are, ultimately, catalyzed by Environmental Education, which acts as the fundamental vector for internalizing the sense of responsibility and ensuring the long-term sustainability of the proposed actions.

General Objective

The objective is to implement measures to improve the quality of life in urban centers based on the observations we made in the city of UberlÃ¢ndia. Based on the data gathered by NASA, it's possible to observe patterns and collect useful information so that an adequate planning can be done for cities that are experiencing rapid growth, such as UberlÃ¢ndia.

Specific Objectives

We divided our specific objectives into the following topics:

  • Research general information on the topics we selected from the text "Potential Considerations" made available on the NASA Space Apps Challenge page about the theme we chose.
  • Conduct research on potential solutions to the problems that can be applied in the localities that fit our theme.
  • Analyze the applicability of systems with NASA data as one of the tools for better urban planning.
  • Relate the problems and proposed solutions to the municipality of UberlÃ¢ndia.
Methodology

The development of this work was conducted in three main phases, combining collaborative analysis with in-depth research, using a diverse set of digital tools.

The first step consisted of deliberation and problem definition through discussion meetings. In these sessions, the team worked on identifying and selecting challenges, proposing potential solutions, and, crucially, analyzing the viability of each proposal.

The second phase involved research and data collection on the following topics: access to local parks in specific communities; strategies for land use in agricultural activities; improving solid waste management; and analyzing the scarcity of access to electricity and other energy sources in communities.

Several digital tools were employed to execute and organize the work. Gemini and ChatGPT were used for research and insight generation. Searches for scientific articles, reports, and reliable references were conducted using Google Chrome and Google Scholar. Documentation, text preparation, and collaboration were conducted using Google Docs, while Canva was used to create visual materials and design the final work.

projectDetails.name: OrC (Orbital Clean)
projectDetails.summary: We developed OrC (Orbital Clean), a substation focused on transforming space debris in metallic wires which will be sold down on Earth for multiple purposes. This project contemplates the challenge of commercializing the Low Earth Orbit (LEO), presenting a viable destination for the metals filling the space in the first few thousand meters outside of the Earth. With OrC, we will guarantee the possibility of space navigation and exploration in the future, given the increasing number of space debris should prevent missions from being launched in the next few decades. Ultimately, OrC aims to reuse and commercialize what used to be considered space trash.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?Â 

OrC is responsible for capturing debris collected through a hatch in one of the bases of the cylindric structure, performing a wire drawing process on the inside in order to transform these metals into wires and storing them in boxes that will eventually be ejected back to Earth with the help of an attached parachute.

What benefits does it have?Â 

  • First, we aim to reduce the number of space debris around the Low Earth Orbit in order to avoid future trouble in regards to humanitiesâ€™ space development.Â 
  • Second, our focus is on giving purpose and market value to the debris through their refinement and transformation into wires.

What is the intended impact of the project?Â 

Transform space debris into a commercialized product by turning them into raw material to be sold on Earth, benefiting both the space market as well as ensuring safety to the future missions.Â 

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?Â 

N/A

How is your project creative?Â 

The search for innovation and the need of a solution to the space debris overflow are combined though an effective solution in the execution of this project in reason of both the approach to the recycling matter but also addressing the lack of specific raw materials.

What factors did your team consider?

The need for solution to this reoccurring problem in LEO, redirecting what would potentially become an obstacle for space navigation and exploration into a product to be commercialized on Earth.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. projectDetails.name: Project FarmFlux
projectDetails.summary:
Farm Flux is an interactive educational game that simulates sustainable agriculture using real NASA satellite data from the POWER API. Players manage virtual farms by making data-driven decisions about crop planting, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock management based on actual climate conditions.

The game addresses the NASA Farm Navigators challenge by integrating real-time temperature, precipitation, humidity, and wind data to demonstrate how satellite information can inform modern agricultural practices. Players learn the environmental and economic impacts of their decisions through a sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) and educational feedback.

This matters because it bridges the gap between space technology and practical farming education. By visualizing 30-day climate trends and showing how weather directly affects crop growth, Farm Flux teaches farmers, students, and agricultural professionals how NASA's open data can optimize resource efficiency and promote sustainable farming methodsâ€”crucial for food security in a changing climate.
projectDetails.details:
Farm FluxÂ is an interactive web-based agricultural simulation game that integrates real-time NASA satellite data to teach sustainable farming practices. Players create virtual farms at real GPS coordinates and make data-driven decisions about crop management, irrigation, fertilization, and livestock handling.

Core Mechanics:

  • Players input farm coordinates (e.g., SÃ£o Paulo: -23.5505, -46.6333)
  • NASA POWER API fetches real climate data (temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind) using MERRA-2 satellite measurements
  • Players plant crops (corn, wheat, soybean, rice, cotton) that grow automatically based on actual weather conditions
  • Every agricultural activity (9 types: organic/chemical fertilization, drip/sprinkler/flood irrigation, rotational/free-range/intensive grazing) generates educational feedback and impacts sustainability scores
  • 30-day climate trend charts visualize temperature and rainfall patterns
  • Sustainability scoring system (Grade A-F) evaluates environmental impact

ðŸŒŸ Benefits & Impact

Educational Benefits:

  1. Data Literacy: Students learn to interpret NASA satellite data for practical applications
  2. Sustainability Awareness: Visual feedback shows environmental consequences of farming choices
  3. Climate Understanding: 30-day trend charts demonstrate weather patterns' impact on agriculture
  4. Decision Making: Players balance economic costs vs. environmental sustainability

Real-World Impact:

  • For Farmers: Demonstrates how free NASA data can optimize resource efficiency (water, fertilizer)
  • For Students: Gamified learning about precision agriculture and climate science
  • For Educators: Ready-to-use tool for teaching sustainable agriculture concepts
  • For Communities: Promotes food security awareness in changing climate conditions

ðŸ› ï¸ Technology Stack

Backend:

  • Laravel 12.0Â (PHP 8.4) - Game logic, NASA API integration
  • SQLite/MySQLÂ - Storing farms, crops, weather data, activities
  • ComposerÂ - Dependency management

Frontend:

  • Vue 3.5Â (TypeScript) - Reactive UI components
  • Inertia.js 2.0Â - SPA framework bridging Laravel & Vue
  • Vite 7.0Â - Fast HMR (Hot Module Replacement)
  • Tailwind CSS 4.1Â - Responsive styling
  • Chart.jsÂ - Data visualization (30-day climate trends)
  • Reka UIÂ - Accessible component library
  • Lucide IconsÂ - Modern icon system

External APIs:

  • NASA POWER APIÂ - Real satellite data from MERRA-2 (Modern-Era Retrospective Analysis)
  • Parameters fetched: T2M (temperature), PRECTOTCORR (precipitation), RH2M (humidity), WS2M (wind speed)

DevOps:

  • GitÂ - Version control
  • NPMÂ - Frontend package management
  • ArtisanÂ - Laravel CLI for migrations, seeding, commands

ðŸŽ¨ Creative Elements

1. Gamification Design:

  • Emoji-based feedback systemÂ (âœ…ðŸŒðŸ’§âš ï¸ðŸ’¡) makes learning engaging
  • Grade systemÂ (A-F) inspired by academic scoring for familiarity
  • Toast notificationsÂ provide instant gratification/warning
  • Progress barsÂ visualize abstract concepts (soil quality, water level)

2. Data Visualization Innovation:

  • Dual-axis chart: Temperature line + precipitation bars in one view
  • Trend badgesÂ (ðŸ”¥ Warming / ðŸ§Š Cooling / âš–ï¸ Stable) simplify complex climate data
  • Color coding: Red (hot/critical), blue (water), green (healthy), orange (warning)

3. Educational Approach:

  • Contextual tips: "Drip irrigation saves up to 50% more water than traditional methods"
  • Predictive feedback: "Optimal weather for fertilization! Plants can best absorb nutrients now"
  • Comparative costs: Shows economic vs. environmental trade-offs ($50-$200/hectare)

4. Realistic Simulation:

  • Automatic crop growthÂ based on real weather (runs hourly via Laravel scheduler)
  • Growth stages: seedling â†’ vegetative â†’ flowering â†’ ripening â†’ mature
  • Harvest readiness: Crops mature only after sufficient days + favorable conditions

ðŸ§  Design Considerations

1. Accessibility:

  • Keyboard navigation: Full ARIA support via Reka UI components
  • Screen reader friendly: Semantic HTML, proper labels
  • Tooltips: Hover and focus states for information
  • Color contrast: WCAG AA compliant

2. Performance:

  • API caching: Weather data cached to minimize NASA API calls
  • Lazy loading: Components load on-demand
  • Optimistic UI updates: Instant feedback while API processes
  • Debounced inputs: Form validation doesn't trigger on every keystroke

3. Scalability:

  • Modular architecture: Services pattern (NasaWeatherService, FarmSimulationService)
  • Database migrations: Version-controlled schema changes
  • Factory & Seeders: Easy demo data generation
  • Policy-based authorization: Secure multi-user support ready

4. User Experience:

  • Empty states: Motivational messages when no crops planted
  • Loading states: Skeleton loaders prevent jarring content shifts
  • Error handling: Friendly messages instead of technical errors
  • Progressive disclosure: Advanced features revealed gradually

5. Educational Integrity:

  • Real data only: No fake/simulated climate data
  • Scientific accuracy: Fertilizer/irrigation impacts based on agricultural research
  • Transparent sources: NASA API parameters clearly documented
  • Balanced messaging: Shows benefits AND drawbacks of each method

ðŸŒ Global Applicability

Multi-Region Support:

  • Works with any GPS coordinates globally
  • NASA POWER API covers entire planet
  • Players can compare farms in different climates (e.g., Brazil vs. India)

Localization Ready:

  • Metric system (hectares, Celsius, mm, m/s)
  • Internationalization (i18n) structure prepared for multiple languages

ðŸ“Š Impact Metrics

Measurable Outcomes:

  • Sustainability Score: Quantifies environmental impact (0-100)
  • Resource Efficiency: Tracks water usage, fertilizer application
  • Yield Optimization: Compares actual vs. potential harvest
  • Cost-Benefit Analysis: Shows $/hectare vs. sustainability trade-offs

Long-term Vision:

  • Export farm reports for educational portfolios
  • Leaderboard to encourage competition
  • Achievement system to reward sustainable practices
  • Multiplayer mode for collaborative learning

All critical decisions remained human:

AI accelerated routine tasks, allowing me to focus on creative problem-solving and educational value.

projectDetails.name: Project Finstream
projectDetails.details:
FINSTREAM is an advanced, interdisciplinary system designed to integrate NASA satellite data with artificial intelligence for the real-time prediction and analysis of shark behavior. It unites oceanography, ecology, and data science to create a dynamic platform capable of transforming environmental information into biological insight.

The system operates by acquiring satellite observations from NASAâ€™s SWOT (Surface Water and Ocean Topography) and MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) missions. SWOT data provide precise measurements of sea surface height anomalies, while MODIS offers chlorophyll-a concentrations, an indicator of marine productivity. These environmental datasets are spatially and temporally aligned with high-fidelity shark telemetry, including geographic position, depth, temperature, and movement data generated or collected at high frequency.

A deep neural network trained on over 345,000 records integrates these environmental and biological variables to predict behavioral statesâ€”searching, foraging, or transitâ€”and estimates foraging probability (p_forrageio) under varying ocean conditions. The model achieves behavioral classification accuracies exceeding 85%, allowing real-time assessment of ecological responses to ocean variability.

FINSTREAMâ€™s architecture combines Python-based AI modules with a .NET backend, PostgreSQL database, and a React-based web interface for real-time visualization. The infrastructure supports simultaneous multi-shark tracking, sub-second latency processing, and modular scalability for expanded datasets.

Beyond its technical achievements, FINSTREAM delivers substantial scientific and conservation value. It provides a unique framework for correlating satellite-derived environmental metrics with biological behavior, offering an innovative validation mechanism for remote sensing data through living organisms. From a conservation perspective, it identifies biologically significant foraging regions, supports marine spatial planning, and contributes to reducing bycatch and humanâ€“shark interactions through predictive modeling.

Technologically, the project demonstrates a powerful application of NASA data to real-world ecological challenges, showcasing how spaceborne measurements can directly inform ocean management and species conservation. Its open-source design encourages scientific collaboration, reproducibility, and educational use, fostering interdisciplinary research across artificial intelligence, marine science, and climate studies.

In essence, FINSTREAM represents a novel synthesis of satellite observation, machine learning, and marine ecology. By bridging the gap between orbital sensors and biological systems, it provides a scalable, accurate, and ethically driven model for environmental intelligenceâ€”advancing both technological innovation and the global effort to understand and preserve marine ecosystems.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)
projectDetails.summary:
Low Earth Orbit (LEO) is on the verge of an unprecedented expansion. The European Space Agency (ESA) projects that the number of active satellites will rise from about 7,500 today to over 100,000 by 2035, a 1,200% increase that dramatically heightens the risk of collisions and chain fragmentation, the Kessler Syndrome.
NASAâ€™s LEGEND and ESAâ€™s MASTER models indicate that, without active mitigation, collision probabilities could rise fivefold within two decades, creating tens of thousands of new debris fragments and threatening the entire commercial use of LEO.

The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms this challenge into opportunity by creating the worldâ€™s first financial market for orbital sustainability.
Inspired by carbon credits, OCE introduces â€œorbital creditsâ€, tradable assets that reward debris removal and charge for orbital usage.
If only 1% of annual satellite launches participate, OCE could enable the removal or recycling of 2,000â€“5,000 debris objects per year, reducing orbital density by 15â€“20% within 15 years.
By aligning sustainability with profitability, OCE ensures that space remains safe, accessible, and economically vibrant for generations to come.
projectDetails.details:
Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE)

What does it do or how does it work?
The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) transforms orbital debris removal from a cost with no clear market into a sustainable economic ecosystem. Inspired by carbon markets, OCE introduces â€œorbital creditsâ€:

  • Satellite operators pay orbital fees based on mass and time in orbit.
  • Missions (public, private, or academic) that remove or recycle debris earn credits.
  • Credits can be traded in a transparent digital marketplace, creating an economic incentive for Active Debris Removal (ADR).

A web application prototype demonstrates this mechanism: operators manage their orbital balance, ADR missions simulate debris removal, and a marketplace enables credit trading. Blockchain integration ensures trust and transparency across international stakeholders.

What benefits does it have?

  • Economic Incentive: Creates a real financial driver for debris removal, solving the current lack of motivation.
  • Sustainability: Promotes circular use of orbital resources by rewarding recycling and reuse.
  • Transparency: Blockchain-backed credits guarantee trust across agencies, companies, and citizens.
  • Scalability: As more satellites are launched, the market naturally grows.
  • Collaboration: Engages governments, startups, investors, and the public in a shared framework.

What is the intended impact of the project?
The OCE establishes the first global financial market for orbital sustainability. Its impact goes beyond technology:

  • The Orbit Credits Exchange (OCE) has the potential to reduce orbital debris density by up to 20% over 15 years by funding the removal or recycling of up to 5,000 objects per year, even with participation from just 1% of annual global satellite launches.
  • Encourages responsible orbital usage and end-of-life (EOL) planning.
  • Reduces the risk of collisions and cascade effects (Kessler Syndrome).
  • Attracts ESG investors and creates a new space economy sector.
  • Raises global awareness by allowing citizens and crowdfunding initiatives to participate in orbital clean-up.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

  • Lovable.app

How is your project creative?

  • Novel Market Mechanism: First to apply the proven concept of carbon credits to space sustainability.
  • Inclusive Participation: Not limited to agenciesâ€”startups, universities, and citizens can take part.
  • Integration of Multiple Layers: Combines economics, ESG principles, blockchain trust, and orbital data in a single ecosystem.
  • Educational Impact: Serves as a tool to demonstrate orbital sustainability concepts to the general public.

What factors did your team consider?

  • Scalability: Designed to grow as satellite constellations expand.
  • Feasibility: Balance between ambitious goals (debris recycling, blockchain) and hackathon-ready prototypes (mock APIs, simulations).
  • Trust: Blockchain integration ensures international adoption potential.
  • Stakeholder Diversity: Operators, agencies, ADR missions, and investors all have defined roles.
  • Sustainability & Circularity: Ensures companies are accountable for orbital usage while encouraging innovation in debris recycling.

challengeDetails.title: Commercializing Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
challengeDetails.excerpt: As the commercialization of space rapidly accelerates, the future of business in low Earth orbit (LEO) holds incredible potential, but also presents significant operational, regulatory, and environmental challenges. This new economic frontier invites innovative and sustainable approaches to foster long-term viability and responsible execution. Your challenge is to conceptualize and design a scalable, sustainable, business model, accompanied by a prototype, that explores the unique opportunities LEO offers while addressing the complexities of operating in space. (Joint Agency Satellite Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)
