challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Gatonautas
node.excerpt: We are a team passionate about science, technology, and space exploration. Our chosen challenge is Hunting for Exoplanets with AI.  And our goal is to create an accurate and accessible solution that can support researchers and contribute to democr...

projectDetails.name: Project Space Cats
projectDetails.summary: Applying machine learning to astronomical research can be complex and often out of reach. Thatâ€™s why we aim to make exoplanet discovery accessible through a website with an intuitive, beginner-friendly interface, while still providing advanced features for researchers. Beyond data analysis, we also offer tools designed for both theoretical understanding and practical learning, empowering users to explore, experiment, and grow, because we believe that by bringing science to people, we can bring people to science.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project processes raw light curves obtained from a CSV file, running them through a custom-built pipeline designed to extract key features (such as orbital period, transit duration, and depth). Using these extracted features, a pre-trained machine learning model â€” trained on NASAâ€™s public light curve datasets processed through our own pipeline â€” predicts whether each light curve corresponds to a planet candidate, non-candidate, or confirmed planet (if matched with any known catalog entry).


All these capabilities are integrated into an intuitive web interface, which also includes an educational section that introduces exoplanet concepts in an engaging and gamified way, making learning fun and accessible.

Users can also manually classify plotted light curves through an interactive tool â€” their classifications are collected and statistically analyzed to continuously improve the machine learning models over time.

What benefits does it have?

Our project bridges the gap between professionals and newcomers in exoplanetary science. It enables both researchers without strong programming backgrounds and enthusiasts who are curious about space science to analyze and interact with real astronomical data through a web interface, while also contributing directly to model improvement.

What is the intended impact of the project?

We aim to create a tool that not only assists in the detection and classification of exoplanets but also promotes scientific outreach by democratizing access to space science. By lowering the technical barrier and integrating user contributions into the process, we hope to inspire new participants to engage with exoplanet research and data-driven astronomy.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

We used Python (and its scientific libraries) for data processing, feature extraction, and machine learning model training, as well as for the backend implementation. The frontend was developed using React, allowing for a dynamic, responsive, and interactive user experience.

How is your project creative?

The creativity of this project lies in merging two complementary goals: providing a functional research tool for scientific use, and creating an interactive educational platform for learners. It transforms a traditionally technical field into an accessible and collaborative experience for anyone interested in contributing to space science.

What factors did your team consider?

Our team focused on addressing the current imbalance in the field of astronomy, where interest in exoplanet discovery is high, but the entry barrier due to required programming and data analysis skills remains steep. We aimed to design a solution that empowers users at all levels to participate meaningfully in space exploration.

GitHub project: https://github.com/Mykaell-Max/Gatonautas
projectDetails.aiReferences:
All core ideas and project structure were conceived and implemented by our team.
AI tools (such as ChatGPT) were used to assist in research, generate code templates, and improve efficiency during development â€” for example, by helping structure functions, optimize syntax, and explore different programming approaches.

projectDetails.name: BioGalactic
projectDetails.summary:
BioGalactic is a web-based knowledge engine designed to address the "Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine" challenge. We developed a data pipeline that ingests, parses, and structures over 600 NASA life science articles from PubMed Central, storing them in a PostgreSQL database enriched with vector embeddings.

Our platform offers two powerful search modes: a traditional keyword search and a semantic search that allows users to ask natural language questions and receive contextually relevant passages as answers. To make this complex research accessible, we also utilize the Llama 3 language model to generate AI-powered summaries for each study.

BioGalactic is important because it transforms a vast repository of dense scientific data into an intuitive tool, empowering scientists, students, and the public to explore the frontiers of space biology with unprecedented ease.
projectDetails.details:
So, what did we build and how does it work?Â Our project, BioGalactic, is a smart knowledge engine that we built from the ground up to tackle the challenge. We started with a list of over 573 NASA life science articles and created an automated pipeline to bring them to life. First, we wrote a script that visits PubMed Central for each article, parses its complex JATS XML structure, and pulls out every single passage. All this structured data gets saved into a PostgreSQL database.

But just storing the text wasn't enough. We supercharged the data in three ways:

  1. Semantic Power:Â We generated vector embeddings for the most important sections of each paper (like the Abstract, Introduction, and Results). This is the magic that lets users ask real questions instead of just guessing keywords.
  2. Smart Tagging:Â We used scispaCy to automatically read through the text and identify key biological and NASA-related terms, paving the way for even smarter filtering in the future.
  3. AI Summaries:Â We fed the most relevant passages of each study to the Llama 3 model. It then generated a simple, easy-to-read summary explaining what the study was about, its impact, and the tools used.

Users explore all this through a fast frontend built with React. It talks to two different backends: a robust .NET API for browsing and filtering, and a specialized Node.js API that handles the heavy lifting of our AI-powered semantic search.

What are the benefits and impact?Â The main goal is toÂ break down the wallsÂ around complex space biology research. For scientists, BioGalactic is a massive time-saver, letting them ask questions like "how does microgravity affect the human immune system?" and get instant, relevant paragraphs from hundreds of papers. For students and the public, our AI summaries provide a "front door" to the science, making it approachable and exciting. We want to spark curiosity and help everyone, expert or not, make faster discoveries.

What's our creative spark?Â Our creativity came from not just building a search engine, but creatingÂ three different ways to see the science:

  1. The 10,000-Foot View:Â Quick, AI-generated summaries for a fast overview.
  2. The Magnifying Glass:Â Semantic search results that pinpoint the exact passages that answer your question.
  3. The Deep Dive:Â The full, structured text of the original article for in-depth analysis.

We also got creative with our architecture, using a hybrid "two-engine" backend. We used .NET for its strength with structured data and Node.js for its agility with AI tasks. It's like having a specialized engine for each job, making the whole system faster and more efficient.

What tech did we use?

  • Frontend:Â React, TypeScript, TanStack Router & Query, Tailwind CSS
  • Backend:Â .NET 8 (Main API), Node.js with Fastify (Semantic Search API)
  • Database:Â PostgreSQL with theÂ pgvectorÂ extension
  • AI/ML:Â Llama 3 (via Groq API), Hugging Face Transformers.js, scispaCy
  • DevOps:Â Docker, Docker Compose, Portainer, and Caddy for reverse proxy and HTTPS.

What factors did we think about?

  • User-Friendliness:Â We wanted it to feel fast and intuitive, whether you're just browsing or asking a complex question.
  • Honesty about the Data:Â We knew automated tools aren't perfect, so we added a clear disclaimer and a direct link to the original source on every article page.
  • Performance:Â We built it to be fast and ready to grow, usingÂ pgvectorÂ for instant search results and Docker to make sure it can handle more data and users in the future.
  • Keeping Costs Low:Â By using the super-fast Groq API and powerful open-source models, we made sure our AI features are both top-tier and incredibly cheap to run.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Artificial Intelligence is not just a tool we used; it is the core engine of our BioGalactic project. We leveraged AI in two distinct ways: as a fundamental component of the user experience and as a tool to accelerate our development process.

1. AI as a Core Project Feature:

Our platform is fundamentally AI-driven, designed to make complex scientific data accessible and queryable. We integrated AI in the following key areas:

  • AI-Generated Summaries (Data):Â The centerpiece of our accessibility effort is the AI-generated summary for each of the 573 scientific articles. We developed a data pipeline that feeds key passages from each study into theÂ Llama 3Â model (served via the high-speed Groq API). The model was prompted to extract structured information: "What was studied," "Where it was studied," "Tools used," and "Study impact." In compliance with the rules, this AI-generated content is clearly presented as a summary to distinguish it from the original source material.
  • Semantic Search (Data & Code):Â To enable users to ask natural language questions, our backend generates vector embeddings for relevant article passages using open-source Hugging Face models. The resulting vectors allow our semantic search API to find the most contextually relevant information, going far beyond simple keyword matching.
  • Named Entity Recognition (NER) (Data):Â Our data ingestion process usesÂ scispaCy, a specialized NLP library for scientific text, to identify and tag critical biological and NASA-specific entities within each article. This enriches our dataset and creates a foundation for future advanced filtering capabilities.

2. AI as a Development Tool:

In addition to being a core feature, we utilized AI language models during the development cycle to enhance our productivity and decision-making. We used these tools for:

  • Research and Comparison:Â We conducted research to compare the performance, cost, and implementation details of various open-source embedding models and Large Language Models to select the most effective and efficient options for our project (leading us to choose Llama 3 on Groq).
  • Brainstorming and Debugging:Â AI was used as a brainstorming partner for architectural decisions and as a debugging tool to help resolve complex code issues, particularly with data pipeline integration.

In summary, AI is intricately woven into the fabric of BioGalactic, powering its most innovative features and enabling our team to build a more powerful and user-friendly tool within the hackathon's timeframe.

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Platform FAHRENHurbs
projectDetails.summary: Climate change requires the attention of public administrators. Temperature  changes significantly affect quality of life. Managers are dealing with urban  infrastructure issues and the expansion of urban spaces. According to the IBGE  (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics), 87% of the Brazilian population lives  in urban areas. Various factors impact extreme heat indices; urban expansion, often  uncontrolled, raises ambient temperatures. Therefore, the development of a website is  proposed to organize and provide authorities with access to information on this issue,  enabling the implementation of measures to create new neighborhoods. The  methodology for this project was structured based on data provided by NASA on  climate change, from which the "High-Resolution Annual Global Extreme Heat  Estimates" was selected, containing information from 1983 to 2016. Using this  material, a prototype application called FahrenHurbs was developed, integrated with  the website, which uses an average of 28Â°C as a metric for extreme temperatures.  Using this data, the interface was developed to integrate and organize all the data.  This will hopefully provide urban planners with the resources to develop smart urban  growth strategies that preserve the well-being of people and the environment.
projectDetails.details:
FAHRENHURBS PLATFORM: A TOOL FOR MANAGERS ABOUT EXTREME HEAT

Alice GonÃ§alves Coutinho de Faria (alicecdf@icloud.com)

Daniel Vito Ramos (danielvitoramos@gmail.com)

Laura Rodrigues de Souza (laura.souza2@ufu.br)

Luiz Carlos Freitas Silva (luizcw2410@gmail.com)

MaÃ­sa GonÃ§alves da Silva (maisasilva.eseba@gmail.com)

Saulo Coutinho de Faria (saulocoutinho@gmail.com)

Team: GEPITronautas

Challenge: Data Pathways for Healthy Cities and Human Settlements: Climate

change brings new complexities to consider when maintaining the well-being of society

and the environment in cities. Natural resources, ecosystems, and existing

infrastructure must be monitored to ensure that the quality of human life remains high.

Your challenge is to demonstrate how urban planners can use NASA Earth observation

data to develop smart urban growth strategies that preserve the well-being of people

and the environment (Earth Sciences Division).

Abstract: Climate change requires the attention of public administrators. Temperature

changes significantly affect quality of life. Managers are dealing with urban

infrastructure issues and the expansion of urban spaces. According to the IBGE

(Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics), 87% of the Brazilian population lives

in urban areas. Various factors impact extreme heat indices; urban expansion, often

uncontrolled, raises ambient temperatures. Therefore, the development of a website is

proposed to organize and provide authorities with access to information on this issue,

enabling the implementation of measures to create new neighborhoods. The

methodology for this project was structured based on data provided by NASA on

climate change, from which the "High-Resolution Annual Global Extreme Heat

Estimates" was selected, containing information from 1983 to 2016. Using this

material, a prototype application called FahrenHurbs was developed, integrated with

the website, which uses an average of 28Â°C as a metric for extreme temperatures.

Using this data, the interface was developed to integrate and organize all the data.

This will hopefully provide urban planners with the resources to develop smart urban

growth strategies that preserve the well-being of people and the environment.

Keywords: Extreme Heat, Climate Change, Cities and Solutions.

IntroductionÂ 

Climate change is a challenge that must be considered in public administrators'Â  discussions. Population growth and the consequent expansion of urban spaces are aÂ  trend, especially in medium- and large-sized cities.Â 

According to a survey conducted by the IBGE (Brazilian Institute of GeographyÂ  and Statistics), in 2022, more than 87% of the Brazilian population lived in urban areas,Â  corresponding to approximately 203.1 million people (IBGE, 2025). This represents anÂ  increase of more than 16 million people compared to the previous survey, representingÂ  an increase of 0.82% per year. This percentage is accentuated when considering theÂ  Brazilian regions, with the Southeast region (94.44%) having the highest urbanÂ  population (IBGE, 2025), where this project is being developed. This motivated theÂ  researchers to develop a research proposal aimed at solving problems related toÂ  population growth.Â 

Therefore, to accommodate this population growth, new neighborhoods areÂ  likely to emerge in cities, requiring urban planning by various public sectors,Â  considering sanitation, urban mobility, energy, green spaces, among other aspects.Â 

The public administrator's concern is that growth contributes to the population's qualityÂ of life, enabling urban development. It is important to emphasize that growth must beÂ  aligned with progress, with a view to smart cities, where modernization and technologyÂ  aim to improve the population's quality of life, always considering the criteria ofÂ  sustainable development.Â 

"Smart cities are related to the concept of sustainable development (FGV, 2019,Â  our translation)." These are cities that align technological development withÂ  sustainability, while also considering the population's quality of life and naturalÂ  resources.Â 

These cities, a projection of the future urban environment, have characteristicsÂ that have evolved over time. [...] However, when a city has better dataÂ Â management, it is possible to achieve holistic solutions involving differentÂ Â urban systems (FGV, 2019, our translation).Â 

"Science has no doubt that climate change is generating significant impacts forÂ  Brazil and the planet as a whole (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 2, our translation)." ClimateÂ  change affects different sectors, impacting the economy, ecosystems, naturalÂ  resources, infrastructure, health, among other areas, and can compromise the wellÂ being of society and the environment in cities. Among the different effects of climateÂ  change, this work will focus on the impacts on temperature variations, consideringÂ  extreme heat. Urban development patterns produce many impacts related to urbanÂ  climate, notably the phenomenon of extreme heat, which results in impacts such asÂ  health needs; energy supply, which is impacted by high temperatures in addition toÂ  high consumption; water supply, which increases significantly during this period; andÂ  transportation, which increases the number of vehicles in circulation, as there is aÂ  preference for private transportation over public transportation on days of extremeÂ  heat. These are some of the impacts of this phenomenon, which are exacerbated byÂ  temperatures that exceed the global average. As well as the impacts of this factor,Â such as the number of days of the event and the population affected by theÂ Â phenomenon.Â 

As a result of urban expansion, the importance of urban climateÂ Â studies is debated and, in this context, they are fundamental toÂ Â understanding UCI across scales of analysis, integratingÂ Â everything from the environmental quality of citizens to theÂ Â impacts of UCI on regional climate (UMMUS EICHEMBERGERÂ Â et al., 2008). The negative effects of UCI include environmentalÂ degradation such as poor air quality, increased energyÂ consumption for building cooling, respiratory diseases, and lowÂ Â productivity (WERNECK, 2018, p. 18, our translation).Â 

In urban spaces, built-up areas and circulation routes prevent heat accumulatedÂ  at the surface from being transported to the upper atmosphere, which prevents heatÂ  lossâ€”that is, the circulation of cold airâ€”which occurs more readily in rural areas.Â  Therefore, urban areas experience higher temperatures than rural areas, varying byÂ  around 1Â°C compared to small urban areas, but this difference can exceed 4Â°C in largeÂ  urban centers (LOPES et al, 2022). "The intensity of urban heat depends on its spatialÂ  location, as well as local characteristics (LOPES et al, 2022, p. 285, our translation)."Â 

Many Brazilian cities are "highly susceptible to the most severe impacts ofÂ  climate change, such as [...] intensification of temperature rise due to the urban heatÂ  island (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 14, our translation)." Problems resulting from these climateÂ  changes threaten to exceed the capacity of Brazilian cities to absorb losses andÂ  recover from their impacts, thus justifying reflection on solutions to minimize theirÂ  impacts.Â 

These impacts tend to exacerbate the risks commonly encountered inÂ Â Brazilian cities, as well as the inadequacies in local governments' capacity toÂ Â address internal infrastructure and the failure to provide necessary basicÂ Â services, exacerbating the vulnerability of certain social groups andÂ Â communities. Therefore, mitigation and adaptation strategies in urban centersÂ must consider aspects such as habitability, thermal comfort, health, mobility,Â Â urban planning, transportation, access to water and energy, among otherÂ Â aspects (ARTAXO, 2022, p. 14-15, our translation).Â 

Developing solutions to this problem can mean savings for the public coffers.Â  Planning to improve the population's quality of life while considering the city's growth,Â  with the emergence of new planned neighborhoods, tends to contribute to reducing theÂ  impacts of heat zones, thus making the city more sustainable. This justifies the work,Â  considering the production of a website and possibly an application for publicÂ  administration to process data. This will support the allocation of funds to minimize theÂ  impacts of extreme heat, enabling the planning of new neighborhoods.Â 

Extreme heat refers to temperatures exceeding 28Â°C, the planet's averageÂ  temperature. Urban heat islands are "one of the main causes of decreased bioclimaticÂ  comfort in areas where surface patterns are heterogeneous, especially in summerÂ  (LOPES et al, 2022, 281, our translation)." Several factors impact heat zones, such asÂ  season, built-up area, location, and vegetation, which can impede evapotranspiration,Â  favoring increased radiative absorption and, consequently, a significant increase inÂ  surface temperatures.Â 

The proposal aims to support public administrators by presenting elements thatÂ  can inform the development of smart growth strategies, creating new neighborhoodsÂ  that preserve the well-being of people and the environment, focusing on the analysisÂ  of NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) data on extreme heat.Â 

MethodologyÂ 

The methodology used was a review of the data provided, considering theÂ  decision-making process of the study object. This step supported the selection ofÂ reference materials, considering the data on which the group based its solution to theÂ Â problem.Â 

Computer simulation can be used as a research method to understand urbanÂ Â climate-related phenomena and evaluate mitigation strategies for the impactsÂ Â of urban climate control (ICU) before their implementation. This resource hasÂ Â been widely applied in educational and research projects and can be anÂ alternative to fieldwork for obtaining diagnostic information (WERNERC,Â 2018, p. 52, our translation).Â 

To organize the actions, a mental map was created to organize how the problemÂ  of extreme heat impacts the population.Â 

Figure 1: Mind MapÂ 

Source: Authors' own.

With this resource in mind, the researchers decided to create a website whereÂ  public managers could visualize the impact of extreme heat events, using populationÂ  as one of the baseline data. This data would be displayed on a map. Visually, the sizeÂ  of the circle relates to the number of people affected by the event, while the sidebar,Â  with varying colors, relates to the intensity of the event, as shown in Figure 2.Â 

Managers can also obtain more information by clicking the icon, which opens aÂ  tab with additional information, as shown in Figure 2, related to other factors that impactÂ  the extreme heat index.Â 

Figure 2: Website LayoutÂ 

Source: Authors' own.

The project works with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which wereÂ discussed during the United Nations (UN) General Assembly in September 2015 andÂ  included in the 2030 Agenda. Among the objectives related to the proposal, theÂ  following stand out: SDG 11 Sustainable cities and communities; SDG 13 CombatÂ  climate change.Â 

Figure 3: Application LogoÂ 

Source: Authors' own.Â 

An application is also expected to be developed that uses the information filteredÂ  by the website. The application icon is shown in Figure 3 and is calledÂ  "FAHRENHURBS." The application name comes from Fahrenheit, a measure ofÂ  temperature, and Hurbs, which means "city" in Latin. The logo's colors were based onÂ  the SDGs, a mix of 11, which is orange, and 13, which is green.Â 

To develop the website and, subsequently, the application, data from the studyÂ  "Annual Global High-Resolution Extreme Heat Estimates" (GEHE) were used,Â  covering information from 1983 to 2016. The research group opted to review the dataÂ provided and select the material, as it provides compiled data that is already organized,Â streamlining the process, unlike the analysis and processing of raw data using satelliteÂ  imagery. The choice of this model refers to the fact thatÂ 

[...] GEHE provides scientific researchers and decision-makers from a wideÂ Â range of fields, including climate change, public and occupational health,Â Â urban planning and design, risk reduction, and food security, with insights intoÂ Â how humid heat has impacted human and environmental systems worldwide.Â Â The dataset can be used to identify how changes in extreme humid heatÂ Â impact human health and well-being, as well as ecological systems, at scalesÂ Â ranging from local to national to global. (TUHOLSKE, 2021, our translation).Â 

To determine the areas potentially exposed to extreme heat and, by extension,Â  more susceptible to climate vulnerability, the study's data were processed andÂ  selected, including average temperatures above the 28Â°C limit, excess heat, dates onÂ  which these indices were observed, the period of occurrence, the duration interval, theÂ  intensity of the event, the location of the collected data, vegetation, built-up area,Â  population, and other factors that significantly impact extreme heat in urban areas.Â  Other data from the study were not considered in the development of the website andÂ  app; the research group already had a large amount of data to analyze, so it wasÂ  decided to filter this data.Â 

The temperature parameters are based on ISO (International Organization forÂ  Standardization) criteria, which relate to the risk of extreme heat, based on the planet'sÂ  average temperatures. These are defined as days when WBGTmax > 28, 30, and 32Â  degrees Celsius, that is, when the temperature is characterized as extreme heat.Â 

The days with this temperature index are the markers used as coefficients,Â  correlating with the magnitude of the event. This dataset also includes the annual rateÂ  of change in the number of extreme heat days that exceeded these thresholds.Â 

In the search for a website or application that would facilitate the creation ofÂ  Fahrenhurbs, the researchers tested three different websites: Kodular, Wix, andÂ  Thunkable. During the tests, the only one that proved easiest to use was Thunkable,Â due to its practicality, so we will attempt to use it to create the application. The otherÂ two sites presented website creation errors using AI (Artificial Intelligence) or wereÂ  difficult to create due to paid plans, so the researchers chose to work with the tool thatÂ  best suited the parameters established for their work.Â 

The application's initial interface features the home, explore, notifications, andÂ  profile pages. The categories include weather, strategy, emergency, risk areas, smartÂ  cities, and safety tips, as shown in Figure 4.Â 

Figure 4: Application

Source: Authors' own.Â 

The data were organized and processed as shown in Figure 5 to enableÂ  analysis. This process is necessary to compile the information and plot it on the websiteÂ  interface and later on the application. Python was used, "Managed by the PSF (PythonÂ  Software Foundation), the Python programming language is extremely simple andÂ robust. Its well-designed architecture provides good performance and code readability"Â Â (SILVA; SOUSA & SILVA, 2019, p. 55, our translation).Â 

Figure 5: Data AnalysisÂ 

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021).Â 

The group chose to use this language because it is...Â 

[...] present in various everyday applications, supporting other tasks. TheÂ Â language is highly versatile and can be used in commercial settings or in moreÂ Â specific areas such as scientific development, geoprocessing, and mobileÂ Â applications, either alone or integrated with other tools, further expanding theÂ Python world (SILVA; SOUSA & SILVA, 2019, p. 55-56, our translation).Â 

The program data is organized to present a range from 1983 to 2016,Â  considering the population of cities, population growth, and consequently the numberÂ  of people affected by extreme heat events, as can be seen in Figure 6.

Figure 6: Code â€“ Analysis Range: Population ParametersÂ 

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021).Â 

Figure 7 refers to the intensity of the extreme heat event, considering variousÂ  factors such as the number of days the event lasts, the temperature, and other factorsÂ  that will result in the extreme heat event coefficient.Â 

Figure 7: Code â€“ Analysis Range: Event Intensity

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021).Â 

In Figure 8, the event intensity data are correlated with the population, resultingÂ  in a parameter that allows comparison between two variables with different magnitudesÂ  (population and event intensity).Â 

Figure 8: Code â€“ Analysis Range: Event Intensity x Population

Source: (TUHOLSKE et al, 2021).Â 

Determining this variable, which combines population and event intensity,Â  makes it possible to compare events that occurred in different cities with differentÂ  numbers of people affected, thus enabling decision-making by public officials. ThisÂ  action is necessary for the construction of the website, as well as the applicationÂ  interface, based on this entire analysis performed with the database.Â 

Final ConsiderationsÂ 

This study focuses solely on the problem of extreme heat, presenting data forÂ  public officials to use in decision-making, highlighting the negative effects of thisÂ  phenomenon, which can consequently generate greater government spending. ThisÂ  would support decision-making with mitigation actions that can be propagated,Â  exploring opportunities for cooling cities and creating new neighborhoods, which areÂ planned to promote the advancement of smart city development. In this sense, studiesÂ on mitigation actions, focusing on extreme heat monitoring, are becoming the target ofÂ  multidisciplinary research that discusses quality of life, materials development,Â  climatology, and architecture and urban planning due to the economic, social, andÂ  environmental impacts resulting from the benefits of reduced air temperature. This isÂ  reflected in the planned growth of cities, ensuring a balance between economics andÂ  sustainability.Â 

Thus, it is hoped to provide urban planners with resources, considering NASA'sÂ  Earth observation data, to develop smart urban growth strategies that preserve theÂ  well-being of people and the environment.Â 

Urban planners are responsible for shaping the best way to supportÂ  communities in their landscapes. Rapidly growing cities must implement balancedÂ  projects to enable successful economic development and climate resilience. EarthÂ  observation data resources can inform urban planning strategies. Data on extremeÂ  heat can help planners assess the sustainability of urban environments over time andÂ  support better decision-making for long-term growth.Â

projectDetails.name: Project NASA Helps Farming
projectDetails.summary:
We developed an interactive educational game called "NASA Space Farming", which simulates agriculture in space environments using real NASA data. The web application combines elements of gamification with scientific information on climate, soil moisture, and vegetation health obtained from NASA satellites.
The project tackles the challenge of educating about sustainable agriculture and space science in an accessible and engaging way. Players manage limited resources, make data-driven decisions, and learn about farming techniques in microgravity.
This initiative is important because it democratizes access to complex scientific data, promotes STEM education, and raises awareness of the challenges of food production in the context of climate change and space exploration, inspiring future generations of scientists and farmers.
projectDetails.details:
What is the Game?

The game is a simulation of agricultural activities where the player cultivates various crops (sunflower, tomato, lettuce, soybean, wheat, corn, and coffee).

Throughout the game, the player is guided to make decisions based on satellite data, primarily from NASA. The game provides an immersive experience in managing both crops and livestock (dogs, cattle, chickens, and sheep), all while emphasizing the use of real-time data.

Objectives/Benefits

With this project, we aim to create not just an entertainment source but also a valuable tool for information and experiences that directly connect with real-life situations. We hope to make the understanding of satellite data clearer and more practical, showing its importance in complementing ground-based data in various scenarios. External data, like aerial images, can greatly assist farmers, leading to more sustainable agricultural practices.

The game is designed to closely mirror real-world situations, and it uses accessible language and design, aiming to reach a broad audience, not just professionals in the field. It serves as a light, fun way to spark interest in agricultural technologies and data, breaking down the barriers to their implementation. It emphasizes that obtaining information isn't enough; itâ€™s crucial to apply and make good use of it.

Using NASA Data

TheÂ  maps guide the player on the best types of crops to grow based on the available data. The data from NASA (like NDVI, temperature, and humidity) are crucial for guiding in-game decisions, helping players understand how these external data sources influence agricultural practices.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

How to Play

The game starts with the player logging in to save progress. After logging in, the player selects between two scales for their farm:Â IndustrialÂ orÂ Small. The player can then track their mission, progress, score, and theÂ Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). Below this, there is a progress bar and an area showing coordinates and the action performed. The available actions are: cultivating, fertilizing, and managing livestock.

There are two buttons: one updates the NASA data, and the other shows the points required to advance to the next mission. A world map shows the location of the player's farm, which is tied to the data from NASA. The game promotes understanding of how to use data effectively to resolve issues, highlighting their importance in making informed decisions.

The farm/soil is represented by a graph, and the player selects an action to perform by clicking on it. Lastly, the player can track soil moisture and plant health through graphs over time.

How It Works

The game is a simulation of farm management, combining agronomy (sunflower, tomato, lettuce, soybean, wheat, corn, and coffee) and livestock (dog, cattle, chicken, sheep). The gameplay is guided by real-time NASA data, which highlights the direct impact these data have on in-game actions.

Benefits/Objectives

With the project, we intend to create more than just entertainment; we aim to offer information and experiences that will help players connect directly to real-world agricultural challenges. The goal is to make satellite data easier to understand and to show its value in complementing ground-based data in various scenarios. External data, like aerial imagery, can play a crucial role in assisting farmers and promoting more sustainable farming practices. The game is designed to be accessible, encouraging a broad audienceâ€”not just professionals in the fieldâ€”to engage with the concept of using data in agriculture.

It aims to spark curiosity in a light, fun way and to help break down the barriers to integrating technology and data into agricultural practices. The focus is not just on obtaining information but on applying it effectively for better outcomes.
projectDetails.aiReferences: The tools we used were artificial intelligence and websites provided by the NASA SPACE APPS team. The artificial intelligence we used was Blackbox, Kimi, Chat GPT, and Gemini, which we used for help developing ideas and codebase ideas. We also used them for logo ideas and cropping the logo's edges. We added the information from the provided website to the game.

projectDetails.name: Eco City
projectDetails.summary:
Eco City : We build the conection, we live the change
Eco City is a data-driven sustainability platform that transforms citizens into active agents of environmental change. By converting eco-friendly actions, such as cycling, walking, or using public transport, into Green Tokens, the system monetizes avoided COâ‚‚ emissions and makes sustainable habits financially rewarding. Unlike traditional carbon credit systems restricted to corporations, Eco City democratizes the market, integrating individuals, companies, and governments in a shared ecosystem of incentives and transparency. Each token represents a tangible and auditable environmental contribution, backed by a sustainable rewards fund that combines carbon credit sales, ESG sponsorships, and circular-economy vouchers. Beyond personal engagement, Eco City also empowers urban planners by providing real-time mobility data and seasonal reports that bridge the gap in outdated urban databases. This dynamic flow of environmental and mobility information enables more accurate planning, forecasting, and policy design.
projectDetails.details:
ECO CITY â€“ PROJECT FOR THE NASA SPACE APPS CHALLENGE

Challenge: Data Pathways and Healthier Cities

Team: Guardians of the city


In the current world, it is evident that pollutant emissions and sustainability have become critical issues in the social fabric. According to data released by NASA's observatory in 2023, the combined effects of polluted air contribute to 6.7 million premature deaths per year. Thus, atmospheric contamination is a determining factor in the degradation of quality of life.
The causes that aggravate this issue are diverse, with the main ones being: constant use of individual motor vehicles, excessive consumption of electricity and cooling, as well as the inadequate disposal of waste.Furthermore, the time gap for updating urban data is detrimental to urban development, as planners are limited to outdated data, which leads to delays and poor city planning. In this way, Eco City emerges as a solution that connects the environment to the urban planner.
Eco City is the MVP of a fintech company aimed at Generation Z, which seeks health, quality of life, and has become engaged in sustainability issues, as shown by Forbes in the article: Gen Z cares about Sustainability: make your brand actions tangible. For the prototype, we used React Native and Git. At the same time, it is noted that the carbon credit trade remains restricted to the business sphere, disregarding the potential of societyâ€™s participation and cooperation as an active agent of environmental impact. In this scenario, Eco City aims to promote integration and collective engagement, aligning the interests of individuals, industry, and the State for sustainable and shared development.
To achieve this, radical innovation is required by creating a sustainable incentive ecosystem that transforms individual environmental actions into real economic value. This proposal fundamentally democratizes the carbon credit market. The technical basis of the GreenToken â€“ Eco City's economic system â€“ is anchored in the metric of avoided COâ‚‚, measured through a transparent and auditable methodology. We used as reference the average emission of a gasoline-powered car, estimated at 0.2 kg COâ‚‚/km, a value that represents the average fleet in circulation. Whenever a user replaces the car with an ecological alternative, the system quantifies the direct reduction in emissions using the formula: Tokens per km = (COâ‚‚ avoided by the activity / COâ‚‚ avoided by the bicycle) Ã— Effort Multiplier. The practical application of this results in specific values for each type of transport: cycling generates 1.0 token/km as the reference standard, walking produces 1.25 tokens/km given its urban mobility, and public transportation generates approximately 0.5 token/km, reflecting its proportionally lower impact â€“ it should be 0.75, but to compensate for walking, the token value for public transport was reduced.
The value of each Green Token was stabilized at $0.87 through a calculation that considers economic viability and aims to engage the user. This value is not arbitrary but derived from a fundamental comparative analysis: considering only the pure value of the carbon credit at $79/tCOâ‚‚ â€“ according to the Chicago Stock Exchange on 10/05/2024 â€“ the value per kilometer cycled would be only $0.0158, resulting in just $4.74 per month if the user cycled 300 km/month â€“ an amount clearly insignificant and insufficient to motivate a change in habits. Thus, through a model in which the token value is given by token = monthly target payout / average tokens generated per month. For an average user performing 20 kilometers of cycling (20 Green Tokens), 10 kilometers of walking (15 Green Tokens), and 50 km of public transport (25 Green Tokens), totaling 60 Green Tokens per month, the calculation 52.20/60 = 0.87 USD/token ensures a payout of $52.20, a value sufficiently effective to generate engagement in the population.
The superiority of this model becomes evident in direct comparison with the traditional carbon credit system. In the same usage scenario, the conventional model would generate only $0.95 per month ($0.316 from cycling + $0.237 from walking + $0.395 from public transport), making the incentive of Green Tokens 55 times more powerful and transforming carbon credits from a technical instrument into a viable mechanism of social and economic engagement.
Economic sustainability is guaranteed by the tripartite structure of the Rewards Fund. First, through the sale of aggregated carbon credits, where the actions of all users are consolidated using the formula: Total credits (tCOâ‚‚) = Î£ (equivalent km Ã— 0.0002) for sale on the voluntary market. Second, through corporate sponsorships for ESG and sustainable marketing, where companies finance part of the fund to achieve proven environmental goals. Third, through the circular economy with partner vouchers, allowing tokens to be exchanged for products and services, reducing the need for direct liquidity in dollars. This structure ensures that the token at $0.87 functions as a stable internal conversion value, backed by real assets and recurring revenues, not by market speculation.
Users have multiple ways of realizing value: direct cash withdrawal, exchange for premium vouchers at partner establishments, donations to environmental projects, or participation in gamification systems with rankings and missions that offer multipliers and additional bonuses. This diversified ecosystem creates virtuous cycles of sustainable engagement, where each use or redemption feeds back into the system while generating valuable impact data for companies and governments.
In conclusion, Green Tokens profoundly redefine the role of the citizen in the contemporary carbon economy. By systematically converting sustainable activities into measurable and financially relevant value, we create a paradigm where individuals are fairly and motivationally rewarded; companies meet ESG goals with precise traceability and authentic social engagement; governments and cities acquire new metrics for participatory decarbonization; and the planet benefits from real, measurable, and auditable emission reductions. The $0.87 token thus symbolizes much more than a monetary value â€“ it represents the concrete instrument that materializes environmental impact into tangible economic and social return, transforming sustainability from an abstract concept into a lived purpose and shared benefit.
In addition, the Eco City project also includes an interface for the urban planner. As mentioned earlier, whether governmental or not, the time gap for updating this data hinders professionals from predicting and designing scenarios, which delays urban development. Thus, with data collected from users on urban mobility, planners would rely on seasonal reports to complement the previous database, thereby reducing the time gap.
For future implementations, the proposal is to integrate municipal data on infrastructure, mobility, sanitation, energy, and housing with NASA's spatial information, capable of representing the environmental and climatic behavior of the territory. From this combination, we could build a simulator that projects possible changes in the city and assists in visualizing the consequent urban alterations in the region, such as increased traffic or microeconomic changes, with precision.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (â€œtrashâ€) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

challengeDetails.title: Your Home in Space: The Habitat Layout Creator
challengeDetails.excerpt: Space habitats are â€œhomes in spaceâ€ that keep crew members healthy and able to execute their mission. Whether located on a planetary surface or in space, habitats must support critical functions such as waste management, thermal control, life support, communications, power, stowage, food storage and preparation, medical care, sleep, and exercise. Space habitat concepts can involve a diverse array of materials, geometries, and layouts. Your challenge is to create a visual tool that enables users to define a space habitatâ€™s shape/volume and explore possible layout options. (Exploration Systems Development Mission Directorate)

Your challenge is to develop a web-based app that forecasts air quality by integrating real-time TEMPO data with ground-based air quality measurements and weather data, notifying users of poor air quality, and helping to improve public health decisions. Teams are encouraged to utilize new technologies that allow seamless scaling of computing from local devices to cloud systems, enhancing collaboration and streamlining work efficiency. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Deep Dive: Immersive Data Stories from Ocean to Sky
challengeDetails.excerpt: Satellite observations reveal insights about our dynamic home planet to scientists, but people without a remote sensing background often find the stories within these datasets difficult to access. NASAâ€™s open data policy makes these observations available to everyoneâ€”scientists and non-scientists alike. projectDetails.name: Project KOIKWA
projectDetails.summary:
Koikwa 1 â€“ Buraco no CÃ©u is an educational Internet of Things (IoT) project designed to simulate satellite data acquisition and analysis. The system measures local environmental conditionsâ€”specifically temperatureâ€”using a BMP180 sensor connected to a Heltec V3 microcontroller, and compares these ground-based readings with satellite-derived temperature estimates from NASAâ€™s POWER (Prediction of Worldwide Energy Resources) dataset.

Additionally, the project integrates a u-blox M10 GPS module to record geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), ensuring accurate spatial correlation between local and satellite data. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) in real time to a connected application, where it is stored, visualized through dynamic graphs, and analyzed statistically to highlight variations and trends.

The overarching mission of Koikwa 1 â€“ Buraco no CÃ©u is to inspire scientific curiosity and technological learning among children by providing a hands-on demonstration of how IoT technologies and open-access satellite data can be combined to explore environmental science in an accessible and engaging way.
projectDetails.details: Â The project aims to simulate the reading of satellite data by comparing temperature measurements obtained from the BMP180 sensor with information from NASA POWER, while also displaying latitude and longitude data using the u-blox M10 GPS module, with both the module and sensor controlled by the ESP32-S3 microcontroller.

projectDetails.name: Project Koikwa 2
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Koikwa 2 - Cotton Rope, is a space lander prototype designed as an educational tool for instrumentation, embedded electronics, sensing, and programming. We developed a system using a BBC micro:bit board and an HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor to map surfaces by acquiring real-time distance and magnetic field data. The micro:bit's internal magnetometer measures the magnetic field, providing orientation and composition data, while the ultrasonic sensor determines the lander's altitude and maps the surface topography.
This prototype directly addresses the challenge by providing a hands-on, low-cost platform for learning essential space exploration technologies. Our project is deeply inspired by the origin story of the KayapÃ³ people of Brazil, whose ancestors descended from the sky on a long cotton rope. In their story, the stars represent their celestial ancestors. Our lander's descent to map a new world mirrors this mythological journey. This connection is important as it bridges modern space science with the rich, ancient cosmology of indigenous cultures, reminding us that the quest to understand our origins and explore new frontiers is a timeless, universal human endeavor.
projectDetails.details:
Inspiration: A Bridge Between Worlds

Our project is deeply rooted in the powerful origin story of the MebÃªngÃ´kre (KayapÃ³) people, an indigenous ethnicity from our home region in UberlÃ¢ndia, Brazil. Their cosmology tells of ancestors who lived in the sky until a warrior discovered a passage to Earth. Enchanted by the world below, they decided to descend using a long rope made of cotton. For them, the stars are their celestial ancestors, a nightly reminder of their origins.

Our lander's missionâ€”to descend from above and map an unknown worldâ€”is a direct technological parallel to this ancient journey. OurÂ "Cotton Rope"Â is the stream of data connecting our probe to our control station. The goal of Koikwa 2 is to create a project that is not only scientifically functional but also rich in meaning, connecting the drive for space exploration with humanity's oldest stories about the cosmos.

How It Works: The Technical Mission

Koikwa 2 is a functional prototype built to demonstrate the core principles of a planetary lander's survey mission.

  • Hardware Core:Â The brain of our lander is aÂ BBC micro:bit, a versatile and accessible microcontroller. It's connected to anÂ HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor, which acts as a simple altimeter and surface scanner. The entire system is powered by a 3.7V LiPo battery, making it a self-contained unit.
    1. Topographical Mapping:Â The HC-SR04 sensor emits ultrasonic pulses and measures the time it takes for the echo to return. Our code converts this time into a precise distance measurement, allowing the lander to map the height and contours of the surface below it.
    2. Magnetic Field Analysis:Â Simultaneously, the micro:bitâ€™s onboard magnetometer gathers magnetic field data (X, Y, Z axes). This data can be used to determine the lander's orientation and could potentially detect magnetic anomalies on a planetary surface.
  • Software & Data Stream:Â The firmware was developed inÂ MicroPython, valued for its simplicity and power. The lander outputs a continuous stream of comma-separated values (CSV) in the formatÂ distance_cm, magnetic_field_x, magnetic_field_y, magnetic_field_zÂ via a serial connection. This raw data can be easily logged, parsed, and visualized using simple scripts or even spreadsheet software.


How Our Project Addresses the Challenge

Koikwa 2 directly addresses the challenge of creating educational tools for space science in several ways:

  • Accessibility & Low Cost:Â It uses off-the-shelf, affordable components, making space science accessible to students, hobbyists, and educators without large budgets.
  • Hands-On Learning:Â It provides a tangible platform for learning fundamental skills in electronics, programming (MicroPython), sensor integration, and data analysisâ€”the very skills needed for a career in aerospace.
  • Inspiration & STEAM:Â By connecting STEM with the Arts and Humanities (the "A" in STEAM), our project provides a powerful narrative hook to engage a wider and more diverse audience in the wonders of space exploration.

projectDetails.name: The Secrets of Space Weather
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, â€œThe Secrets of Space Weatherâ€, focuses on teaching kids about space weather through a fun and educational game. The main goal is to make complex scientific concepts, such as solar flares, CMEs, radiation storms, and their effects on Earth, accessible and engaging for young learners. We developed an interactive digital game that combines storytelling, colorful visuals, and simple challenges to encourage curiosity and understanding of how the Sun influences our planet.

To address the challenge of limited awareness and education about space weather among children, "The Secrets of Space Weather" uses gamified learning techniques and playful interaction. The game provides short missions where players learn about solar activity and understand the importance of space weather in our lives. This approach transforms abstract scientific data into relatable, hands-on experiences.

"The Secrets of Space Weather" is important because it bridges the gap between science and education, inspiring the next generation to explore astronomy and space science. By presenting real scientific ideas in a creative and age-appropriate way, the project promotes STEM education (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) and helps build a foundation for future scientific curiosity and understanding.
projectDetails.details:
The mysteries of space weather and its influence on Earth are often seen as complex and distant subjects, but they can directly affect our daily lives. Solar flares, coronal mass ejections, and geomagnetic storms can interfere with communication systems, navigation, and even power grids. Despite their importance, these phenomena are rarely explored in an accessible way for young audiences.

To change this, we created â€œThe Secrets of Space Weatherâ€, a digital educational gameÂ  that combines science, art, and narrative to introduce children and teenagers aged 10 to 15 years to the fascinating world of space weather â€” in a fun and interactive way.

The story follows Luma, a curious girl passionate about science who embarks on a journey guided by her scientist friend, Dr.Brall, to discover what space weather is and how it affects people around the world. Across three exciting phases, Luma meets different characters such as a pilot struggling with signal loss, a photographer chasing auroras, and astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation. Throughout these, Luma meets not only people impacted by the space weather but also the personified phenomena themselves.

Each event, like a Solar Flare, an Aurora Borealis or a Radiation Storm, becomes a living character who explains its origins and behavior. These unique interactions allow children to learn from both sides of the story: the people who experience the effects and the solar phenomena that cause them. Each encounter includes playful dialogues that translate scientific concepts into easy understanding comparisons and mini-games that reinforce learning in a fun way.

What makes our solution unique is its creative and emotional approach. The personification of solar events gives them memorable and relatable personalities that help children connect emotionally with scientific ideas. Through visual metaphors and everyday analogies, the game connects abstract physics to the childâ€™s own world, making learning intuitive and inspiring.

Unlike traditional educational materials, our game does not just explain â€” it invites the player to live science, allowing children to actively participate in the narrative, helping characters and solving thematic mini-games. This promotes active learning, critical thinking, and curiosity through play.Â 

Another key differentiator is the balanced portrayal of space weatherâ€™s dual nature â€” its challenges, like radiation and interference, and its beauty, like the auroras that paint the sky. Few educational materials highlight this duality, and our game does so in a way that sparks wonder, empathy, and environmental awareness.

Beyond entertainment, the game has strong educational potential. It can be integrated into classrooms or informal learning environments as a support tool for science education and space literacy, encouraging new generations to become interested in astronomy, physics, and environmental awareness.

Our current version functions as a pilot project with three stages, designed to demonstrate the gameâ€™s educational potential and scalability. Future levels can be created to expand this universe, introducing new challenges such as helping a power grid operator redirect Geomagnetically Induced Currents (GICs) to protect transformers from failures caused by Geomagnetic Disturbances (GMDs); assisting a space traffic engineer in maneuvering satellites to compensate for increased atmospheric drag driven by Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) and neutral density (ND) expansion; or even supporting a farmer in stabilizing GNSS signals to ensure precise planting despite signal scintillation during a geomagnetic storm. This progressive expansion highlights the real-world diversity of space weather impacts, demonstrating the gameâ€™s potential to grow further while educating players about some of the most fascinating space phenomena.

The project was developed using Kripta for character and environment design and Godot 4.5 as the main game engine, with GDScript as the primary programming language. The Dialogic plugin was implemented to manage the interactive storytelling system. Team collaboration was supported through Discord for communication and Git/GitHub for version control and code synchronization.

The educational content is based on NASA data, which provided the scientific foundation to explain key space weather concepts such as solar flares, aurora borealis, radiation storms, coronal mass ejections (CMEs), and the solar activity cycle. The design of the gameâ€™s levels and missions â€” such as helping a transatlantic pilot after a solar flare or saving astronauts facing dangerous solar radiation â€” was created by insights from a NASA survey on user needs for space weather, ensuring the gameplay aligns with realistic scenarios and practical understanding.

The game's design is directly inspired by the Results of the First National Survey of User Needs for Space Weather (NASA resource) report, which outlines user needs and critical impacts across seven sectors important to national security, the economy, and society. The idea was to transform documented space weather threats into a dynamic challenges. For instance, the Aviation Sector phase mirrors the real-world operational need to mitigate risks from Solar Flares that cause HF communication outages (Radio Blackouts), forcing the player to execute the maneuver of diverting the aircraft to safer routes, replicating actions taken by some air carriers during events like the Gannon Storm. By translating these specific, identified sector vulnerabilities and the documented need for improved education and awareness into dynamic mechanics the game directly contributes to the overarching goal of enhancing national resilience to space weather.

Ultimately, â€œThe Secrets of Space Weatherâ€ seeks to make space science accessible, emotional, and inspiring. By transforming NASAâ€™s research into a living adventure, combining visual design, gameplay mechanics, and verified space weather data, our project not only educates but also cultivates the next generationâ€™s curiosity about the Sunâ€“Earth connection, motivating young minds to explore, discover, and protect the world around them â€” from the ground to the stars â€” with wonder and understanding.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AI (ChatGPT version 5.0) primarily to assist with translation, text refinement, and generating ideas for the project script. Additionally, AI was employed to troubleshoot technical issues and suggest improvements in code.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. â€œSpace weatherâ€â€”the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earthâ€”can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital childrenâ€™s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Lobotomia SoluÃ§Ãµes
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, Astral Leucotome, is an interactive, web-based simulation tool that models the regional consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. We developed a Python Flask backend that serves as the scientific engine, coupled with a dynamic JavaScript frontend that provides intuitive controls and a map-based interface for visualizing the outcomes.
This tool directly addresses the challenge by allowing users to select real asteroids from NASA's API or customize their own theoretical impactor. The backend calculates a suite of environmental effects using physics-based models, including crater dimensions, kinetic energy, seismic magnitude, and air blast radius. These calculations are based on established scientific principles, such as the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic shaking and yield scaling for the air blast. Users can also simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission, demonstrating how a spacecraft can alter an asteroid's velocity.
The importance of this project lies in its ability to make the abstract threat of an asteroid impact tangible and accessible. By translating complex scientific data into clear, visual consequences, it serves as a powerful educational tool for the public, students, and policymakers, effectively underscoring the critical importance of planetary defense initiatives.
projectDetails.details:
What It Does & How It Works

Astral Leucotome is a web-based simulation tool that calculates and visualizes the regional environmental consequences of an asteroid impact on Earth. It operates on a client-server architecture:

  • Backend: A robust API built with Python and the Flask framework serves as the scientific engine. It receives simulation parameters, fetches real-time data on near-Earth objects from NASA's NeoWs API, and processes it through a pipeline of physics modules. These modules calculate the asteroid's kinetic energy, the resulting crater dimensions, the equivalent seismic magnitude (using the Gutenberg-Richter relation), and the radius of the air-blast shockwave based on scientific models from papers like Collins et al. (2005). The backend also includes an endpoint to simulate a kinetic impactor mitigation mission.
  • Frontend: A dynamic, interactive interface built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript (using jQuery, Leaflet, Bootstrap, D3 and TreeJS) provides the user experience. Users can either select a real asteroid from a searchable list or customize a theoretical impactor using sliders for mass, diameter, and velocity. They can then choose an impact point by dragging and dropping an icon onto an interactive world map, triggering the simulation and visualizing the results.

The primary benefit of our project is its educational power. It demystifies the complex science of asteroid impacts, making the abstract threat tangible and accessible to a broad audience, from students to policymakers. By transforming raw scientific data into clear visual outputsâ€”such as concentric circles for the crater and shockwave on a mapâ€”the tool effectively communicates the scale of a potential disaster.

The intended impact is threefold:

  1. Raise Public Awareness: To foster a greater public understanding of the real, albeit low-probability, risk of an asteroid impact.
  2. Support Decision-Making: To provide a "what-if" sandbox where users can explore the consequences of an impact in a specific location, highlighting the need for and effectiveness of planetary defense.
  3. Inspire Interest in Science: To create an engaging, hands-on experience that encourages exploration and learning in the fields of physics, geology, and planetary science.

Tools, Languages, and Software

  • Backend:
    • Languages: Python
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Flask (for the web server), Flasgger (for OpenAPI/Swagger documentation), SQLAlchemy (for caching), python-dotenv (for environment management).
    • Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
    • Frameworks/Libraries: Bootstrap (for styling and layout), jQuery (for DOM manipulation), Leaflet (for the interactive 2D map), D3.js and Three.js (for dynamic data visualizations and 3D rendering).
    • Version Control: Git, GitHub
    • IDE: Visual Studio Code
    • Deployment/Tunneling: ngrok (for development and sharing).

The project's creativity lies in its transformation of static scientific research into a dynamic, hands-on learning experience. Instead of reading a complex paper, a user can directly engage with the physics. The combination of a searchable database of real asteroids with fully customizable "what-if" scenarios provides both realism and creative freedom. The drag-and-drop interface for selecting an impact location is an intuitive and engaging method that immediately connects the simulation to a familiar geographical context, making the results far more personal and impactful.

Factors Considered

Our team prioritized several key factors during development:

  • Scientific Accuracy: We based our core calculations on peer-reviewed scientific literature, specifically the models presented by Collins, Melosh, & Marcus (2005) for impact effects and the Gutenberg-Richter relation for seismic magnitude. We made simplifications where necessary for the hackathon but always started from an established scientific basis.
  • User Experience (UX): We focused on creating an intuitive interface. The use of sliders for input, real-time calculation feedback, and clear visual outputs on a map were all deliberate choices to make the tool easy and engaging to use without prior scientific knowledge.
  • Modularity and Scalability: The backend was designed with a clear separation of concerns (data fetching, energetics, cratering, effects), making the code easier to manage, test, and extend in the future.
  • Team Collaboration: We utilized a feature-branching workflow in Git to allow for parallel development on the frontend and various backend modules, which was critical for making significant progress in a short amount of time.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
We utilized Google's Gemini, ass an AI-powered tutor, and technical consultant throughout the hackathon. The AI's role was to accelerate development and assist in overcoming technical challenges, allowing our team to focus on the project's vision, design, and scientific integration.

Specifically, AI was used in the following areas:

  • Conceptualization and Scientific Modeling: Assisting in the interpretation of the project's scientific documents, explaining complex physics concepts (such as kinetic energy, overpressure, and NAT loopback), and helping select and implement appropriate simplified formulas (like the Gutenberg-Richter relation and cube root scaling for air blasts) for the hackathon's scope.
  • Debugging: Providing real-time assistance in diagnosing and solving a wide range of issues
  • Best Practices and Documentation: Aiding in the formulation of conventional Git commit messages, explaining team collaboration workflows (feature branching), translating code comments, and assisting in the drafting of the final project summaries and descriptions.

All AI-generated code and concepts were reviewed, understood, and integrated by the team members.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

challengeDetails.title: Build a Space Biology Knowledge Engine
challengeDetails.excerpt: Enable a new era of human space exploration! NASA has been performing biology experiments in space for decades, generating a tremendous amount of information that will need to be considered as humans prepare to revisit the Moon and explore Mars. Although this knowledge is publicly available, it can be difficult for potential users to find information that pertains to their specific interests. Your challenge is to build a dynamic dashboard that leverages artificial intelligence (AI), knowledge graphs, and/or other tools to summarize a set of NASA bioscience publications and enables users to explore the impacts and results of the experiments these publications describe. (Earth Science Division)

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)
