projectDetails.name: A.I.M. - Aegis Impact Model
projectDetails.summary: A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) is a visualization and predictive system designed to simulate and analyze scenarios in which celestial bodies collide with Earth. The platform leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate analytical reports based on the selected impact location, detailing instantaneous, economic, and environmental consequences, as well as physical parameters such as released energy and impact radius. Users can fully customize meteor parameters, including composition, diameter (0â€“100 km), velocity, and impact angle, enabling the exploration of a wide range of collision scenarios across different regions of the planet. The project aims to serve as both a scientific and exploratory tool, providing a dynamic environment for impact assessment and educational visualization. Future expanded versions of A.I.M. are envisioned to incorporate pre-impact prediction and post-impact analysis, creating a comprehensive framework for understanding and modeling the complete lifecycle of meteor events.
projectDetails.details:
INTRODUCTION

According to the Statistical Discovery Report from the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies (CNEOS), nearly 40,000 Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) have been discovered to date. With a significant number of these bodies passing close to Earth, and with recorded impact events such as the Chelyabinsk Event (2013), the study and prediction of potential impact scenarios are of critical importance. Accurate forecasting of such events has the potential to mitigate risks and ultimately save lives.

[Image 1 - CNEOS Close Approach Visualization 2025 SY10]

THE NECESSITY

Given the vast number of objects passing near Earth, the probability of collisions with our planet remains a significant parameter to consider. Through the use of advanced computational and analytical technologies, predicting all possible impact scenarios based on an asteroidâ€™s physical composition and trajectory becomes an invaluable approach to mitigating potential threats.

From an educational perspective, such a tool could serve as an exceptional resource for academic research, classroom studies, and scientific outreach, enhancing understanding of celestial dynamics and planetary defense.

THE SOLUTION

Powered by artificial intelligence, A.I.M. can generate a comprehensive range of statistical and analytical data that may assist governmental and environmental agencies in mitigating the environmental, economic, and social impacts of potential meteor events within a given region.

[Image 2 - A.I.M.'s Main Screen]

Beyond its scientific applications, the system also serves as a valuable educational platform for universities, schools, and research institutions, expanding knowledge about asteroids while enabling users to simulate and analyze real-world problem-solving scenarios.

[Image 3 - A.I.M.'s Config Screen]

The DEMO version of A.I.M. allows for full customization of meteor parameters, supporting diameters of up to 100 kilometers, thereby encompassing not only minor but also catastrophic impact scenarios. It features an interactive 3D visualization of the Earth, providing a highly immersive simulation experience.

For the development of this DEMO, Gemini 2.5 Flash was employed to process and interpret data based on the user-selected impact location, ensuring accuracy and dynamic adaptation of simulated conditions.

[Image 4 - A.I.M.'s DEMO A.I. Report]

TECHNOLOGIES UTILIZED

The A.I.M. system integrates AI-powered and map visualization APIs, while maintaining a lightweight core architecture built primarily with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. These core technologies handle the rendering, styling, and mathematical computations required to visualize impact radius and released energy based on the meteorâ€™s defined parameters.

The web application is deployed on Vercel and fully integrated with GitHub for continuous development and version control. Its core logic is implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, while external APIs including Gemini 2.5 Flash for AI-driven data interpretation and Mapbox for geospatial visualization extend its analytical and interactive capabilities.

[Image 5 - Application Architeture Diagram]

Future Improvements

  • Advanced AI Integration: Implement more sophisticated AI models to generate highly detailed and statistically accurate reports, including graphical visualizations, data tables, and potentially proposed mitigation strategies for different impact scenarios.
  • Integration of a Meteor Database: Incorporate a database of scientifically catalogued meteors to enhance simulation realism and expand configuration parameters, allowing users to analyze real-world impact cases with precise physical data.
  • Enhanced Map Data Visualization: Enrich the map interface with additional environmental and physical data, such as detailed information about the impact radius, shockwave propagation, tsunami generation, and seismic activity associated with the simulated event.

Conclusion

The A.I.M. (Aegis Impact Model) serves as a foundational step toward the development of a modular and comprehensive system for the prediction and simulation of meteor impacts. Designed as both a scientific and educational tool, it aims to democratize access to impact analyses and case studies, allowing users from various fields to explore the potential consequences of celestial collisions in an interactive and data-driven environment.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
During the development of this project, artificial intelligence played a key role in several areas:

  • Report Generation: The Gemini 2.5 Flash API served as an essential tool for producing predictive reports based on the user-selected impact location, providing detailed analyses of potential consequences.
  • Content Review and Ideation: ChatGPT 5.0 contributed to textual review, refinement, and idea generation, supporting the projectâ€™s conceptual development and enhancing the clarity and quality of documentation.

projectDetails.name: Project EcoPulse
projectDetails.summary:
Our project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in UberlÃ¢ndia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure that are sensitive to extreme climate variations. The lack of accessible healthcare facilities and the worsening of health conditions due to climate change are critical challenges. To mitigate these problems, we propose an integrated system that involves the distribution of smart watches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices, which measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygenation, and detect falls, help prevent serious complications and enable rapid intervention. In case of anomalies, the watch sends an alert via radio waves to the healthcare system, triggering mobile health stations.
These mobile stations will be deployed seasonally to the regions most in need, based on detailed data on climate and extreme environmental conditions, such as air quality, extreme temperatures, and other climatic factors. This ensures that medical care is optimized for areas at greatest risk of health problems due to climatic conditions. In addition, the clocks will be made from recyclable materials, promoting the city's sustainability. The system aims not only to improve the efficiency of medical care, but also to offer a response tailored to the needs of each community, preventing health complications and ensuring rapid action when most needed.
projectDetails.details:
EcoPulse â€“ Project Documentation

1.0 About our Project

1.1 What It Does

The project aims to improve access to healthcare and promote sustainability in UberlÃ¢ndia, focusing on vulnerable areas with limited infrastructure and sensitivity to extreme climate variations.

1.2 How It Works

The system is integrated and involves the distribution of smartwatches to monitor the health of vulnerable populations. These devices measure blood pressure, heart rate, blood oxygen levels, and detect falls. In case of anomalies, the watches send alerts via radio waves to the healthcare system, activating mobile units.

1.3 Benefits

  • Prevention of serious complications through continuous monitoring.

  • Rapid and efficient response with deployment of mobile units.

  • Improved healthcare management and reduced hospital overload.

1.4 Intention

  • Promote sustainability by using recyclable materials in the manufacture of the watches.

  • Ensure efficiency and inclusion in medical care, prioritizing vulnerable populations.

1.5 Impacts

  • Facilitated access to healthcare in regions with limited infrastructure.

  • Encouragement of sustainability through eco-friendly materials.

  • Reduction of severe medical emergencies and social inequality.

1.6 Considered Factors

  • Social vulnerability and extreme climatic conditions (air quality, temperature, rainfall).

  • Seasonal allocation of mobile units based on climate and environmental data.

2.0 Mobile Units â€“ Improvement

Mobile health units, implemented through adapted vans, already exist in UberlÃ¢ndia, but the proposal is to enhance this infrastructure, making it more efficient in serving vulnerable communities.

2.1 Functioning and Integration

When the watch detects an anomaly, it automatically sends an alert to the healthcare system. The nearest van is dispatched, receiving the data and navigating to the location with real-time information.

2.2 Seasonality and Planning

The distribution of vans will be optimized according to climate risks, such as heat waves and increased pollution, ensuring strategic deployment.

2.3 Equipment and Training

Vans will be equipped with full medical kits, direct communication with hospitals, and trained personnel, ensuring integrated healthcare delivery.

2.4 Benefits for the Community

This enhancement transforms mobile units into continuous connection points between citizens and the healthcare system, preventing severe emergencies and improving service efficiency.

3.0 Links Used and Applications

3.1 Copernicus â€“ UCDB 2024 Visual

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

  • Socioeconomic: Life expectancy increased from 2000-2015 but decreased from 2015-2020, highlighting the challenge of maintaining a healthy and sustainable city.
  • Danger and Risk: Increased risks from 2014-2016, mainly linked to heat waves affecting cardiovascular and respiratory health, potentially causing fainting.
  • Climate: Average annual temperature increased 2.5Â°C (1970-2010) with projections until 2030, showing the direct impact of climate change on health.
  • Emissions: Increase in pollutant and COâ‚‚ emissions (1975-2020), intensifying the greenhouse effect and respiratory diseases.
  • Healthcare: Average of 6 hospitals per 100,000 inhabitants in UberlÃ¢ndia (approx. 42 for 760,000 inhabitants), low considering demand.



  • Access: Between 300,000â€“400,000 people live more than 1 km from a hospital, evidencing difficulty of access in vulnerable areas.

3.2 GHSL â€“ Global Human Settlement Layer

European Union (EU) Copernicus Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)

Â Used to identify vulnerable suburban zones (in yellow), essential for planning mobile unit distribution.

3.3 INPE â€“ Map Catalog

Brazilian Space Research Institute (INPE) Catalogue

Geographic database for evaluating regions of UberlÃ¢ndia, supporting mapping of social and environmental vulnerabilities.

4.0 WebSite Link

https://missaohorizonte.github.io/EcoPulse/MissaoHorizonte/index.html

projectDetails.details:
Project Details

AstroUQuest is an educational game designed to make learning about space fun, interactive, and engaging for children. The game works through quizzes, challenges, and rewards, allowing players to explore the universe while earning official NASA Space UberlÃ¢ndia 2025 certificates.

Benefits and Impact:

  • Encourages curiosity and learning about science and space.
  • Provides an interactive, gamified experience to enhance understanding.
  • Inspires the next generation of space explorers.

  • Programming Languages: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
  • Design & UX: Figma, Canva

Creativity and Considerations:
The project combines education, gamification, and visual storytelling. The team focused on accessibility, engagement, and fostering curiosity, ensuring that children of different ages could enjoy and learn from the game.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: Nexonull
node.excerpt: Building Stories

projectDetails.name: The Day the Sun Messed with Everything.
projectDetails.summary:
Our project, â€œThe Day the Sun Messed with Everything,â€ is an educational illustrated story designed to explain the effects of solar activity on everyday life in a simple and engaging way. We developed a narrative that follows different characters â€” a farmer, a pilot, an astronaut, an engineer, and a child â€” all experiencing the impacts of a solar storm from their unique perspectives.

The project addresses the challenge of making complex scientific phenomena, like solar flares and geomagnetic storms, accessible to children and the general public. By connecting these events to relatable daily situations, readers can better understand how solar energy influences technology, communication, and life on Earth.

This is important because increasing awareness of space weather helps people appreciate the Sunâ€™s power and the importance of science in predicting and protecting our planet from its effects.
projectDetails.details:
Our project, â€œThe Day the Sun Messed with Everything,â€ is an interactive educational story that demonstrates how solar activity can affect life on Earth. It works by combining storytelling, visual illustrations, and science communication to explain complex phenomena â€” such as solar flares, magnetic storms, and their effects on satellites, communication systems, and power grids â€” in a way that is accessible to all ages, especially children.

The main benefit of this project is its ability to transform scientific knowledge into an engaging learning experience. Readers gain awareness of the importance of solar observation and space weather research, while also developing curiosity about science, technology, and environmental awareness.

The intended impact is to promote scientific literacy and help communities understand how solar energy influences everyday technologies â€” from airplanes and electricity to GPS and internet systems.

We developed the project using Canva for graphic design. The creativity lies in the fusion of storytelling and real-world science â€” turning a potential global issue into an inspiring, easy-to-understand narrative.

Our team considered clarity, age-appropriate language, cultural inclusivity, and scientific accuracy to ensure the story educates, entertains, and empowers readers to appreciate the Sunâ€™s vital role in our lives.

Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital childrenâ€™s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. node.title: Orbital Token Market
node.excerpt: Inicio.

projectDetails.name: Project Orbital Token Market
projectDetails.summary:
We developed Orbital Token Market, a groundbreaking platform that bridges the real economy of space with blockchain technology, enabling a new era of accessibility and transparency in orbital infrastructure. Our mission is to transform orbital capacity into liquid, tradeable, and accessible assets through tokenization. By registering satellites and converting their available service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, we create a secure marketplace where companies can monetize unused orbital time, and investors can directly participate in the space economy with clarity and confidence.

The platform provides tools for satellite scheduling, token management, and the creation of investment pools that finance new space projects. Each available satellite hour is tokenized into a digital asset, which can be purchased, traded, or allocated. When the service is consumed, the token is burned, ensuring efficiency, scarcity, and a continuous operational flow. This system establishes a dynamic and sustainable cycle, connecting enterprises, investors, and researchers.

Our platform democratizes space because it makes the next frontier accessible, transparent, and collaborative. Any researcher, company, or individual anywhere in the world can rent satellite time using cryptocurrency tokens, making access to orbital infrastructure no longer restricted to governments or large corporations. Addressing the critical challenge of opening the space economy to global participation.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?


Orbital Token Market is a blockchain-based platform that transforms orbital capacity into liquid and accessible assets. By registering satellites, we convert available service hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens. These tokens can be purchased, traded, or allocated by companies, researchers, or individuals anywhere in the world. When satellite time is used, the token is burned, ensuring transparency, efficiency, and a continuous cycle.

Benefits and intended impact
The Orbital Token Market delivers tangible value across multiple sectors of society by transforming orbital capacity into an accessible, tradeable asset.

For space companies, the platform offers a new revenue stream by enabling them to monetize unused orbital time. Instead of idle satellite capacity going to waste, companies can convert it into tokenized service hours, improving operational efficiency, generating recurring income, and attracting new customers from around the world. This creates financial sustainability for satellite operators and incentivizes the development of additional infrastructure.

For investors, the model provides direct exposure to the real space economy, which has traditionally been closed to individuals or limited to large institutional players. Through tokenization, investors can diversify their portfolios with Real World Asset (RWA) tokens backed by orbital services, receiving transparent and verifiable returns. This democratizes access to one of the fastest-growing industries of the 21st century.

For researchers and academic institutions, the platform removes cost and logistical barriers. By renting satellite hours directly with cryptocurrency tokens, they can conduct experiments, gather Earth observation data, or test communications systems without requiring massive budgets or government-level partnerships. This accelerates scientific discovery and innovation.

For entrepreneurs and startups, the system creates opportunities to build new businesses on top of orbital servicesâ€”whether in communications, climate solutions, agriculture analytics, or IoT networks. Accessing satellite capacity through tokenized assets reduces entry costs and fosters innovation.

For ordinary individuals, the project represents the first time that people from anywhere in the world can meaningfully participate in the space economy. Anyone can acquire a fraction of orbital capacity, rent it for personal or community projects, or hold tokens as part of a transparent, blockchain-based ecosystem.

The intended impact of the Orbital Token Market is to reduce barriers to entry, create sustainable funding for new satellites, and foster a collaborative global ecosystem. By aligning the incentives of companies, investors, researchers, and individuals, the platform not only expands access to space but also strengthens its role as a shared resource for humanity.

Tools and creativity
We use Hedera blockchain, smart contracts (Solidity), token management systems, scheduling interfaces, and cloud infrastructure to ensure scalability and reliability of services. We already have a functional prototype available at orbitaltokenmarket.com, and our smart contract is deployed on the Hedera Testnet (hashscan.io/testnet/contract/0.0.6854902/source), fully prepared to move into production. We also integrate Laravel technology for robust backend management and user-friendly web applications.

A core innovation of our project is the introduction of Real World Assets (RWA) tokenization into the space economy. In our model, each satellite service hour becomes a digital tokenized asset that represents a tangible share of orbital capacity. These RWA tokens can be traded, purchased, or allocated in a transparent and efficient way, providing liquidity to previously inaccessible infrastructure. Once the service is consumed, the token is burned, ensuring a continuous and verifiable economic cycle.

This approach enables satellite-owning companies to monetize unused orbital time, while researchers, individuals, and organizations can rent satellite hours directly using cryptocurrency tokens. Investors, in turn, gain direct access to recurring revenue streams tied to real space operations, something that was once limited to governments or large corporations.

The projectâ€™s creativity lies in combining DeFi principles with RWA tokenization of orbital infrastructure, creating a unique marketplace where finance, technology, and space converge. By bridging blockchain with space assets, Orbital Token Market introduces a sustainable and scalable economic model that democratizes access to low Earth orbit and fosters collaboration among companies, investors, and innovators.

Scalability
The model scales naturally as more satellites are registered on the platform, creating a growing ecosystem of orbital services. Each new satellite adds capacity and diversity, enabling the marketplace to expand into a wide range of applications such as advanced Earth observation for climate monitoring and disaster response, global communications networks that bridge underserved regions, high-precision navigation systems for transportation and logistics, and even in-space manufacturing of advanced materials, pharmaceuticals, and components that cannot be produced under Earthâ€™s gravity. Looking further ahead, the same model could support sustainable space tourism platforms, where access to orbital infrastructure is allocated transparently through tokenized assets.

By tokenizing satellite hours into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, the model creates true liquidity for orbital capacity, transforming what was once an illiquid and inaccessible resource into a globally tradeable asset class. Tokenization not only ensures flexibility to meet dynamic global demand, but also enables fractional ownership and usage, allowing individuals, startups, and research institutions to access orbital resources previously available only to governments or large corporations. This scalability drives both the growth of the space economy and the democratization of access to space, establishing Orbital Token Market as a foundation for the next generation of space-enabled services.

Sustainability
We emphasize responsible orbital operations by collaborating with agencies and companies on debris mitigation strategies and long-term end-of-life satellite management. Our roadmap includes incentives for operators who follow sustainable practices and recycling strategies for decommissioned assets.

Resilient infrastructure
We plan to integrate resilient satellite architectures capable of handling LEO challenges such as radiation, thermal cycles, and debris impact. This includes adopting modular components and adaptive scheduling for redundancy.

Cost-effectiveness
Beyond launch, the model addresses ongoing operational costs by distributing them across token holders, creating investment pools that fund maintenance, upgrades, and new deployments.

Regulatory landscape and international cooperation
We acknowledge the complexity of national and international space laws. Our model evolves in compliance with licensing frameworks, while partnerships with international agencies and organizations strengthen global trust.

Profitability and responsibility
We aim to balance financial returns with ethics and environmental sustainability by aligning investor rewards with responsible orbital practices. Transparency and accountability are at the core of our model.

Innovation
Orbital Token Market introduces an entirely new asset class: tokenized satellite service time. By converting orbital capacity into Real World Asset (RWA) tokens, the platform transforms something once accessible only to governments and large corporations into a liquid, tradeable resource for the global community.

This innovative approach lowers financial and technical barriers, enabling participation from startups, researchers, investors, and even individuals. It opens the door to entirely new marketsâ€”ranging from precision agriculture and climate monitoring to secure communications, advanced Earth observation, and in-space manufacturing. Each of these sectors can now access orbital infrastructure in a fractional, transparent, and flexible way.

Beyond market creation, the platform also promotes collaboration across industries by aligning the incentives of space companies, investors, researchers, and innovators. It establishes a bridge between blockchain and the space economy, where decentralized finance (DeFi) mechanisms fuel real-world orbital infrastructure.

In essence, the Orbital Token Market is not just innovating in finance or space, it is pioneering a new economic model where blockchain technology, orbital assets, and global accessibility converge, laying the foundation for a sustainable and inclusive space economy.

Prototyping
We already have a functional prototype: the website orbitaltokenmarket.com enables token management, purchases, and satellite hour scheduling. In addition, our smart contract is already deployed on the Hedera Testnet, available for audit here: hashscan.io/testnet/contract/0.0.6854902/source. This prototype effectively demonstrates the feasibility and innovation of our model.

node.title: Plastic Busters
node.excerpt: Sou Gustavo Kim, apaixonado por ciÃªncia e tecnologia. E quero explorar o poder dos fungos contra o plÃ¡stico.Busco pessoas criativas

projectDetails.name: Project Plastic Busters
projectDetails.summary:
Plastics exhibit high resistance to natural degradation, with a half-life that can exceed 600 years depending on their polymeric composition. This persistence poses a significant environmental challenge, as plastics gradually fragment into smaller particles known as microplastics, which display high stability and potential toxicity to living organisms. Recent studies have reported the presence of microplastics in fish and even in human tissues, underscoring the extent of environmental and biological contamination.
Given this global issue of plastic pollution, the development of sustainable and science-based solutions is imperative. Several fungal species have demonstrated notable efficiency in degrading synthetic polymers under optimal conditions, particularly those belonging to the genera Aspergillus, Pestalotiopsis microspora, Zalerion maritimum, Penicillium spp., and Fusarium spp.
This project aims to advance this field of study by employing artificial intelligence tools to identify and assess, on a global scale, environments with favorable conditions for fungal-mediated plastic biodegradation, thereby enhancing bioremediation strategies and promoting environmental sustainability.
projectDetails.details:
This environmental pollution icontinues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this project can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.
The front-end development was structured based on modular architecture best practices in Python, prioritizing scalability and code clarity. The Streamlit library served as the core of the interface, chosen for its ability to integrate interactive components, dynamic visualizations, and scientific APIs with minimal development overhead.
Communication between the interfaces and backend modules (such as ml_model.py, correlation.py, and data_loader.py) occurs through direct function calls, ensuring an optimized data flow. The interactive map was implemented using Folium and streamlit-folium, incorporating layers from NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services) to render satellite imagery, allowing users to explore environmental variables such as air quality and altitude.
The Analytical Dashboard was developed with Plotly Express and Matplotlib, displaying performance indicators of fungal activity in the decomposition of different types of polymers. The Predictor module integrates with a machine learning model, providing forecasts of fungal colony behavior when exposed to specific plastic types, based on data stored in an SQLite (.db) database.
The input layer (modules â€œInsert Plasticâ€ and â€œInsert Fungusâ€) was designed to automatically feed data into the database, including field validation and direct integration with analytical routines. The entire application was developed with a focus on usability, efficiency, and digital sustainability, applying the principles of Green Computing within the environmental and scientific scope of the Plastic Busters project.
This pollution continues to increase every day, and while the only current remediation is the use of alternative products, there is still no solution for all the existing pollution. Once developed, this AI can greatly assist in combating plastic pollution. The greatest challenge is creating a sustainable world, and using fungi to degrade plastic, even in inhospitable environments, could be the path to the future.

projectDetails.name: Fire Alert: World Edition
projectDetails.summary: We developed a wildfire monitoring system using real-time data from NASA satellites through the FIRMS platform. The system collects and analyzes data such as geographical coordinates, fire intensity, and detection reliability, calculating the distance to points of interest and classifying fire hotspots by intensity and risk. Additionally, the system displays real-time alerts on a web interface and allows user interaction. Based on the same concept, we created a game, Fire Alert: World Edition, to encourage wildfire fighting in a simple and interactive way. Both projects aim to improve early detection and rapid response to wildfires, contributing to the protection of ecosystems, communities, and facilitating the planning of preventive actions. The importance of these systems lies in creating effective tools for continuous monitoring and raising public awareness about the severity of wildfires.
projectDetails.details:
System Description

The system uses real-time data from NASA satellites through FIRMS. Each satellite provides information on fire hotspots, including geographical coordinates, fire power (FRP), acquisition time and date, and detection confidence level. To access the database, the system uses the Map Key provided by NASA, ensuring authentication and authorized access.

Programming and Processes

The program is written in Python, utilizing libraries such as pandas and numpy for data manipulation and analysis, and requests for HTTP requests.
It performs the following processes:

  • Generation of an area of interest (bounding box) based on the latitude, longitude, and radius provided by the user;
  • Collection of satellite data for the past N days;
  • Conversion and standardization of essential columns: latitude, longitude, FRP, intensity, reliability, risk, and distance;
  • Calculation of the distance between each hotspot and the point of interest using the Haversine formula;
  • Classification of intensity (Low, Moderate, High), reliability (>40%), and risk (Medium, High);
  • Sorting and filtering of data to display only reliable hotspots near the monitored point.

Artificial Intelligence Collaboration

Initially, the AI helped create a basic version capable of querying fire hotspots near a coordinate by making requests to the NASA FIRMS API, filtering the data by reliability, and calculating the distance to the central point.
Based on user feedback, the AI then suggested parameter adjustments, increasing the alert radius, and adding different confidence levels, making the code more flexible.

In later stages, the AI guided the introduction of multiple satellites, vectorization with NumPy to improve performance, handling missing data, and the creation of additional metrics such as fire intensity and risk based on reliability.
Enhancements were also made to the presentation of results, such as sorting by proximity, formatting timestamps, and centering tables, always following the user's instructions to make the output clearer and more understandable.

Finally, the AI assisted in implementing user interactivity and the bilingual translation of the script, maintaining all previous functionalities.
Each design decision, each function addition, or logic adjustment was made based on conversations, demonstrating how artificial intelligence can be used to guide and structure the development of a complete project in a collaborative manner.

Data Presentation and Interface

The processed data is transformed into centered tables with clear headers and professional alignment, making quick interpretation easier.
The web interface provides real-time alert visualization, including geographic location, fire intensity, data reliability, risk, and distance from the monitored point.

System Benefits

The system's benefits come from early detection of fire hotspots, enabling rapid responses, continuous and reliable monitoring based on official NASA data, risk assessment based on quantitative and qualitative variables, public availability for managers, companies, and communities, expanding prevention efforts, and potential future integration with emergency response systems.

Project Objectives and Impact

The project aims to significantly reduce damage caused by fires, protect ecosystems and human communities, increase decision-making efficiency for environmental agencies and private companies, and create business opportunities through the public monitoring platform.
Additionally, it contributes to environmental research and provides reliable data for prevention policies and territorial planning.

Educational Expansion

Moreover, based on the same programming concept, we developed a game called Fire Alert: World Edition.
The goal of the game is to encourage global firefighting efforts in an interactive and simple way.

Game Description

The game presents a world map in which the players assume the role of firefighters responsible for extinguishing fires in different regions.
Two types of events are displayed on the map:

  • Real fires, represented by a flame icon;
  • False alerts, represented by a red triangle containing an exclamation mark and the letter â€œF.â€

The map is covered with these symbols. False alerts must not be clicked, as doing so results in a deduction of 5 points. Conversely, real fires must be clicked, representing the act of extinguishing the fire; each correct action adds 10 points to the playerâ€™s score.

At the beginning of the game, the initial score is set at 25 points.
Each successfully extinguished fire awards 10 points, while each mistakenly selected false alert deducts 5 points.
The game concludes when the score reaches zero.

Programming and Mechanics

The game was developed using the Scratch platform, employing programming blocks that perform the following functions:

  • Define and update the score according to the playerâ€™s actions;
  • Control time through a timer that counts up to five seconds before restarting;
  • Utilize a custom block named â€œcoordinatesâ€, responsible for moving the sprites to random positions on the map;
  • Switch the backdrop between the World Map and a black screen (Game Over) according to the gameâ€™s progression.

The system includes five false alerts and five fires, distributed across the continents and relocated every five seconds.
In addition, â€œStartâ€ and â€œPlay Againâ€ buttons were programmed to initialize and restart the game, respectively.

Mathematical Logic

The gameâ€™s functionality is grounded in computational logic and mathematical calculations, which define the coordinates and timing of each event.
These operations ensure that all movements and interactions occur with accuracy, consistency, and precision.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
The development of the code was entirely based on conversations with an artificial intelligence, using ChatGPT as a programming assistant. With each version, the code evolved from suggestions, adjustments, and explanations provided by the model, which interpreted the user's commands and objectives and transformed these instructions into practical implementations.

We also used ChatGPT to translate the texts from Portuguese to English.

projectDetails.name: External Support Structure (ESTU)
projectDetails.summary: Our project aims to tackle one of humanity's greatest challenges: the waste of essential resources. The proposal is to optimize the use of materials during a space mission to Mars, utilizing waste generated throughout the process. The mission, lasting about three years, inevitably generates waste. Our solution consists of repurposing materials that would be discarded by constructing external structures to the habitat. The ESTU (External Support Structure), as it is called, Our project aims to reduce waste, ensuring greater efficiency in resource use. In a world where space exploration is growing exponentially, it is necessary to establish ways to prevent the increase of waste in space, thus solidifying humanity's commitment to sustainability in the cosmos.
projectDetails.details:
External Support Structure (ESTU)

ESTRUTURA EXTERNA DE APOIO

our website: https://ingryd-julia.github.io/reorbit6/NASA.html

PROPOSAL: An External Support Structure (ESTU) is a structure built outside the astronauts' habitat that can be used for various purposes, including workshop and storage (the use will depend on the astronauts' needs and available resources). The ESTU was developed for the useful utilization of the three-dimensional cubic structure, material recycled after the inflatable habitat is inflated and secured, to create a new space that serves as support for astronauts to perform tasks, missions, and life in space more efficiently and sustainably.

Workshop - A suitable place for the development of tools and materials using or not using recyclable resources. The workshop will be built in a way that promotes the creation and artisanal development with workbenches, support tables, and spaces for organizing tools.

Warehouse - A suitable place for the storage of any materials developed or brought from Earth that are not essential in the astronauts' habitat for the economy and optimization of astronauts' spaces. The location should be constructed in such a way that the mentioned storage structures are prioritized.

WASTE: Temporary aluminum structure of the inflatable habitat, clothing waste, floor cloths/plates, food packaging (containing aluminum and polyethylene), bubble wrap, packing foam, air cushions for packing, empty CTBs, used PMC plates in packaging, Martian regolith (not waste, but used).

  • Structure - rearranged aluminum from the temporary three-dimensional cubic structure of the inflatable habitat:

(We estimated around 2.6m (3,3 feet) in height at the highest point of the cabin, since it is made with the support poles from the habitat.{ Maybe it will be taller.})

  • Cloth (see below)

PROPOSAL: Multi-purpose protective cloth developed from recyclable material that will be used for external protection of ESTU and other activities, for example:

a) to be used as a floor for the ESTU as well;

b) protect materials added outside the astronauts' habitat and the ESTU as equipment if necessary;

c) can be used as extra protection for astronauts due to its thermal properties and protection against dust and other environmental elements;

Important: the uses of the tarpaulin are unlimited and can vary according to the team's needs.

The original tarp has three layers, designed to form an effective protection.

1. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile environment of Mars, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. The outermost layer, which will be the most resistant layer, will protect the ESTU from the hostile Martian environment, keeping stored materials and astronauts safe. Furthermore, it is the layer that will serve as a barrier against sandstorms, and in the case of using tarps for equipment protection, it is also very important. The materials must be the most resistant ones available.

Materials: aluminum, polyethylene, nylon, polyester. Present in: Food packaging, external packaging, beverage bags, thermal bags, rehydration bags.

How can the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the first layer be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together.

Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gases.

2. The middle layer for thermal insulation and extra protection. For human uses or depending on the intended use of the ESTU, temperature is crucial, which is why this layer is important.

Materials: bubble wrap or air bags. Present in: Various packaging. (in some situations, these materials are the packaging themselves.

How the joining of the packaging/materials for the creation of the second layer can be done: By heating the edges of the plastics to bond them together. Note: this can be done with a tool similar to an iron or a hair straightener.

Important: This heating must be done at a low temperature to avoid releasing any toxic gas.

3. The innermost layer that will serve to structure the tarp, in addition to being the least rigid of the layers. In the case of human use or equipment protection, a material like aluminum (present in the first layer) could cause a lot of discomfort or damage to the integrity of the equipment, which is why the fabric layer is quite useful.

Materials: Fabrics such as cotton, cellulose, nylon, polyester. Present in: clothes, dishcloths, disinfectant wipes.

How can the joining of the fabrics for the creation of the third layer be done: By sewing the fabrics together. This can be done with a kit brought by the astronauts themselves or by using small strips of fabric to tie everything together with knots.

After developing the three layers separately, it is necessary to join them.

Ways to join the three layers of the Cloth:

a) Join layers 1 and 3 in such a way that layer 2 remains firmly in the middle without the need to be fixed. How: Heat the entire edges of the first layer and stick it to the third layer so that the second layer stays in the middle.

b) Join all the layers using tape that ensures secure adhesion (to avoid potential problems with the structure of the tarp)

Important: The structure of the three-layer tarp can be rearranged as needed. For example, it may be necessary to have a tarp made only of fabric, so the astronauts could use three layers made only of fabric.

Proposal for the floor of ESTU: A cloth made only with first-layer materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular containers and tables for storage and project fabrication

Cargo transfer bags (CTB's) - Self-storage bags for space missions and come in various size configurations. After emptying a CTB, its shape is suitable for making simple structures.

Blocks - When filled and compacted with Martian regolith, they can become convenient structural blocks for cladding and structuring. They can also be used as seats and other furniture if their interior is filled with foam and other materials.

PROPOSAL: Modular Tables/Shelves for Storage and Project Development

Polymer Matrix Composites (PMC's) - These are materials composed of a thermoplastic or thermosetting resin matrix coated with a fiber that is substantially more resistant than the matrix. In the case of the PMC provided in the mission, which is made of plastic resin and carbon fiber, we can reuse its hardness and strength to produce workbenches and modular furniture for the developing structure.

(In the example, a PMC top is placed on an aluminum structure, serving both as a table and a shelf.) If all the aluminum has been used in the workshop structure, CTB blocks can also be used as a foundation for such tables.

challengeDetails.title: SpaceTrash Hack: Revolutionizing Recycling on Mars
challengeDetails.excerpt: During a hypothetical three-year mission to Mars and back, an eight-person crew would accumulate 12,600 kg of inorganic waste, or trash, including various packaging materials, textiles, and structural materials. This scenario creates a pressing need to recycle available materials, rather than execute the expensive and inefficient processes of transporting additional resources from Earth and/or sending trash back to Earth. As humans prepare to explore unknown worlds in the future, your challenge is to design sustainable systems that could manage, reuse, or recycle inorganic waste (â€œtrashâ€) that is brought to and/or accumulated on the surface of Mars. (Space Technology Mission Directorate)

node.title: Savoir-faire
node.excerpt: We are a group of 6 friends from the same Computer Science class at UFU (Federal University of UberlÃ¢ndia).

projectDetails.name: Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction Tool (SWAMP Tool)
projectDetails.summary:
We've developed Savoir-Faire SWAMP (Statistical Weather Analysis and Meteorology Prediction), a web application that provides historical meteorological data and statistical analysis to help users estimate the likelihood of specific weather phenomena for a given day and location.

SWAMP it addresses to the challenge because the tool enables users to create a personalized dashboard to view the probability of certain weather conditions (e.g., temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind speed) for a selected time and place.

SWAMP is particularly useful for anyone planning an outdoor event, such as a vacation, a hike, or a fishing trip, as knowing the chances of adverse weather helps in making more informed decisions.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do or how does it work?

Our project is a web application that provides a probabilistic weather forecast based on historical data. Using NASA's POWER API, it gathers 20 years of climate data for a specific location and date. Instead of predicting the weather in real-time, it applies a statistical model based on the Bell Curve (Normal Distribution) to analyze weather patterns within a seven-day window around the chosen date. The result is a forecast that informs the likely intensity of a weather event (like rain), allowing the user to know if the historical pattern points to a drizzle, a heavy storm, or a day with no precipitation.

What benefits does it have?

The main benefit is providing a much more detailed and useful forecast for event planning. While traditional forecasts offer a percentage chance of rain, our tool contextualizes that chance with its probable intensity. This allows users to make more informed decisions: a high probability of a "drizzle" has a very different impact than a high probability of a "storm." Consequently, the project helps manage expectations and prepare more suitable contingency plans for any outdoor activity.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to empower people to plan events with greater confidence by reducing the uncertainty associated with the weather. By providing a historical perspective on what is "normal" for a given week of the year in a specific location, our tool aims to become a reliable resource for event organizers, travelers, and anyone who needs to plan ahead. The ultimate goal is to lessen the stress of planning and increase the success rate of activities that depend on good weather.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

For development, we used a modern, performance-focused stack. The frontend was built with React, Tailwind CSS, Shadcn/ui, and Recharts for data visualization. The backend is an API built in Python with the FastAPI framework, served by Uvicorn and Gunicorn. For data processing, we used the Pandas and NumPy libraries. For optimizations, we employed aiohttp for asynchronous requests to the NASA API, orjson for rapid JSON serialization, and an in-memory cache to speed up responses.

How is your project creative?

Our project's creativity lies in its approach to the problem. Instead of competing with real-time weather forecasts, we shifted the question from "Will it rain?" to "Based on the last 20 years, how does the weather typically behave this week?". The application of a well-established statistical model (the Bell Curve) to generate a forecast of likely intensity, based on a vast set of historical NASA data, is an innovative way to extract practical value and insights for event planningâ€”something that conventional forecasting tools do not offer.

What factors did your team consider?

Our team considered several factors. First, technical feasibility aligned with our skills: we chose a web application challenge because the team has strong full-stack development experience. Second, the quality and availability of data, which led us to select a challenge with rich NASA data sources. Finally, performance and user experience were crucial, guiding our technological choices to ensure the application was fast, responsive, and presented the data clearly and intuitively to the end-user.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
No images, videos, audio, or data were generated with AI.

We used Lovable AI as a kickstart for our frontend development. We provided the tool with our original references, screen mockups, and logo to guide the design process. We also detailed the planned functionality, expected UI behavior, and responsiveness requirements. Based on this input, the AI generated a React prototype that served as the foundation for building our application, kickstarting the initial development. Additionally, we used Gemini Pro as a copilot to refine the code, streamline the process, and ensure the proper use of React features with which we were unfamiliar.

challengeDetails.title: Meteor Madness
challengeDetails.excerpt: A newly identified near-Earth asteroid, "Impactor-2025," poses a potential threat to Earth, but do we have the tools to enable the public and decision makers to understand and mitigate its risks? NASA datasets include information about known asteroids and the United States Geological Survey provides critical information that could enable modeling the effects of asteroid impacts, but this data needs to be integrated to enable effective visualization and decision making. Your challenge is to develop an interactive visualization and simulation tool that uses real data to help users model asteroid impact scenarios, predict consequences, and evaluate potential mitigation strategies. (Planetary Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Space Life Team
projectDetails.summary:
We developed a web platform that allows users to efficiently search and explore NASAâ€™s bioscience publications through an intelligent keyword-based search system. Our tool organizes and filters hundreds of scientific papers, helping researchers quickly locate information relevant to their interests.
At this stage, the project focuses on building a robust and accurate search engine â€” the foundation for future enhancements. Upcoming features will include an AI assistant capable of answering questions based on NASA publications, as well as bibliometric visualizations that reveal relationships, trends, and research gaps.
By creating a structured and scalable platform, our goal is to make NASAâ€™s bioscience data more accessible, interactive, and insightful, empowering scientists and mission planners to accelerate discoveries that support the next era of human space exploration.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details

Our project is an intelligent search platform designed to help users explore NASAâ€™s bioscience publications more efficiently. It focuses on creating a powerful keyword and semantic-based search system that makes navigating hundreds of scientific articles faster and easier.

What it does / How it works

The system processes NASAâ€™s bioscience publication data, cleans and structures the text, and generates vector embeddings using natural language models. These embeddings are stored in a FAISS index to enable fast and semantically meaningful searches.
Through an interactive Streamlit interface, users can type keywords and instantly retrieve the most relevant publications, along with short text excerpts that summarize each result. This allows users to identify useful information without opening every document.

Benefits and Intended Impact

The project significantly reduces the time required to find relevant scientific studies, improves accessibility to NASAâ€™s bioscience data, and supports evidence-based decision-making. By providing a strong foundation for future featuresâ€”such as AI-powered question answering, bibliometric visualizations, and similarity notificationsâ€”it aims to accelerate discoveries that support future lunar and Martian exploration.

Tools and Technologies

We used Python, HuggingFace for text embeddings, FAISS for efficient vector search, and Streamlit for building the interactive web interface. The system architecture was designed for scalability and modularity, ensuring easy integration of future functionalities.

Creativity and Design Considerations

Instead of relying on simple keyword matching, our system uses semantic understanding to connect related ideas across documents. It also includes automatic deduplication and contextual excerpts for a smoother user experience.
Our team focused on performance, scalability, and user accessibilityâ€”creating a clean, intuitive, and expandable foundation for a knowledge exploration tool that bridges science, data, and discovery.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Using embedding and vectorization techniques and stacks to build a vector database, we used HuggingFaceEmbeddings for embedding processing, such as retrieval, document loaders, and FAISS to construct the pipeline.

challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, letâ€™s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earthâ€¦ but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice â€“e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.â€”and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: ET and Lily - Starborn Girls
projectDetails.summary: We present the story â€œET and Lilyâ€, a digital children's book that takes kids and teens on a fun journey to discover what space weather is and how it affects different people on Earth. Using NASA data and accessible explanations, the project offers a solution to the challenge of writing and illustrating a story that explains space weather and its diverse impacts on the people around us and various situations. We believe it is essential for the new generations to learn about scientific topics in a lighthearted way, awakening their curiosity and promoting knowledge. That is why â€œET and Lilyâ€ was created in order to make this knowledge accessible and easily understandable for everyone, encouraging the little curious to be the great scientists of the future.
projectDetails.details:
What does it do and how does it work?

"ET and Lily" is a children's story that begins when an extraterrestrial researcher falls into Lily's backyard, a curious and dreamy girl who has the desire to become a scientist. Together, they embark on a journey to explore Earth and understand how space weather impacts people's lives and even their own.

The story uses data from NASA, as well as additional information from other agencies and images to explain the events that occur in the story in a light and understandable manner for a young and lay audience.Â 

The characters travel to various locations around the world to meet new people who can help them understand more about space weather. In this narrative, they learn about what space weather is and how it impacts farmers, photographers, radio stations, and astronauts by interfering with GPS and radio signals and creating auroras borealis and emitting harmful radiation in space. At the end of the story, there is a direct interaction with the reader, encouraging them to take an interest in scientific events that directly affect the planet, such as space weather, as well as in scientific research and the pursuit of knowledge.

What are the benefits?

The project offers a series of benefits by bringing a story that makes complex concepts and real NASA data be understood in a playful and engaging way, in addition to providing authentic learning without losing the fun tone. The story also captivates and offers reflections on how events that seem so distant actually affect all our lives and the importance of studying them.

What do we hope to achieve?

The story was designed to encourage children to see the world more broadly and understand the relationships between natural phenomena and the daily lives of humanity. We hope that readers develop an interest in science and scientific research and, consequently, let them know more about NASA.

What tools were used?

The development of "ET and Lily" involved various tools and resources to ensure the quality of the content and the effectiveness of the project. Among the tools used are:

  • Canva: For the creation of illustrations and visual designs of the story, in addition to being the platform on which the project was made;
  • Ibis Paint: Creation of the characters and flying saucer;
  • Google: Used to access the scientific information utilized and ensure that the scientific concepts addressed in the story are accurate and truthful;
  • Quillbot: Grammar review and translation.

Factors considered in the project development and why is it creative?

  • Natural curiosity of children: We know that children are naturally curious, and we want to take advantage of this characteristic to engage them with scientific topics.
  • Childlike visual aspects: The characters were hand-drawn to bring a more playful and accessible feel, with the intention of creating an emotional connection with the child audience.
  • Educational approach: The story was constructed to be informative without losing its fun character, with the idea that learning about science should be an enjoyable experience.

projectDetails.name: Through the Stellar Gaze
projectDetails.summary:
For the "Stellar Stories" challenge, I developed "Through the Stellar Gaze," a children's storybook that translates complex NASA science into an educational narrative for early readers. The core of my project is a custom AI agent, configured in Gemini with a curated dataset of NASA's resources on space weather. This agent's ability to be continuously updated with new information makes the storytelling dynamic and endlessly customizable.

This project directly addresses the challenge by creating an accessible story about space weather. Its importance lies in making science relatable. Growing up with a passion for stars, I often felt that scientific knowledge and representation were out of reach. "Through the Stellar Gaze" uses AI to bridge this gap, creating relatable narratives that can inspire the next generation, especially young girls, to see themselves in STEM careers and feel empowered to explore their own scientific curiosity.
projectDetails.details:
At its core, this project is about forging a personal connection between children and science.

"Through the Stellar Gaze" is a children's storybook that brings the science of space weather to life for early readers. It works through a unique, AI-assisted workflow. The project's creative core is a custom AI agent I developed in Gemini Pro, which was trained on a curated dataset of NASA resources (articles, transcripts). This agent was configured with a specific persona: an expert astrophysicist skilled in simplifying complex information.

The true innovation lies in this customizable agent. It serves as a dynamic engine capable of generating new, scientifically-grounded stories and characters on demand. This makes the project a replicable framework for science communication, not just a single story.

The primary benefit is making science accessible and engaging. A key asset of the custom agent is its ability to generate diverse characters, allowing children from all backgrounds, cultures, and identities to see themselves front and center in scientific narratives. Furthermore, the story can be easily adapted into other languages, amplifying its impact to a global audience.

The project addresses a gap I experienced firsthand: a world where scientific wonder wasn't always reflected in the stories available to young people. The AI-powered system behind "Through the Stellar Gaze" was designed specifically to bridge this divide. Its purpose is to craft narratives that are not only educational but also deeply empowering. The ultimate goal is to foster a lasting sense of curiosity and show young minds, particularly girls, that they have a central place in the world of science and exploration.

As a solo participant, every decision during development was guided by the goal of maximizing the project's impact and accessibility. This involved a careful balance of three key factors. The story was designed to be visually engaging and simple enough for early readers to ensure it could reach the widest possible audience. However, this simplicity did not come at the cost of accuracy; a primary goal was to maintain scientific fidelity to the sourced NASA data. Finally, inclusivity and representation were a core consideration, leading to a framework that supports diverse characters to make the world of science feel welcoming to every child.

Tools used:

  • Gemini 2.5 Pro: Used to create the custom AI agent, generate the foundational manuscript, produce all core illustrations, and summarize research data.
  • Canva: Used for the final layout and design of the storybook, cover art, text effects, and presentation materials.
  • Google Drive: Used for sharing the final storybook and presentation.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
My intent for this project was to translate complex NASA data into a scientifically-grounded yet accessible children's book. As a solo participant working within a tight deadline, the originality of my approach was to develop a custom AI collaborator to efficiently manage the project's scope.

The process began by me curating a dedicated knowledge base from NASA's available resources for this challenge. I selected key materials, including scientific articles and video transcripts. Using this information, leveraged Gemini 2.5 Pro to build a custom AI agent with a unique persona: an expert astrophysicist who also shared my skills in communication, art, and storytelling, specifically tasked with transforming complex data into a simple, user-friendly narrative.

The custom "gem" was essential for:

Synthesizing the vast amount of technical information into a foundational manuscript, which then served as the basis for my work. My efforts focused on editing and adapting this AI-generated draft to ensure the final narrative quality and alignment with the project's original intent;

Instructed the AI agent to produce a foundational manuscript for a children's book aimed at an audience of early readers, based on NASA's data that I selected;

Authored the detailed prompts that guided the AI in generating the illustrations, defining specific characteristics for each character and the cover art;

All core illustrations and character designs were generated in Gemini 2.5 Pro based on the detailed prompts. I then used a separate graphic design tool to edit the final book cover and page layouts using these AI-generated assets. To ensure transparency, the original illustrations feature a Gemini watermark in the bottom-right corner;

Additionally, I utilized the AI for a final grammatical and stylistic review of the project's texts, using it strictly as a revision tool not for creation to ensure professional clarity.

projectDetails.name: TARS: Threat Assessment & Response Simulator
projectDetails.summary: Our project, TARS, directly addresses the "Meteor Madness" challenge by creating a robust orbital physics engine to simulate potential asteroid impact scenarios. Using real-time data on Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) from NASA's JPL Small-Body Database API, our system reverse-engineers a potential threat. Instead of merely tracking an existing orbit, TARS calculates the precise starting position and velocity an asteroid, originating from beyond Neptune, would need to guarantee a future collision with Earth. This entire catastrophic trajectory is then visualized in a user-friendly web interface, allowing users to select a real NEO and watch its simulated journey. TARS is a powerful educational and predictive tool that highlights the critical importance of planetary defense by modeling physically plausible worst-case scenarios.
projectDetails.details:
The project is a comprehensive simulation platform designed to model and visualize potential asteroid impact threats to Earth.

  • How it Works: The system is built on a two-part architecture. The backend is a powerful simulation engine written in Python. It pulls data for a selected Near-Earth Object (NEO) from NASA's API, including its estimated size. It then performs a complex calculation, treating the solar system as an n-body problem, to determine a hypothetical starting point in the outer solar system. This starting point is specifically calculated to ensure the NEO's trajectory will eventually intersect with Earth's orbit for a direct impact. The frontend is a web-based interface built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. It runs on a localhost server, which communicates with the backend engine. Users can select a real NEO from a list, and the frontend then dynamically visualizes the NEOâ€™s entire calculated trajectory from the outer solar system to its final impact with Earth.
  • Benefits and Impact: The primary benefit of TARS is its unique "inverse" approach. It serves as an advanced educational tool for demonstrating the complex orbital mechanics that could lead to an impact. For planetary defense researchers, it provides a method to simulate and analyze worst-case scenarios, which is crucial for developing and testing interception strategies. The intended impact is to raise public and scientific awareness of NEO threats by providing a clear, data-driven visualization of what a potential catastrophe could look like.
  • Tools and Creativity: We used Python with the NumPy library for the backend physics calculations and HTML/CSS/JavaScript for the frontend visualization. The project's creativity lies in its reverse-engineering of an impact event. While most tools track existing paths, we calculate a hypothetical but physically accurate path that guarantees an impact, offering a novel perspective on threat assessment.
  • Live Server: This Visual Code Extension was used to run the localhost server.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Declaration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) Use

In the development of our project, Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools were utilized to accelerate innovation and assist in specific technical areas. The core concepts, scientific logic, and overall project direction were driven entirely by human ideation and collaboration among team members. The AI's role was that of a supportive tool, not a primary creator.

Our use of AI can be broken down as follows:

  1. Backend Simulation Engine: The physics engine and core simulation logic were predominantly designed, architected, and coded by our team. AI assistance was employed for targeted tasks, such as debugging minor logical errors, optimizing code snippets for performance, and suggesting alternative algorithmic approaches. The fundamental structure and its scientific integrity are products of human effort.
  2. Front-End Development: Our team did not possess prior expertise in front-end programming. To bridge this skill gap, we utilized AI to help generate the foundational code for the user interface. While the AI assisted in translating our design concepts into functional code, the user experience (UX) flow, visual layout, and all creative decisions were conceived and directed by the team. Human ideas and solutions were paramount, with the AI serving as an implementation tool.
  3. General Debugging and Problem-Solving: Throughout the project, AI was used as a debugging partner to help identify syntax errors and troubleshoot complex issues. This allowed our team to focus more on the high-level logic and creative aspects of the project, rather than getting stalled by minor implementation hurdles.

In all instances, the AI was a tool that followed human guidance. The solutions, creative direction, and the very intent behind our project were the result of our team's original thoughts and collaborative work.

projectDetails.name: Shark Predictor
projectDetails.summary: We developed Shark Predictor, a data-driven application that directly addresses the "Sharks from Space" challenge. Our solution integrates diverse satellite data from NASA and Copernicus Marine Service, including sea surface temperature, chlorophyll concentration, and ocean currents. Using a machine learning model, the application analyzes these factors to predict the probability and type of shark presence in any given marine location, complete with a risk assessment for human populations. This project is vital as it translates complex Earth observation data into actionable insights for marine conservation, scientific research, and public safety.
projectDetails.details:
Our application provides real-time predictive analysis of shark habitats based on oceanographic data.

HOW IT WORKS
The system workflow is as follows:
1. Input Validation: The application first validates that input coordinates fall within a marine environment, ensuring the model operates in its intended domain.
2. Data Integration: It retrieves multi-source data via APIs, including temperature, currents, and chlorophyll from NASA and ocean depth from Copernicus.
3. ML Prediction: This data is fed into our trained machine learning model to calculate the probability of shark presence, predict potential species, and assess the risk level.
4. Visualization: The results are presented through an intuitive user interface with an interactive map that clearly visualizes high-probability zones and risk levels.

IMPACT & BENEFITS
- Conservation: Enables targeted efforts by identifying critical shark habitats and migration corridors.
- Scientific Research: Provides a powerful tool to study the link between environmental conditions and species distribution.
- Public Safety: Offers proactive risk assessment for coastal communities and responsible ecotourism.

KEY TECHNOLOGIES
- Backend & Machine Learning: Python (Flask, Scikit-learn, Pandas, GeoPandas)
- Frontend & Visualization: JavaScript (Leaflet.js), HTML5, CSS3
- Data Sources: NASA Earthdata (MODIS, OSCAR), Copernicus Marine Service

INNOVATION & STRATEGY
Our core innovation is a purely software-based predictive model that is cost-effective and globally scalable. Unlike systems requiring physical hardware, our application can be deployed instantly in any oceanic region with available satellite data. The ability to fuse diverse datasets to predict not only presence but also species type and risk level represents a significant leap forward in actionable marine intelligence.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team utilized a suite of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools to support and accelerate various phases of the project.

RESEARCH AND CONCEPTUALIZATION
For in-depth research and refining concepts, we leveraged large language models including Google Gemini and GPT to search for technical information and validate ideas.

CODE DEVELOPMENT AND REFINEMENT
AI-powered coding assistants were essential. We employed Manus A.I for initial code generation and refinement. Claude A.I was used for advanced code refinement and correcting complex errors. Additionally, our commented code was reviewed and enhanced by these AIs to improve clarity and maintainability.
PRESENTATION AND DESIGN

We used Prezi AI to assist in the design, layout, and visual structuring of our final presentation slides, helping to communicate our project's story effectively.

PROJECT UTILITIES
We also used Manus A.I for utility tasks, such as organizing and packaging our final project files for submission.

This multi-AI approach allowed our team to work more efficiently, enabling us to focus on the core architectural logic and data integration.

challengeDetails.title: Sharks from Space
challengeDetails.excerpt: Earthâ€™s ocean is one of the most powerful habitats in our universe, supporting a range of life that sustains ecosystems and habitability across the globe. It is common to measure photosynthetic activity in the ocean from space, but far more challenging to track top predators. Your challenge is to create a mathematical framework for identifying sharks and predicting their foraging habitats using NASA satellite data, and also to suggest a new conceptual model of a tag (a small electronic device that can be attached to an animal to track and study its movement) that could measure not only where sharks are, but also what they are eating, and in real time transmit that data back to users to enable development of predictive models. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Tech for good
projectDetails.summary:
Letâ€™s conquer Mars without forgetting those who remain on Earth.
Our project uses NASAâ€™s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability on our planet.
The Tech4Good Platform enables local governments to register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage the distribution of food aid through digital vouchers, replacing centralized cafeterias and food baskets.
This model distributes income within local businesses, reduces urban inequality, and creates a virtuous cycle of economic growth in vulnerable communities.
By turning NASA data into actionable intelligence, we help public managers direct resources precisely where they are most needed â€” promoting social dignity, sustainability, and healthier cities for all.
projectDetails.details:
What it does / How it works:
The Tech4Good Platform transforms NASAâ€™s Earth observation data (MODIS, SMAP, GPM, GLDAS, and VIIRS) into actionable intelligence to identify municipalities with the highest levels of food vulnerability. Local governments register beneficiaries, accredit restaurants, and manage aid distribution through digital vouchers â€” replacing traditional food baskets and centralized cafeterias.

Benefits and Intended Impact:
This approach decentralizes food access, strengthens local economies, reduces inequalities, and ensures that assistance reaches those most in need. The platform increases transparency, reduces waste, and fosters social dignity by creating a sustainable, data-driven food assistance ecosystem.

Tools, Languages, and Software:
The project integrates NASA APIs, Python, GitHub Copilot, and AI tools such as ChatGPT for data processing, indicator modeling, and dashboard visualization. The system uses QR code technology to validate meals and automate payments to local establishments.

Creativity and Design Considerations:
Tech4Good stands out for connecting space data to urban food policy, transforming global insights into local action. The team prioritized sustainability, scalability, and social impact, ensuring that the model can be replicated by municipalities worldwide.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team leveraged AI technologies such as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot to enhance both creativity and technical execution.

  • ChatGPT was used to design the projectâ€™s visual identity (logo and graphics), refine written content, and translate materials from Portuguese to English.
  • GitHub Copilot assisted in building the tool for consuming NASA APIs, calculating vulnerability indicators, and developing the interactive monitoring dashboard.

By combining human insight with AI-powered tools, our team accelerated development, ensured clarity in communication, and delivered a data-driven solution aligned with NASAâ€™s mission to apply space data for social impact.
