projectDetails.name: The Chess Forecasters
projectDetails.summary:
The project is a smart, personalized weather forecasting platform designed to support decisions about outdoor events and everyday activities. It collects weather data from trusted sources like NASA, processes it, and transforms it into detailed forecasts for any location worldwide, using machine learning models to generate actionable recommendations and relevant insights.
The solution automates data collection and processing, enabling on-demand forecasts even for locations poorly covered by traditional services. This helps individuals and organizers make safer and more efficient decisions, reducing risks and optimizing resources. The project is important because it democratizes access to high-quality forecasts, improves the user experience, and makes weather technology accessible and practical for everyone.
projectDetails.details: Our project is a web application developed with Next.js, TypeScript, and Node.js, using Python only to build a supporting API. The API connects to the Distance Matrix to calculate distances and routes and integrates the LLaMA model from Meta, which generates natural language explanations to enhance the user experience. Development was carried out in VSCode, prioritizing a modern and scalable architecture, without the use of visual maps in the interface, instead presenting results in reports and interpretive texts. The goal is to provide a creative solution that combines precise route calculations with intelligent AI-driven analyses, positively impacting academic, logistics, and decision-support applications.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools in several parts of our project. AI assisted us in documentation writing and code correction, helping accelerate the development process. Additionally, we integrated Metaâ€™s LLaMA model into our web application to provide climate explanations, and we used Prophet (Python library) for time series forecasting.

challengeDetails.title: Will It Rain On My Parade?
challengeDetails.excerpt: If youâ€™re planning an outdoor eventâ€”like a vacation, a hike on a trail, or fishing on a lakeâ€”it would be good to know the chances of adverse weather for the time and location you are considering. There are many types of Earth observation data that can provide information on weather conditions for a particular location and day of the year. Your challenge is to construct an app with a personalized interface that enables users to conduct a customized query to tell them the likelihood of â€œvery hot,â€ â€œvery cold,â€ â€œvery windy,â€ â€œvery wet,â€ or â€œvery uncomfortableâ€ conditions for the location and time they specify. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Exoplanet Classifier ML
projectDetails.summary:
We developed an intelligent exoplanet classification system using XGBoost machine learning to automatically distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives from space mission data. Our solution addresses the critical challenge of validating exoplanet candidates by analyzing 24+ astronomical parameters including transit characteristics, stellar properties, and quality flags.

The system features a modern web interface built with Streamlit, offering both individual object analysis and batch processing capabilities. It supports data from multiple NASA missions (Kepler, TESS/TOI, and K2) and provides real-time classification with probability scores.

This tool is crucial for the astronomical community as it accelerates the exoplanet discovery process, reduces manual validation time, and improves accuracy in candidate screening. By automating the classification workflow, researchers can focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations.

The application is deployed online and ready for immediate use by astronomers worldwide, democratizing access to advanced exoplanet classification technology.
projectDetails.details:
**What does it do and how does it work?**

Our Exoplanet Classifier AI is a machine learning system that automatically analyzes astronomical data to distinguish between real exoplanets and false positives. The system processes 24+ observational parameters including orbital periods, transit depths, stellar characteristics, and quality flags from NASA missions. Using XGBoost gradient boosting, it generates probability scores for each candidate, enabling rapid and accurate classification.

**What benefits does it have?**

The system dramatically reduces manual screening time from hours to seconds, improves classification accuracy through consistent machine learning algorithms, and provides standardized validation across different space missions. It democratizes access to advanced classification technology, making it available to researchers worldwide without requiring specialized computational resources.

**What is the intended impact?**

This tool accelerates exoplanet discovery by enabling researchers to focus on the most promising candidates for follow-up observations. It supports the search for potentially habitable worlds and contributes to our understanding of planetary formation and evolution. The system can process thousands of candidates efficiently, potentially leading to new exoplanet discoveries.

**Technical Implementation:**

Built with Python and Streamlit for the web interface, XGBoost for machine learning, and pandas for data processing. The system supports Excel/CSV import, real-time validation, and batch processing. Deployed on Streamlit Cloud for global accessibility with automatic updates via GitHub integration.

**Creative and Innovative Aspects:**

The project combines cutting-edge machine learning with user-friendly design, featuring a space-themed interface with interactive visualizations. We implemented intelligent data validation, dynamic warnings for extreme values, and comprehensive error handling. The system bridges the gap between complex ML algorithms and practical astronomical research.

**Team Considerations:**

We prioritized user experience, data security, and scientific accuracy. The system includes safety warnings about model limitations, protects sensitive training data, and provides comprehensive documentation. We focused on making advanced technology accessible to the broader astronomical community while maintaining professional standards.
projectDetails.aiReferences:
**AI Usage Declaration:**

This project utilized AI tools for documentation and code enhancement purposes only. The core machine learning model, algorithm selection (XGBoost), training process, and scientific methodology were developed independently without AI assistance.

**Specific AI Applications:**

1. **Documentation Generation**: AI was used to translate project documentation from Portuguese to English, including README.md, deployment guides, and user manuals.

2. **Code Comments and Integration**: AI assisted in adding explanatory comments to existing code and making minor integration adjustments for better code readability and maintainability.

3. **Text Enhancement**: AI was used to improve technical writing clarity and structure in documentation files.

**AI Tools Used:**

- ChatGPT/Claude for documentation translation and enhancement

- AI-assisted code commenting for better readability

**Original Work:**

- Complete XGBoost model development and training

- Astronomical data preprocessing and feature engineering

- Streamlit web application development

- Scientific methodology and validation approach

- All core algorithms and machine learning logic

**Compliance:**

All AI-generated content has been reviewed and validated. No NASA branding, logos, or mission identifiers were used in AI-generated content. The scientific integrity and originality of the core project remain intact.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: The of blacks Forun. From the space for your PC
projectDetails.summary: Our project, the of blacks Hub, is a collaborative web forum for space exploration enthusiasts, students, and engineering professionals to share and discuss their space habitat designs.It addresses the challenge by creating a centralized community platform where users can post their own habitat concepts, complete with summaries, key features, and design constraints. The forum allows for peer review and feedback, enabling an iterative and collaborative design process. Members can browse diverse projects, draw inspiration from different approaches to mission scenarios (like Lunar bases or Mars colonies), and engage in discussions that refine their own ideas.This is important because it shifts space habitat design from an isolated exercise to a community-driven effort. The Hub fosters a creative and educational environment, helping to crowdsource innovative solutions and inspire the next generation of space architects by making their work visible and interactive.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details: Habitat Design Hub

What does it do or how does it work?

The Habitat Design Hub is a web-based community forum designed for sharing, discussing, and iterating on space habitat layouts. It functions as a centralized gallery and collaborative workspace for enthusiasts, students, and professionals in the space exploration field.

How it Works:

  1. Discover: Upon visiting the site, users are greeted with a main feed showcasing a variety of habitat design projects. These are presented in a visually engaging card format, each displaying the project's title, creator, and key tags (e.g., "Mars," "Lunar," "Student Project," "Deep Space").
    • Project Title: A catchy name for their habitat.
    • Summary: A 50-200 word overview explaining the concept.
    • Detailed Description: An in-depth look at features, mission parameters (crew size, duration, destination), and design choices.
    • Images/Renders: An option to upload visual aids for their design.
    • Tags: Keywords to categorize their project for easy filtering and searching.
  2. Engage and Collaborate: Users can click on any project to view its dedicated page. Here, they can read the full details and participate in a discussion through a comment section. They can ask questions, offer constructive criticism, suggest improvements, or simply show appreciation with an upvote/like system. This feedback loop is central to the platform's collaborative nature.

What benefits does it have?

  • Centralized Knowledge Base: It consolidates scattered ideas from various platforms into a single, focused hub, creating a rich, searchable database of habitat concepts.
  • Community Feedback and Iteration: Designers receive valuable feedback from a diverse audience, helping them refine and improve their concepts in ways they might not have considered alone.
  • Educational Tool: It serves as a practical, engaging resource for students learning about engineering, design, and space exploration. They can see theoretical concepts applied in creative ways by a global community.
  • Inspiration and Networking: The platform connects like-minded individuals, fostering a community that can inspire new ideas and potential collaborations.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact is to democratize space architecture. We want to lower the barrier to entry for contributing ideas to our future in space. By creating an accessible and collaborative environment, the project aims to:

  • Inspire the Next Generation: Motivate students and hobbyists to pursue STEM fields by giving them a platform to showcase their creativity and engage with professionals.
  • Accelerate Innovation: Crowdsource a wide range of solutions to complex challenges in habitat design, potentially sparking novel ideas that influence real-world missions.
  • Build a Global Community: Foster a vibrant, supportive community passionate about humanity's multi-planetary future, united by the shared goal of designing our home in space.

What tools, coding languages, hardware, or software did you use?

The project is a web application developed with the following technologies:

  • Frontend:
    • Languages: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript
    • The platform is hardware-agnostic. As a web application, it is accessible on any device with a modern web browser, including desktops, laptops, tablets, and smartphones. No specialized hardware is required.

How is your project creative?

The project's creativity lies in its social and thematic approach to a technical challenge.

  1. Niche Community Focus: Instead of a generic design tool, we created a specialized social platform. This transforms the solitary act of design into a collaborative, community-driven experience.
  2. Immersive User Interface: The UI/UX is intentionally designed to be futuristic and space-themed. Elements like the "glassmorphism" card style, dark-mode aesthetic, and specialized fonts create an immersive experience that makes users feel like they are part of a forward-thinking, space-age community.
  3. Bridging Disciplines: The Hub creatively merges the technical field of aerospace engineering with creative design, community management, and education, making a complex subject engaging and accessible to a much broader audience.

What factors did your team consider?

  • User Experience (UX): Our primary consideration was making the platform intuitive and easy to use. The process of posting a project and giving feedback needed to be seamless to encourage participation.
  • Accessibility: We aimed for a clean design with readable fonts and a responsive layout that works flawlessly across all devices, ensuring anyone can access the hub from anywhere.
  • Scalability: The technological foundation (Firebase) was chosen to ensure the platform could grow from a small community to a large, active one without performance issues.
  • Positive Community Culture: We considered the need for moderation tools and clear community guidelines from the outset to ensure discussions remain constructive, respectful, and focused on creative problem-solving.
  • Engagement: We included features like upvotes, comments, and tags specifically to drive user engagement and make the platform a dynamic and exciting place to visit regularly.

Using visuals, spatial audio, and even interactive elements, your VR experience can enable users to dive deeper into Earthâ€™s unfolding ocean story. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: SabIA
projectDetails.summary:
SabIA is a web and mobile application that transforms meteorological information into a visual, educational, and entertaining experience.

The idea is simple: an intelligent thrush bird reacts to real-time weather conditions, changing its appearance and behavior according to the detected climate.

More than just displaying numerical data, SabIA helps the user understand what the weather really means whether the day is too hot, too cold, too humid, or simply uncomfortable.

SabIA aims to bring convenience to the hectic urban life as well as to the cyclical life in the countryside. In large cities, even a small change in the weather can delay traffic, cause flooding, and disrupt outdoor events. In rural areas, however, the weather governs the entire production cycle it is crucial to know in advance when the rainy season will begin in order to plan the best time to plant and harvest, as well as to organize the logistics of purchasing seeds and transporting the crops.
projectDetails.details:
SabIA is an intelligent system powered by a machine learning model capable of predicting the weather for a future date based on the temporal data used during training.

Our system can be divided into three layers:

  • The first layer is the user layer, a front end developed as a one-page application/PWA entirely built with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. This layer presents a dashboard displaying meteorological data for the selected date, along with our mascot offering tips on what to do under those weather conditions. Additionally, an AI-powered chatbot is available to provide more detailed information about the weather.
  • The second layer is the API layer, written in Python using the FastAPI framework. It exposes endpoints that are consumed by the front end to build its dashboards.
  • The third and final layer is an AI model trained on meteorological data provided by NASA. We adopted a pre-trained XGBoost model specialized in sequential data through the refinement of decision trees. This layer includes specific models for short-term and long-term forecasts.

The project introduces a new approach to handling meteorological data by using AI specialized in sequential data, such as time series of temperature (maximum and minimum) and wind speed. The main goal is to improve long-term prediction accuracy, which can consequently enhance urban life by making it easier to anticipate floods and heavy rain, as well as rural life by helping plan planting and harvesting schedules.

In addition, a mascot was created to act as a virtual assistant, providing advice on how to respond to different weather conditions offering a more empathetic and engaging way to present weather forecasts.

A preview can be foundÂ here.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Google Gemini was used to generate the mascotâ€™s images and GIFs, ChatGPT was used to assist with content translation, and CursorAI was used for building the front end and making adjustments to the back end. Heygen was used to create a presentation video.

projectDetails.name: Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index
projectDetails.summary: We developed the Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index (EECI), an innovative metric that uses Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data to assess the actual capacity of urban green infrastructure to combat Urban Heat Islands (UHI). The EECI combines vegetation structure and soil moisture, overcoming the limitations of optical satellites by providing a deeper analysis of the functionality of green areas. It addresses the UHI challenge by precisely identifying where new investments in green infrastructure are needed and how to optimize existing areas. Its importance lies in empowering urban planners with actionable data to create more resilient cities, efficiently allocate resources, and promote sustainable, cooler urban development.
projectDetails.details:
Project Details: EECI - Turatteam | NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025

The EECI (Evaporative Cooling Efficiency Index) project, developed by Turatteam for the NASA Space Apps Challenge 2025, aims to evaluate the efficiency of urban green infrastructure in combating Urban Heat Islands (UHI) using Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data.

What does it do or how does it work?

The EECI is an innovative index that combines vegetation structure and soil moisture to measure the evaporative cooling efficiency of green areas. It works through a process of SAR data analysis (Sentinel-1 VV and VH polarizations) collected via Google Earth Engine and Copernicus. The methodology involves:

  1. Data Acquisition: Collection of Sentinel-1 GRD (Ground Range Detected) SAR data with VV and VH polarizations for the SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil area, from January to June 2024.
  2. SAR Processing: Calculation of theÂ Radar Vegetation Index (RVI), which indicates the 3D structural complexity of vegetation (RVI = q[(q+3) / (q+1)Â²] where q = VH/VV), and aÂ Moisture IndexÂ based on VV polarization, sensitive to the surface dielectric constant (Moisture = VV Ã— -1 - 5 / 15).
  3. EECI Calculation: The EECI is obtained by multiplying the Moisture Index by the Structure Index (EECI = Moisture Ã— Structure). Only areas scoring high in both factors receive a high EECI, indicating high evaporative cooling efficiency. Smooth asphalt surfaces, which strongly reflect SAR signals, are excluded from the analysis through land cover masks to ensure accuracy.

What are the benefits?

The main benefits of the project include:

  • Identification of Critical Areas: Allows for the identification of urban areas with low or no cooling efficiency, indicating where the city needs to invest in new green infrastructure.
  • Optimization of Existing Areas: Reveals forested regions with low cooling efficiency, suggesting interventions such as soil irrigation to maximize their potential.
  • Combating Urban Heat Islands: Provides concrete data for urban planning, assisting in the creation of more resilient and comfortable cities, especially in the face of climate change.
  • Detailed Information: Unlike traditional optical satellites, the EECI evaluates the health and functionality of vegetation, not just its presence.

What is the intended impact of the project?

The intended impact of the project is to provide a robust and data-driven tool to inform and optimize urban planning, specifically regarding green infrastructure. By quantifying cooling efficiency, the project aims to empower decision-makers to:

  • Allocate resources more effectively for the creation and maintenance of green areas.
  • Mitigate the effects of Urban Heat Islands, improving citizens' quality of life.
  • Promote sustainable urban development, ensuring that green infrastructure solutions are truly effective.

What tools, programming languages, hardware, or software did you use to develop your project?

Based on the website's information, the main tools and technologies used were:

  • Processing Platform: Google Earth Engine.
  • SAR Data: Copernicus Sentinel-1.
  • Land Cover Data: ESA WorldCover 2020.
  • Programming Language: JavaScript (for the Google Earth Engine code).
  • Frontend: React, Vite (for the build), Tailwind CSS (for styling), Radix UI (components), among other JavaScript libraries for the user interface.

How creative is your project?

The project's creativity lies in its innovative approach to quantifying evaporative cooling efficiency. Instead of simply mapping the presence of vegetation, the EECI integrates multiple factors (vegetation structure and soil moisture) from SAR data, which are less susceptible to atmospheric conditions than optical data. The combination of these indices to create a cooling efficiency metric is a key differentiator, allowing for more precise and actionable analysis for urban planning. The use of Google Earth Engine for lar
projectDetails.aiReferences:
In the development of the EECI project, Artificial Intelligence (AI) was used as a support tool to accelerate innovation and creativity, in accordance with the guidelines of the NASA Space Apps Challenge. Specifically, AI was employed for:

  • Slide Production: AI tools were used to assist in the generation and organization of visual and textual content for presentation slides, optimizing the design process and communication of project ideas.
  • Project Architecture: AI was also consulted to assist in the conception and refinement of the overall project architecture, helping to efficiently structure the different components and workflows.

It is important to note that AI was not used in the main analysis code of the project, which involves the calculation of the EECI and the processing of SAR data. This critical part of the project was developed manually by the team, ensuring the originality and deep understanding of the applied scientific methodology.

challengeDetails.title: Through the Radar Looking Glass: Revealing Earth Processes with SAR
challengeDetails.excerpt: Like Alice in Wonderland, letâ€™s travel down the rabbit hole to reveal a world that looks like our planet Earthâ€¦ but not quite! Using synthetic aperture radar (SAR), we can image the world by emitting radar pulses toward Earth and recording the energy that is reflected back after the signals interact with Earth's surface. Your challenge is to download multi-frequency or multi-polarization SAR data for an interesting study area of your choice â€“e.g., your hometown, a tropical wetland, ice sheet, forest wildfire, flooded neighborhood, volcano eruption, etc.â€”and use that data to develop hypotheses about the physical drivers operating there. (Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: UrbanMinds - Sustainable Urban Planning
projectDetails.summary: We created a website that recommends the best sustainable urban development methods for the userâ€™s selected location. The platform focuses on enhancing residentsâ€™ quality of life while supporting a fast and sustainable city growth. It is important because sustainable urban development is one of the most pressing issues today, since most urban areas worldwide lack an ecologically sound growth, which is vital for improving people's quality of life and other essential aspects.
projectDetails.details:
We created a website that features a map integrating NASA Earth Science data to recommend the best sustainable urban development methods for the userâ€™s selected location (currently limited to a few cities). The platform focuses on enhancing residentsâ€™ quality of life while supporting fast and sustainable city growth. We intend to bring benefits in people's quality of life and urbanization, since it can help with useful information about pollution, helping the development of cities without destroying nature. Used softwares and tools: NASA Worldview, NASA GIBS (Global Imagery Browse Services), OpenStreetMap, Web Map Service (WMS), Canva, Visual Studio Code, Google Docs, Vercel. Used coding languages:JavaScript, HTML, CSS and Python, and Artificial Intelligences were used to assist the coding. Our project is innovative as it provides practical and dynamic solutions, addressing complex issues related to urban infrastructure. This approach enables citizens to actively participate in identifying problems and to request that the appropriate authorities implement effective solutions.

The interactive map, in conjunction with our artificial intelligence, Aurora, facilitates interaction between citizens and the city. This is an interactive website focused on solving social issues, where users can influence local challenges, while solutions are generated by a proprietary artificial intelligence system.

Our team primarily focused on practicality in problem-solving, as well as on the ease of use and integration of user-provided information into the interactive map. Our starting point was the need to establish a connection between governmental action and individual engagement, with the goal of building more structured and sustainable urban spaces.

How it works (detailed):

Our web application loads an index.html code containing our front-end with a brief summary of our project and our two main tools of the project.

The first tool is an interactive map built using NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) data obtained from NASA's MODIS_Terra_NDVI_8Day layer, which is accessed through GIBS. This data is integrated into our interactive map using Leaflet, a JavaScript library, allowing us to visually represent vegetation index across major urban centers around the globe. The map includes markers that provide detailed and interesting information a few locations, presenting informative insights about vegetation levels, temperature variations, and air pollution metrics.

Our second tool is an artificial intelligence, that we called Aurora, implemented with the Grok API, using the Llama3.3 model with a defined personality. This AI receives a location and a local urban-nature problem from the user, processes them, and generates a possible solution that is then displayed to the user, aiming to offer practical recommendations to resolve it.
projectDetails.aiReferences: We used AIs for various purposes, including research, writing improvement, creation of our AI logo, generating our images used in our project, and to assist our AI coding and website coding (Gemini, Grok, and ChatGPT).

projectDetails.name: Project Urbmind
projectDetails.details:
Aqui estÃ¡ uma versÃ£o estruturada, pronta para vocÃª adicionar fotos no final de cada tÃ³pico. Mantive a relevÃ¢ncia cientÃ­fica, o peso dos impactos e deixei os locais para inserir imagens bem definidos.

Urbmind

Natural events are inevitable and can cause tragedies and enormous losses. With technology, we can predict risks, reduce damage, and transform response into prevention.

What the project does


Climate change poses growing challenges for cities.
It affects urban infrastructure... and people's very quality of life.

To address this scenario, we developed a solution focused on UberlÃ¢ndia, Minas Gerais, that combines data provided by NASA to predict natural disasters in real time.

Our system not only identifies flood and climate catastrophe risks, but also generates safe escape routes and sends automatic notifications to authoritiesâ€”Fire Departments, Civil Defense, City Hall, and Military Police.

This project takes an innovative approach, combining climate change analyses provided by NASA itself, soil permeability and relief maps, and predictive analytics to suggest escape routes to avoid potential natural damage.

Although initially implemented in UberlÃ¢ndia, the solution is scalable, allowing its expansion to other cities and regions facing similar climate challenges.

The result is clear: we reduce human and material losses, preserve the environment, and promote sustainable urban growth.
It's technology that saves lives today... and builds safe cities for the future.

Data Acquisition

  • Sentinel-2 Images: RGB, NIR, and SWIR bands with high spatial resolution.
  • SRTM Data: elevation, slope, roughness, and aspect for topographic analysis.
    All data are aligned in the same CRS and grid for pixel-by-pixel analysis

Colored terrain visualization derived from the SRTMGL1 Digital Elevation Model. Each color represents different altitudes, facilitating the interpretation of terrain morphology, valleys, plateaus, and higher elevation areas. This representation provides a detailed view of the landscape, allowing for precise identification of natural drainage patterns, depressions, and areas prone to water accumulation. By highlighting subtle changes in elevation, it supports hydrological analysis, urban planning, and environmental monitoring. Urban planners and engineers can use these visualizations to assess flood risk, optimize infrastructure placement, and design effective stormwater management systems. Additionally, combining this elevation data with other geospatial layers, such as land cover and satellite imagery, enables comprehensive spatial analysis and decision-making for sustainable development and disaster mitigation.

Multispectral Compositions

  • Atmospheric Penetration: highlights urban areas and water bodies.
  • False Color: precise identification of vegetation and plant cover.
  • NDWI: detection of wet areas and water bodies.

Multispectral composition processed from Sentinel-2 L2A imagery with Atmospheric Penetration enhancement, highlighting urban areas, water bodies, and vegetation zones. This technique improves the visibility of elements hidden by dense vegetation, shadows, or atmospheric particles, allowing for a clearer and more accurate interpretation of land cover. By enhancing the contrast between natural and built-up surfaces, it enables detailed land use analysis, identification of impervious surfaces, and detection of potential flood-prone areas. The imagery supports urban planning, environmental monitoring, and infrastructure development by providing actionable insights into how terrain, vegetation, and urbanization interact. Furthermore, when combined with topographic and hydrological data, this multispectral analysis becomes a critical tool for predictive flood modeling, risk assessment, and sustainable city management, ensuring that decision-makers have precise spatial information for proactive interventions.

Elevation Models and Morphometric Analysis

  • Hillshade, Slope, and Aspect: enable visual analysis of topography.
  • Flatness and Smoothness: identify flat or rough terrain.
  • Flow Accumulation Proxy: simulates natural drainage and water accumulation.

Flood History

Geolocated CSV containing latitude, longitude, rainfall intensity, and dates of past events.
Used for risk adjustment in areas near historical events.

Calculation of Hydrological and Urban Indices

  • TWI (Topographic Wetness Index): identifies areas that accumulate water.
  • Imperviousness: combines band brightness and NDWI to map impervious areas.
    Each index is assigned a calibrated weight: TWI and Imperviousness have higher relevance for flood risk.

Dynamic Integration with Rainfall Data

Final flood probability calculated based on:

  • Rainfall intensity (mm/h)
  • Rainfall accumulation (mm)
  • Event duration
  • Proximity to historical events
    Result is a flood risk score calibrated between 0 and 1.

Examples of Calculations and Analyses


Sentinel-2 RGB bands are carefully aligned to the DEM grid, ensuring precise pixel-by-pixel correspondence between optical and topographic data. From these bands, essential indices are calculated: NDWI, highlighting wet areas and water bodies; NDBI, identifying urban and built-up regions; and Impervious, estimating impervious surface presence. These indicators are normalized to standardize their scales and combined with topographic metrics such as TWI (Topographic Wetness Index) and Flow Accumulation, which assess the terrainâ€™s natural tendency to accumulate water and potential drainage flow. Each indicator is weighted based on its physical relevance and impact on flood risk, resulting in a flood susceptibility score that provides a quantitative and spatially detailed view of the most vulnerable areas, supporting urban planning, disaster prevention, and water resource management.

Automation of Data Collection and Storage

Data are constantly updated and stored in real-time on Supabase. N8N automates the collection of weather information from the weather forecast API, recording rainfall, intensity, and duration in the database. This data is available for the back-end to process and calculate the flood probability at each city point, ensuring the front-end displays accurate, up-to-date alerts for users.

Strategic and Societal Impact

The application interface where the user can directly access flood alerts generated by the model. The interactive dashboard displays the city map with highlighted risk zones, colors indicating flood probability, and detailed information on rainfall intensity and duration. Users can explore different areas, view risk statistics, and receive real-time alerts, enabling rapid decision-making and preventive planning.

Benefits

  • Safe Urban Planning: identifies risk areas and guides urban expansion away from vulnerable regions, ensuring that new developments are situated in safer locations and reducing long-term exposure to floods.

Natural Disaster Reduction: helps prevent human and material losses by anticipating flood-prone areas, enabling timely interventions and community preparedness.

Environmental Protection: supports the preservation of riverbanks, green spaces, and fragile ecosystems, maintaining biodiversity and mitigating erosion.

Water Resource Management: facilitates efficient control of floods, dams, canals, and drainage systems, optimizing infrastructure and resource allocation.

Early Warnings: provides real-time information for alerts and evacuations before critical events, enhancing public safety and response effectiveness.

Resilient Infrastructure: allows for the design of buildings, roads, and urban utilities considering actual flood risk, increasing durability and reducing maintenance costs.

Interactive Visualization: users can explore dynamic maps with detailed flood risk information, overlaying multiple datasets for informed decision-making and spatial planning.

Reduced Public Costs: aids in prevention strategies, lowering expenses associated with repairs, emergency responses, and recovery in flood-affected areas.


Urbmind Platform Features

URBMind is an advanced urban analysis platform that predicts flood risks and climate-related hazards in real time, providing strategic support for critical decision-making in safe and sustainable city management.

Key Features

  • Location Search and Personalized Alerts: users can search any address or coordinate and receive instant alerts if there is a flood risk, ensuring rapid response and damage prevention.
  • City-wide Alert Dashboard: clearly displays all active alerts, highlighting risk zones and providing detailed information on intensity, duration, and probability of critical events.
  • Lab Section: allows users to simulate climate and rainfall scenarios by adjusting intensity and duration, evaluating vulnerability in different areas and anticipating potential disasters.
  • Urban Planning Support: provides precise data and analyses to guide urban expansion, infrastructure projects, and construction planning, contributing to resilient and sustainable cities.
  • Interactive Visualization and Real-Time Data: dynamic maps integrating elevation, soil permeability, and flood history data, allowing detailed exploration of high-risk areas.
  • Integration with Meteorological and Historical Data: combines rainfall forecasts, topography, and historical events to generate flood probabilities, enabling effective preventive planning and action.
  • Future Safe Route Support: planned evolution of the platform will provide safe evacuation routes during critical events, integrating risk analysis and topography to guide movement during emergencies.

URBMind is more than an alert tool â€” itâ€™s a strategic platform that transforms complex data into actionable decisions, reducing human and material losses, protecting the environment, and promoting safe urban development.

Project Documentation and Repositories


All the code developed for this project, including the frontend and backend implementations, is available in the repositories below.
The API documentation is also accessible through Swagger for testing and reference purposes.


Frontend Repository

GitHub: UrbmindNasa Frontend

Backend Repository

GitHub: API-Nasa Backend

API Documentation (Swagger)

Swagger Docs: http://148.230.78.172:8000/docs

Essa abordagem Ã© relevante porque automatiza e escala a anÃ¡lise de grandes volumes de dados astronÃ´micos, ajudando a priorizar candidatos promissores para investigaÃ§Ãµes futuras. Ademais, integra ciÃªncia de dados e astrofÃ­sica para promover descobertas em exoplanetologia.
projectDetails.details:
O Exoplanet Hunter 2025 Ã© uma aplicaÃ§Ã£o que utiliza aprendizado de mÃ¡quina para identificar e avaliar a habitabilidade potencial de exoplanetas com base em dados reais do NASA Exoplanet Archive. O sistema emprega um modelo de classificaÃ§Ã£o Random Forest treinado e balanceado com SMOTE, capaz de prever se um planeta pode sustentar condiÃ§Ãµes habitÃ¡veis.

O projeto oferece uma interface interativa em Streamlit, onde o usuÃ¡rio pode enviar dados de planetas, visualizar resultados, interpretar mÃ©tricas de desempenho (como matriz de confusÃ£o e importÃ¢ncia das features) e compreender o processo preditivo.

Os principais benefÃ­cios incluem a automaÃ§Ã£o da triagem de exoplanetas, reduÃ§Ã£o do tempo de anÃ¡lise e apoio a decisÃµes de priorizaÃ§Ã£o para estudos futuros. O impacto pretendido Ã© ampliar o alcance da pesquisa astronÃ´mica e estimular o uso de IA acessÃ­vel para exploraÃ§Ã£o cientÃ­fica.

Ferramentas e tecnologias: Python, scikit-learn, pandas, matplotlib, Streamlit, GitHub, Google Colab e Gamma App (para o slide).

A criatividade do projeto estÃ¡ na integraÃ§Ã£o prÃ¡tica de ciÃªncia de dados e astrofÃ­sica, tornando a detecÃ§Ã£o de exoplanetas mais intuitiva e educativa. A equipe considerou interpretabilidade, usabilidade, transparÃªncia e o uso Ã©tico de IA.

challengeDetails.title: A World Away: Hunting for Exoplanets with AI
challengeDetails.excerpt: Data from several different space-based exoplanet surveying missions have enabled discovery of thousands of new planets outside our solar system, but most of these exoplanets were identified manually. With advances in artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML), it is possible to automatically analyze large sets of data collected by these missions to identify exoplanets. Your challenge is to create an AI/ML model that is trained on one or more of the open-source exoplanet datasets offered by NASA and that can analyze new data to accurately identify exoplanets. (Astrophysics Division)

node.title: WaveHub
node.excerpt: We are Wavehub, a team of friends passionate about technology, innovation, and space exploration. With skills in software development, creativity, and teamwork, we aim to learn, grow, and create impactful solutions at the NASA hackathon.

projectDetails.name: Wave Nimbus
projectDetails.summary:
Problem. Air pollution changes rapidly, and data is fragmented between satellites, ground stations, and meteorology. This delays local forecasts, hinders timely alerts, and reduces the ability of policymakers and citizens to make evidence-based health decisions.

Solution: A professional REST API in Golang for ingesting, processing, and analyzing tropospheric NOâ‚‚ from TEMPO (NASA), also integrating global data and meteorology. The Go core (Gin Framework) offers low latency, robust routing, and documentation via Swagger UI; a scientific module in Python performs advanced analysis (NetCDF, statistics, and unit conversions). The pipeline: (1) discovery/ingestion of TEMPO granules; (2) reading of NetCDF files; (3) spatial/temporal slicing; (4) aggregations (mean/percentiles) and normalization; (5) exposing endpoints such as /no2/now, /no2/timeseries, and /no2/forecast. Docker standardizes local and cloud deployment. The hybrid architecture combines the performance of Go with the scientific flexibility of Python, maintaining stable REST contracts.

Impact. The API transforms complex data into actionable information, enabling early warnings and short-term forecasts, reducing the exposure of sensitive populations, and supporting public policies. By offering a scalable and documented backend, it accelerates multidisciplinary teams, increases transparency, and facilitates the creation of dashboards, mobile apps, and integrations with other air quality sources.
projectDetails.details:
What the project does / how it works

A Golang (Gin) REST API that processes tropospheric NOâ‚‚ (NASA TEMPO) and integrates ground stations (OpenAQ/AirNow) and meteorology (GFS/HRRR/POWER).

Pipeline: granule discovery â†’ NetCDF reading (Python/xarray module) â†’ QA/masking â†’ spatial/temporal subsetting â†’ statistics (mean/percentiles) â†’ satellite+ground+weather fusion â†’ nowcast/forecast (0â€“24h) â†’ AQI + alerts.

Endpoints (e.g.): /no2/now, /no2/timeseries, /no2/forecast, all in JSON with metadata (units, source, period).

Benefits

Actionable information in plain language (AQI) for citizens, schools, and policymakers.

Early alerts that reduce exposure during critical episodes.

Single backbone for future dashboards, mobile apps, and research, with low latency and clear documentation.

Intended impact

Public health: safer daily decisions (outdoor activities, commuting, sports).

Environmental management: supports policy, enforcement, and risk communication.

Open science: reproducibility (Parquet/Swagger) and transparent data sourcing.

Tools, languages, and software

Golang (Gin, Swagger/OpenAPI), Python (xarray, netCDF4), Docker, Redis (cache/queues), Postgres/Timescale or DuckDB (time series), PMTiles (map tiles), Prometheus/Grafana (observability).

Creativity (what sets us apart)

Hybrid architecture (Go + Python) combining API performance with scientific flexibility.

Spatiotemporal fusion with transport variables (wind/PBL) to improve â€œnowâ€ and short-term forecasts.

Pluggable design: switch TEMPO (North America) or Sentinel-5P/OMI (global) without changing the API.

Factors considered

Geographic coverage (NA vs global), data latency, quality/QA, scalability (local â†’ cloud), accessibility (AQI, clear health messaging), AI governance, and compliance (no NASA branding usage).

(Earth Science Division)

projectDetails.name: Project Solar Bloom
projectDetails.summary: Our project addresses the challenge of making scientific data accessible and understandable in order to transform agriculture into a more sustainable practice. Although advanced technologies such as satellite imagery and climate modeling provided by NASA already exist, there is still a significant barrier of access and comprehension that prevents many farmers and communities from benefiting from this information. This results in negative impacts on productivity, resource conservation, and adaptation to climate change. To tackle this issue, we developed an educational game that uses these open datasets as a foundation to teach agricultural challenges and solutions in an intuitive, visual, and accessible way, even for those without technical knowledge. The gameplay is simple and card-based, where players must make decisions in real-life inspired scenarios such as irrigation, fertilization, or climate variations. This allows players to practically understand how these choices affect production and the environment. The game not only entertains but also democratizes access to scientific knowledge, turning complex data into an interactive experience that connects science and society.
projectDetails.details:
Introduction

Solar Bloom is an educational card game designed to make NASAâ€™s agricultural data accessible, engaging, and easy to understand. In the game, players encounter characters facing real farming challenges, such as irrigation, soil health, or climate impacts, and must select strategy cards, each one representing insights drawn from NASAâ€™s open data, to find the best solution. This gamified approach transforms complex scientific information into interactive play, helping farmers, students, and agricultural enthusiasts learn practical applications for space-based technology. By combining fun gameplay with real-world impact, Solar Bloom promotes sustainable decision-making and raises awareness about how space science supports agriculture on Earth. Our goal is to empower diverse communities to use knowledge from space to cultivate smarter, more sustainable futures.

It's our pleasure to welcome you to Solar Bloom!

Presenting Solar Bloom

The experience starts on this page, where you can select to start the game. The entire interface is designed with pixel art, giving it a nostalgic and charming visual style that makes the experience feel both retro and unique. This artistic choice helps create an inviting atmosphere.

When the game begins, you find yourself in a small wooden room. At that moment, an assistant named Leo shows up, heâ€™s there to guide you, explain what needs to be done, and help you complete the missions step by step. Having an assistant like Leo makes the game easier to understand and more accessible for everyone. It helps new players quickly learn the mechanics, reduces confusion, and allows people of different ages and backgrounds to enjoy the game without feeling lost.

Soon after, people from different countries start appearing, each asking for your help with various tasks, each one related to agricultural problems from their own country.

The player's mission is to select and deliver the card that corresponds to the person's problem in order to solve it. However, the player must be careful, as each letter has its own advantages and disadvantages. Every correct card match propels the story forward, deepening the narrative. Your accuracy unlocks new cards to solve more complex problems and attract new clients from different regions.

Technical Details

In this section, the technical aspects of the project will be presented.

The game was developed in C# using the Godot engine. Godot is a free and open-source game engine known for its flexibility and active community, ideal for creating 2D and 3D games.

All the pixel art for the game was created using Pixilart, a free online platform dedicated to pixel art creation.

Throughout development, a key focus was maintaining simplicity and clarity. To ensure the game is easy to understand, we avoided overly long or confusing dialogues, complex mechanics, and excessive technical or detailed information in the game itself.

Future Improvements

  • Expanded Narrative:Â Introduce more characters and problems to solve, increasing the game's depth and replayability.
  • Card System :Â Add new cards with innovative solutions and distinct advantages. This lets you address and solve a wider range of complex problems.
  • Multi-Language Support:Â Translate the game into several languages, to make it accessible to a global audience.
projectDetails.aiReferences: Throughout the project, we utilized ChatGPT (GPT-5) to enhance the writing quality, assist in logo creation, and support code generation and refinement.

projectDetails.name: Project Solarius
projectDetails.summary:
The objective of this project is to develop an interactive website that encourages children to investigate the intriguing realm of space weather, through a character, called "Solaris", the solar flare. The website helps kids understand how changes in the Sun and Earth can impact our technology and the environment by transforming complicated scientific concepts into something entertaining and simple to understand through interactive simulations, films, animations, and enjoyable activities.
This project makes science interesting and immersive. It illustrates how space weather affects daily life and contemporary technology by combining important concepts from space physics, such as the heliosphere, magnetosphere, and ionosphere. The project is important to prevent communication, navigation, and power system disruptions, educating people about and monitoring these phenomena. It also serves as a reminder of how interconnected we are with events occurring beyond our planet. It's more than just a website, it's a educational resource that stimulates interest, promotes exploration, and teaches youth the importance of space science both here on Earth and elsewhere.
projectDetails.details:
What exactly does it do?

  • Delivers a 25-page interactive storyÂ following Solaris, a solar flare character, as it travels from the Sun to Earth, affecting various technologies along the way
  • Features 7 unique charactersÂ representing different professions impacted by space weather: ISS astronaut Sofia, tech farmer Pedro, aviation pilot Captain Ana, NOAA scientist Dr. John, power grid operator Maria, and satellite controller Bruno
  • Provides realistic audio experiencesÂ based on scientific data, including solar wind frequencies (40-350Hz), authentic ISS alarms, tractor engine sounds, jet turbines, and electrical transformer harmonics
  • Implements an achievement systemÂ that rewards exploration and learning progress with badges like "Space Explorer" and "Cosmic Scholar"
  • Teaches real space weather impactsÂ on GPS agriculture, aviation routes, power grids, satellite communications, and International Space Station operations using authentic NASA data
  • Includes interactive navigationÂ with keyboard controls, sound toggles, volume controls, and random page access for personalized exploration

How does it work?

  • Frontend Architecture: Built with HTML (11.2%), CSS (50.1%), and JavaScript (38.7%) using modern web technologies
  • Audio System: Utilizes Web Audio API and ElevenLabs to create scientifically-based sounds including pattern sequences, frequency sweeps, and harmonic generators that simulate real space weather phenomena
  • State Management: JavaScript class-based architecture maintains user progress, visited pages, achievements, and audio preferences across the session
  • Content Delivery: Modular page system with dynamic content loading, scientific data integration, and responsive design for multiple devices
  • Educational Integration: Each page incorporates real NASA data including solar core temperatures (15 millionÂ°C), Earth-Sun distance (150 million km), ISS altitude (408 km), and solar wind speeds (300-800 km/s)

What benefits does it have?

  • Makes complex science accessibleÂ by transforming technical space weather concepts into relatable character-driven narratives
  • Addresses real-world relevanceÂ as solar storms recently caused over $500 million in agricultural damages and disrupted GPS systems used by farmers
  • Aligns with NASA educational prioritiesÂ supporting Space Weather Centers of Excellence and SWREDI initiatives
  • Promotes STEM educationÂ through authentic scientific data while maintaining engaging storytelling elements
  • Builds space weather awarenessÂ crucial for our technology-dependent society, especially as solar activity increases during the current solar maximum
  • Supports multilingual learningÂ by presenting NASA content in Portuguese, making it accessible for Brazilian students
  • Demonstrates practical impactsÂ showing how space weather affects GPS farming equipment, aviation safety, power grids, and satellite operations that students encounter daily

What do we hope to achieve?

  • Increase space weather literacyÂ among young learners, preparing them for a future where understanding solar-terrestrial interactions becomes increasingly important
  • Inspire future scientistsÂ by showing real-world applications of space science through relatable characters and scenarios
  • Bridge the gapÂ between complex NASA research and public understanding, making space weather as recognizable as terrestrial weather
  • Create lasting educational impactÂ through memorable characters and interactive experiences that make learning space science engaging rather than intimidating
  • Contribute to global space weather awarenessÂ supporting NASA's mission to protect technological infrastructure from space weather events
  • Demonstrate effective science communicationÂ by combining rigorous scientific accuracy with creative storytelling and modern web technologies

Tools, Languages & Technologies Used:

  • Frontend: HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript (ES6+)
  • Audio Technology: Web Audio API, synthetic sound generation, frequency modulation
  • Scientific Data: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory data, NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center information
  • Development Tools: Git/GitHub for version control, responsive web design principles
  • Content Management: Modular JavaScript architecture, JSON data structures for story content
  • Accessibility: Keyboard navigation, volume controls, audio toggle functionality
  • Educational Framework: Based on NASA Space Weather Research, Education, Development Initiative (SWREDI) standards
projectDetails.aiReferences:
Our team used AI tools in some aspects of our project to accelerate creativity, improve design quality, and overall development, such as the organization of the ideas and brainstorming.

Visuals & Storytelling:
Google Veo was used to create some images.
We got ElevenLabs to get some audios and soundtracks for our website.

We used Vercel V0 for coding assistance to help structure the website, refine some components and ensure the best integration across tabs and features.

Perplexity AI fixed some syntax and formatting errors in the website code.


Resources and Informatios:


Perplexity AI helped us organizing the flow of the website, summary and some major mistakes that went unnoticed.
We used BlackBox AI to fix some typos and text formatting errors.

Google Gemini Pro was adopted in the final opinion of the project and in possible improvements to be made.

By administering these AI tools with responsibly and with care, we were able to focus more on creativity and innovation, not to mention accessibility, while ensuring transparency in what purposed AI was applied.

challengeDetails.title: Stellar Stories: Space Weather Through the Eyes of Earthlings
challengeDetails.excerpt: Although the Sun is 93 million miles away from our planet, solar activity can significantly impact our daily lives. â€œSpace weatherâ€â€”the variations that occur in the space environment between the Sun and Earthâ€”can impact technologies in space and on Earth. Your challenge is to write and illustrate a digital childrenâ€™s story that explains what space weather is and the varying impacts it has on different people such as farmers, pilots, astronauts, power grid operators, and the general public. You can tell the story from the perspective of a person impacted by space weather or from the point of view of a solar flare or coronal mass ejection (CME) as it approaches Earth. (Heliophysics Division)

projectDetails.name: Future Weather - XBigDevs
